lessons.text:
Welcome to the HTML basics tutorial!

This tutorial is aimed at anyone who wants to start with web development, you do not need any prior knowledge, here you will learn how to develop templates for your designs, using only HTML.

Let's start. What is HTML?

Let's pretend that our website is a building, then HTML is the structure of the building, that is, the columns that support the building but are not exposed to the outside, they are behind how the website works. Using the same analogy the building has bricks which are small units that make up the structure. In the case of HTML its bricks are called tags.

What is a tag?

It is a piece of code that represents something on a web page, for example, a tag can define a button, a text field, an image, etc.

As you can see in this example, each tag (a line of code) displays different web elements.

How to create a tag?

HTML tags are created as follows:

  • Opening tag.

  • Closing tag.

To tell HTML that you will include a tag, you will use the "less than" and "greater than" signs.

Opening tag:

Is created with 3 steps.

  1. Add a less-than sign (<).

  2. Add tag name (NameOfTag).

  3. Add a greater-than sign (>)

 <NameOfTag>

Closing tag:

  1. Add a less-than sign (<).

  2. Add a slash sign (/).

  3. Add a tag name (NameOfTag).

  4. Add a greater-than sign (>).

 </NameOfTag>

Together it looks like this:

 <NameOfTag></NameOfTag>

This is a real example, where we are defining a button that inside has the text send:

 <button>send</button>

You can add content between the tags to display it:

 <name>content</name>

Do the following in the HTML editor:

  • Replace the <!--add your code here--> comment with the following code:

     <h1>Hello world!</h1>

  • Hit the run code button at the top, the result should be the same as the expected result tab.

  • Hit the send code button at the top, you should get a 100%.

Congratulations, now you can continue to the next lesson!

Can you modify a tag?

Yes, you can!

HTML tags can be modified by adding attributes

But, what is an attribute?

They are special words used within the opening tag to change properties of the tag, for example the font color or size, here's the syntax:

<tag attribute="value">

The attribute part is attribute="value"

A real-world example would be:

<button style="color: red">

Where style="color: red" is the attribute of that tag, the attribute is created as follows:

  1. Add attribute name (example: style)

  2. Add an equal sign ( = )

  3. Add attribute value between quotes ("color: red")

Do the following in the HTML editor:

We are going to change the color of the text using a style attribute.

  • Replace the text <!--add your code here--> with the following code:

     <h1>Hello world</h1>

  • Hit run code at the top and see the changes.

  • Add this attribute to the <h1> tag:

     style="color: red"

  • Hit run code at the top, the result should be the same as the expected result tab.

  • Hit send code at the top, and you should get 100%.

Congratulations, now you can continue to the next lesson!

HTML structure

To create a website you should have an HTML structure, it helps you organize your code as the website grows, let's create it!

An HTML structure is created as follows:

  1. A non-closing <!DOCTYPE html> tag to specify the document type.

  2. An <html> tag.

  3. Between the <html> tag goes a <head> tag and a <body> tag.

Example:

 <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
 <head>
 </head>
 <body>
 </body>
</html>

Notice that in this case we have tags inside other tags and we also add ENTERS inside the tag's content.

Do the following in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--add your code here--> text with the following code:

     <!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
  </head>
  <body>
    <!--add hello world here-->
  </body>
</html>

  • Once the code from the previous instruction has been added, replace the <!--add hello world here--> text with the following code:

     <h1 class="my-title">hello world</h1>

  • Hit run code at the top, the result should be the same as the expected result tab.

  • Hit send code at the top, and you should get 100%.

Congratulations, now you can continue to the next lesson!

How can I write a text with titles, subtitles and paragraphs?

In order to write a text, let's say a blog entry or a book. You only need titles of different sizes and paragraphs. These are represented in HTML with tags:

  1. <p> tags are used to render paragraphs or text.

  2. <h1> to <h6> any of these tags indicate a title of varying importance.

Title tag or header tag.

Heading tags or title tags are HTML elements that are used to create titles and subtitles.

To create the tag, the first letter of the word heading is used (h), and there are six headings defined by HTML, ranging from 1 to 6, <h1> has the biggest font size while <h6> has the smallest font size.

Example :

  • <h1>

  • <h2>

  • <h3>

  • <h4>

  • <h5>

  • <h6>

with h1 having the biggest importance and h6 having the least importance.

Do the following in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--add your code here--> comment with the following code:

    <h1>Tag h1</h1>
<h2>Tag h2</h2>
<h3>Tag h3</h3>
<h4>Tag h4</h4>
<h5>Tag h5</h5>
<h6>Tag h6</h6>

  • Hit run code at the top, the result should be the same as the expected result tab.

  • Hit send code at the top, and you should get 100%.

Notice that each title tag has a different size ranging from a big font size and going all the way to a small font size.

Congratulations, now you can continue to the next lesson!

Now let's look at how we can write paragraphs

The <p> tag renders text, it is named after the first letter of the paragraph word.

 <p>any text you'd like</p>

Do the following in your HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--add your code here--> comment with the following code:

     <p>This is my first text in HTML</p>

  • Hit run code at the top, the result should be the same as the expected result tab.

  • Hit send code at the top, and you should get 100%.

Congratulations, now you can continue to the next lesson!

Anchor tag <a>, to design links

We continue with links in HTML.

What is a link in HTML?

A link or link It is a text with which it can be used to redirect to a specific point of our app or to another website.

How to create a label?

Link tags or links are created as follows:

 <a href="url">texto</a>

The href attribute is used to redirect to some route or address.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--add your label here--> comment with the following code:

     <a href="#">Enlace sin redirección</a>

    For now we will use the value of # to indicate that we will not redirect that link anywhere.

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Lists in HTML!

What are lists?

They are tags that allow you to structure the content of your web page, with this you can highlight content for the user.

These lists come in two forms, ordered lists, and unordered lists.

Ordered lists:

As its name indicates, they are lists that are used to display information in an orderly manner.

Example:

They are created as follows:

 <ol> <li>item-1<li> <li>item-1<li> </ol>

  • As you can see, the <ol> tag of the abbreviation for "ordered list" is used, that is, "ordered list".

  • As you can see inside the <ol> tag there are some <li> tags, these are used to generate the content of the list, that is, each element of the list. Its abbreviation comes from the word "list item".

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu etiqueta de listas ordenadas aquí--> with the following code:

     <ol> <li>Nombre</li> <li>Apellidos</li> <li>Direción</li> <li>Teléfono</li> <li>Localidad</li> </ol>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Lists in HTML part 2!

Unordered lists:

As the name implies, they are lists that are used to display information in an unordered manner.

Example:

Unlike the ordered list, you can see that its elements are not separated by ordered numbers, but by periods.

They are created as follows:

 <ul> <li>item-1<li> <li>item-1<li> </ul>

  • As you can see, the <ul> tag is used for the abbreviation of "unordered list" that is, "unordered list".

  • As you can see inside the <ul> tag there are some <li> tags, these are used to generate the content of the list, that is, each element of the list. Its abbreviation comes from the word "list item".

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--añade tu etiqueta h4 aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <h4>Nuestras sedes</h4>

    We will create a title for our list of venues.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu etiqueta de listas no ordenadas aquí--> with the following code:

     <ul> <li>Colombia</li> <li>Argentina</li> <li>Mexico</li> <li>USA</li> <li>UK</li> </ul>

    As you can see, we created a list in which no element has priority, for example, Colombia can go first, how can the USA be.

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note : This is the most common way of making lists, most of the time <ul> is used more than <ol> since most of the time it is not ordered data that needs to be displayed.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Images in HTML!

Images tag:

As its name indicates, it is a label with which we can display images for our web application.

They are created as follows:

Example:

As you can see in this image, to add an image in html you use the <img/> tag, this is a tag that does not need a closing, you can call it as you see in the image or close it with a slash as follows:

 <img src="image-url"/>

This tag has some attributes:

  • src : The URL of the image.

  • alt : This attribute defines the text that users will see if the image URL is wrong or if the browser does not support the image format or if the image has not been downloaded yet.

  • height : The height of the image.

  • width : The width of the image.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--añade tu etiqueta de imagen aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <img src="https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2022/05/27/06/34/tre-cime-di-lavaredo-7224478__340.jpg" alt="bosque" width="60%" height="60vh"/>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Buttons in HTML!

Label to generate buttons:

It is a label with which we can display images for our web application.

They are created as follows:

Example:

 <button>enviar</button>

As you can see in the example, to add a button in html you use the <button> tag.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu etiqueta button aquí--> with the following code:

     <button>Contactar</button>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations, you have completed the course!

Basic template.

Replicate the design proposed on the right side of the screen, where it says "Expected result".

Steps to follow:

  1. Replace the <!--añade tu estructura aquí--> comment and create an html structure.

  2. Create a header containing a navigation menu ( nav ) and add the following attribute to the nav class="my-menu" tag.

  3. Create a section and add the following:

    1. For the section add the following attributes: class="content-down" style="height: 72vh" and you will create:

      1. A container and add these attributes: class="message-1" style="font-size: 12px;" .

      2. Inside the container create an h5 title and a comment section with a button.

  4. Create a footer.

  5. Add this code inside the head tag:

     <style> body { padding: 0px; margin: 0px; } header { background: #000; color: #fff; height: 15vh; width: 100%; margin: 0px; display: flex; justify-content: start; align-items: center; } .my-menu ul { display: flex; flex-direction: row; justify-content: center; align-items: center; list-style-type:none; } .my-menu ul li { margin: 4px; font-size: 14px; } .my-menu ul li a{ color: #fff; text-decoration: none; } .my-menu ul li a:hover{ background: #fff; color: #000; } footer { background: #000; height: 13vh; color: #fff; text-align: center; display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; } .content-down { display: flex; flex-direction: row; justify-content: center; } .message-1 { width: 100%; display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: center; text-align: center; } </style>

Welcome to the HTML Forms and Containers tutorial!

We continue with containers in HTML.

What is the div tag used for in HTML?

When talking about containers in HTML we refer to the <div> tag, this tag is used to contain blocks of tags, for example.

 <div> <h1>titulo</h1> <p>texto</p> </div>

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--add your label here--> comment with the following code:

     <p>Quiero que sea negro</p>

  • Hit the “run code” button at the top.

  • We see that the paragraph is red instead of black. Then cut the paragraph <p>Quiero que sea negro</p> and replace it with <!--Esta es una segunda opción-->

  • Hit the “run code” button again, at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

input tag!

What are input tags ?

They are tags that allow you to capture user data, usually used for forms.

Example:

They are created as follows:

 <input />

As you can see it is a tag without closure.

Main attributes :

  • type : Specifies the type of the input.

  • value : Value to display.

Input types :

You can create different input by adding the type tag such as <input type="email"/> .

  • type="text" : Specifies that the input type is to be of type text.

  • type="email" : Specifies that the input type will be of type email.

  • type="file" : Specifies that the input type is to be of type file.

  • type="number" : Specifies that the input type is to be a numeric type.

  • type="search" : Specifies that the input type is to be a search type.

  • type="url" : Specifies that the input type is to be of type URL.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tus etiquetas input aquí--> with the following code:

     tipo texto: <input type="text" value="texto"> <br/> tipo email: <input type="email" value="thiago@peaku.co"> <br/> tipo file: <input type="file" style="font-size: 12px"> <br/> tipo numerico: <input type="number" value="0"> <br/> tipo búsqueda: <input type="search" value="busqueda"> <br/> tipo URL: <input type="url" value="https://peaku.co"> <br/>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

label tag !

It is a tag that allows you to select the input when the user clicks on the text.

They are created as follows:

 <label>texto</label>

Let's see an example to understand it better.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--añade tus etiquetas aquí--> comment with the following code:

     Haz click: <input type="text" value="texto"> <br/> <label id="label-tag">Haz click: <input type="text" value="texto"></label> <br/>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

textarea tag!

It is a tag that allows you to create a large text field for the user.

Example:

As you can see, the first one is a textarea field and the field in red is of type input , the difference is that the textarea is more to include very wide texts like a comment.

They are created as follows:

 <textarea></textarea>

Let's see an example to understand it better.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--añade tus etiquetas aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <label id="label-textarea">comentarios: </label> <textarea id="id-textarea"></textarea> <br/>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “run bot” button at the top, it should write over the textarea of both windows.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get should be 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

form tag!

It is a tag that allows you to create a form.

They are created as follows:

 <form> <!--tus inputs--> </form>

Let's see an example to understand it better.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

Replace the <!--añade tu formulario acá--> comment with the following code:

 <form id="form-id" onsubmit="document.getElementById('div-id').style.display = 'none';document.getElementById('success-id').style.display = 'block';return false;"> <label>Nombre: <input id="name-id" type="text" value="nombre"></label> <br/> <label>Comentario: <textarea id="textarea-id">añade un comentario</textarea></label> <br/> <input id="submit-id" type="submit" value="Enviar"> </form>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations, you have completed the course!

Welcome to the Generating Structures in HTML tutorial!

Let's start by creating the header.

What is header?

It is the header of your application, I will show you an example:

To create the header of an application, use the tag <header> .

 <header>contenido</header>

We are going to create our header, don't worry about creating the styles, we will put them for you.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--añade tu etiqueta header aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <header>Este es el encabezado de mi app</header>

    As you can see, you have created a header for your app.

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Creating a navigation bar or navbar!

So that the user can go to various parts of our app, a navigation bar is used, usually it is in the same header , as you can see in this example:

To create the navigation bar you will use the tag <nav> , but to create its items you use the lists you learned earlier.

 <nav>contenido</nav>

We are going to create our navigation bar, don't worry about creating the styles, we will put them for you.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu etiqueta nav aquí--> with the following code:

     <nav> <ul> <li><a href="#">Inicio</a></li> <li><a href="#">Sobre nosotros</a></li> <li><a href="#">Contacto</a></li> </ul> </nav>

  • Press the "run code" button at the top, the result and observe the changes .

    • As you can see, you have created a navigation bar for your app, but you still need to add one more step.

  • Add the following attribute to the <nav> tag:

     class="my-menu"

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Creating a footer !

A footer is the area of your website that appears at the bottom of your site footer , as seen in this example:

To create the footer you will use the tag <footer> .

 <footer>contenido</footer>

We are going to create our footer, do not worry about creating the styles, we will put them for you.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--añade tu etiqueta footer aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <footer>pie de página</footer>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

HTML sections!

The <section> tag generates a block with which we can include several tags.

Let's understand it better by writing code.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment in <!--añade tu primera etiqueta section aquí--> with the following code:

     <section style="height: 30vh; background: red;"></section>

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu segunda etiqueta section aquí--> with the following code:

     <section class="content-down" style="height: 42vh; background: blue;"></section>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

    As you can see in the example, you have just created two sections where you can include several tags :)

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

We continue!

Let's see how those sections with more content would be.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--añade tu etiqueta de imagen aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <img src="https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2022/06/08/05/46/physics-7249773__340.jpg" height="90%" width="100%"/>

  • Replace the <!--añade tus etiquetas del contenido secundario aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <div class="message-1" style="font-size: 12px;"> <h5>principal</h5> <p style="font-size: 12px;">Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Repellendus ut, voluptatum expedita ullam quisquam reiciendis.</p> </div> <div class="message-2"> <h5>otros productos</h5> <p style="font-size: 8px;">Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit.</p> </div>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

    As you can see in the example, you have just created content in the two sections that you created in the previous class.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations, you have completed the course!

Structuring a template in HTML .

Replicate the design proposed on the right side of the screen, where it says "Expected result".

Steps to follow:

  1. Replace the <!--añade tu estructura aquí--> comment and create an html structure.

  2. Create a header containing a navigation menu ( nav ) and add the following attribute to the nav class="my-menu" tag.

  3. Create two sections and add the following:

    1. For the first section add the following attribute style="height: 30vh;" and inside that section create an image

      1. Image URL: https://media.istockphoto.com/photos/streaming-online-watching-video-on-internet-picture-id1336543971?b=1&k=20&m=1336543971&s=170667a&w=0&h=yUEMKwno8mQS-2tl0w4ujiSTxNOlFhx1vVax1Phvfko= .

      2. Add the following attributes to the image: height="90%" width="100%" .

    2. For the second section add the following attributes: class="content-down" style="height: 42vh" and you will create:

      1. A container and add these attributes: class="message-1" style="font-size: 12px;" .

      2. Inside the container create an h5 title and a paragraph.

      3. For the paragraph add this attribute: style="font-size: 12px;" .

  4. Create a footer.

  5. Add this code inside the head tag:

     <style> body { padding: 0px; margin: 0px; } header { background: #000; color: #fff; height: 15vh; width: 100%; margin: 0px; display: flex; justify-content: start; align-items: center; } .my-menu ul { display: flex; flex-direction: row; justify-content: center; align-items: center; list-style-type:none; } .my-menu ul li { margin: 4px; font-size: 14px; } .my-menu ul li a{ color: #fff; text-decoration: none; } .my-menu ul li a:hover{ background: #fff; color: #000; } footer { background: #000; height: 13vh; color: #fff; text-align: center; display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; } .content-down { display: flex; flex-direction: row; justify-content: center; } .message-1 { width: 100%; display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: center; text-align: center; } </style>

welcome to css

We welcome you to this CSS course from scratch, here you will have the opportunity to learn the basics of this style language with which you can give your web projects a better look.

Note: To take this course you must have at least basic knowledge of the structure language or HTML, if you still don't know what this is, don't worry, since we have a course for it in our front-end course.

Selectors

A selector in CSS is the way we can access a tag in the HTML and thus change its styles.

There are 5 main types of selectors, which are:

  • universal selector

  • tag selector

  • class selector

  • ID picker

  • Attribute Picker

universal selector

As its name indicates, the universal selector is used to refer to all the tags in the HTML document, to use it the * sign is used followed by opening and closing braces {...} .

Look at the following example:

 * { color: blue; font-family: sans-serif; }

What the above snippet will do is select all the tags inside the HTML and apply a blue font color and sans-serif font to them.

Everything we define inside the curly braces {...} they are attributes and values, you can identify them because the attributes are the ones at the beginning, that is, on the left followed by a colon : and the value that we want, if we take the previous example as a reference then it is as if we were saying “I want the color of all the letters to be blue”.


Let's do it

Notice that an initial code like the following already appears in the HTML editor:

 <div> <h1>¡Hola mundo!</h1> <p>I'm learning CSS</p> </div>

It is time then to style it with CSS

  1. Click the run button.

You will be able to see that the result is a black text, this comes by default in HTML, we are going to modify it.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Write your code here */ with:

 * { color: blue; font-family: sans-serif; }

  1. Again click the run button.

This time you will be able to observe how all the words have a blue color, just what we needed.

  1. Finally click on the “ send code ” button so we can rate your result and give you a score.

Very well, you have completed this lesson on the universal selector, see you in the next one where you will see how to use the tag selectors and some more properties that we can use.

tag selectors

As its name implies, tag selectors allow us to select some type of tag in the HTML document, and thus be able to edit only its scope.

The moment we begin to differentiate some things from others we can have more control over the styles that we are adding, this is known as specificity and it increases as we delve into the HTML. We will see this throughout this course, so don't worry if you don't know what it is yet.

Alright let's see how tag selectors are used in CSS.

Notice that the following code is already written in the HTML editor:

 <div> <h1>Quiero que este texto sea gris</h1> <p>Y este sera amarillo</p> </div>

What we want to achieve is to select the <h1> and <p> tags to give each a different style.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* h1 tag styles */ with the following:

 h1 { color: gray; font-family: sans-serif; }

  1. Click the “run code” button.

Note that now the content of the <h1> tag is in gray and with sans-serif typography, also note that every time we have to separate properties we do it with a semicolon ( ; ), in this case we need to separate the color property from font-family .

  1. Now replace the comment that says /* p tag styles */ in the CSS editor with the following:

 p { color: yellow; font-size: 50px; }

  1. Again click the “run code” button.

In this case we have given the content of the <p> tag a yellow color and increased the size of the font to 50 pixels.

  1. It's time to rate your code. To do so, click on the “send code” button and check your results.

Congratulations you have completed this lesson, follow your pace and let's continue to the next lesson.

class selectors

The class selectors help us to choose only the tags in the HTML that have a specific class, for example, if we have 5 <div></div> tags but only three have the class=“color-verde” then only select those three labels.

Let's see how we can use the class selectors. For this, notice that in the HTML editor there is a code like the following:

 <div> <section> <h1 class="titulo">Selectores de clase</h1> </section> <section class="contenedor"> <p class="parrafo">CSS es muy cool.</p> <p class="parrafo">Quiero seguir aprendiendo.</p> <p>Este párrafo no tiene estilos :(</p> </section> </div>

Notice that we have 4 classes of which two of them are repeated, now let's see how we can select those classes with CSS.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the /* Container class styles */ comment with the following:

 .contenedor { background-color: lightgray; }

Note that the way to select a class is by using a dot before the class name.

This container will have a light gray background color.

  1. Click the “run code” button.

Time to style the title.

  1. Go back to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Title class styles */ with:

 .titulo { color: blue; font-size: 25px; }

  1. Finally, let's style the <p class=”paragraph”> tags, replace the /* Paragraph class styles */ comment with the following:

 .parrafo { margin: 3px; color: red; }

  1. Click the “run code” button again.

Notice that only the first two paragraphs have styles, while the last paragraph just appears as it is by default.

The margin property indicates that the container, in this case those with the "paragraph" class, will have a margin around it of 3 pixels.

It's time to submit your results.

  1. Click the “send code” button and check your results

You do very well, now let's continue with the next lesson where you will learn about ID selectors, see you there.

ID selectors

ID Selectors have the highest level of specificity, this means that everything that is included in the styles of a tag with the id property will be taken as the most important, for example, if the same tag has the class and id properties and both modify the background color, only the color specified using the id will be displayed.


In theory there should only be 1 equal id in the entire HTML document, unlike classes that can be used as many times as we need.

Now let's see how the IDs work in the HTML document and more importantly how we can select them from CSS, to do this go to the HTML editor, there you will find a snippet like the following:

 <div> <h1>Selector de ID</h1> <article> <p class="parrafo-normal">Este párrafo no tiene ID</p> <p id="parrafo-id">Este párrafo SI tiene ID</p> <p class="parrafo-normal">Este párrafo no tiene ID</p> </article> </div>

Note that only one <p> tag has the property id=”parrafo-id” As we have already said, this is because there should only be one identifier of the same type.

In the CSS editor you will see that a preview and a comment appear at the end, which will be where we will write our code.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Write your code here */ with the following:

 #parrafo-id { background-color: lightblue; padding: 5px; border: 1px solid black; }

Note that the way to refer to an identifier in HTML is by using a hash ( # ) followed by the name of the identifier, in this case #parrafo-id .

  1. Click the “run code” button.

What we have done with this selector is to give the label a light blue background, followed by a padding or internal margin of 5 pixels and finally a black border one pixel thick.

Alright, time to check your results.

  1. Click the “send code” button and see how it went.

Excellent, we only need one more step in terms of selectors, so you can continue to the next lesson where you will learn about attribute selectors, see you there.

Attribute Selectors

Attribute selectors, as their name indicates, are useful when selecting attributes from a label. There are many ways to select by attributes, even using search patterns, but for practical purposes in this course we will limit ourselves to the way more basic so you can understand it better.

As usual we have a small structure in HTML like the following, which you can also find in the respective editor.

 <div class="contenedor"> <h1 id="title">Learn web development</h1> <hr> <a href=; target="_black">Aprende y consigue tu trabajo soñado</a> <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/es" target="_black">Desarrollo front-end</a> <a href="https://www.freecodecamp.org/" target="_black">Desarrollo fullstack</a> </div>

Notice that <a></a> link tags have 2 attributes, href and target , we are going to select the first of them to be able to apply styles in CSS.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Write your code here */ with the following

 [href] { color: darkblue; margin: 3px; text-decoration: none; display: block; }

As you can see, the only thing we need to refer to an attribute in CSS is to enclose it in square brackets [atributo] .

  1. Click the "run code" button.

On this occasion the styles applied were a dark blue font color, a 3-pixel margin, we removed the underline that the <a> tags have by default and finally we made them display as a block for better visualization.

Note: Do not worry if by now you do not understand what they are or what the styles that we can apply are, since they will be seen in greater depth in later sessions of this CSS course.

  1. Click the “send code” button and check your results.


Very well you have completed this session of the CSS course where you learned about the 5 main selectors and their uses. Don't forget to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✔ "check" button in the top right corner of your screen.

COLORS AND SIZES

Welcome to the CSS course, in this module you will learn about colors and their different ways of declaring them in styles, in addition we will also see what corresponds to sizes, their types and uses.

Colors

We have several ways to declare colors in CSS, this time we will see the 3 most common and that you can find most frequently anywhere.

Add color by names

The easiest method of being able to add colors to a CSS tag is by using the color name, these names come by default with the language so you don't have to worry about importing them or anything like that.

The way to add colors to the property you need is as follows:

 selector { propiedad: nombreDelColor; }

Property: Can be anything that supports color such as background-color, border, color, etc.

ColorName: Any color supported by CSS, see which ones are possible here .  

Let's do it.

It is time to put it into practice for a better understanding, for this, as is customary throughout this series of tutorials, we have an advance in the HTML editor, so now we must provide its respective styles.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Letter class styles */ with the following:

 .carta { background-color: tomato; text-align: center; }

  1. Click the “run code” button.

As you can see the background color has changed to the specified one.

  1. Now replace the comment that says /* h3 tag styles */ with:

 h3 { color: gold; }

  1. Again click on “run code”.

  2. Finally let's style the <p> tag, to do so replace the /* Styles of the p tag */ comment with this:

 p { color: darkSlateGray; font-weight: bold; }

Notice that in each style block, we defined a different color, these were tomato, gold and darkSlateGray respectively. The above are just three of the many colors that are available.

You do very well, it's time to see a more customizable color type, we are talking about RGB colors which we will delve into in the next lesson, see you there.

RGB colors

RGB colors can be understood as an extension that we can use to generate colors of almost any scale that we need.

Its use and implementation is as follows:

 selector { propidedad: rgb(valor1, valor2, valor3); }

Explanation.

rgb(): It is the function that we need to add the desired values, the letter r means red or red in English, g is green or green and b is blue or blue.

Values: The values inside the parentheses are a number between 0 and 255, being 0 the absence of color and 255 the total presence, this means that any variation like 145 is a melange. We combine 3 values because they are three colors (red, green and blue).

Let's do it.

We will create 5 squares to make it easier for you to understand how the colors created with RGB work.

Note that in the HTML there are 5 different IDs ( c-1 , c-2 , c… ), and in the CSS editor there is an initial code which you may already know a little about, but if not, don't worry as is not the main topic of this lesson, so you can continue without problems.

  1. Run the code and you will see 5 squares with a simple background color.

Now let's make the first square white.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the /* color square 1 */ comment with:

 #c-1 { background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); }

  1. Again click the run button.

As you can see the first square has changed its color, just what we need.

Now let's change the color of the other squares and then we'll go on to explain what happens.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* color of the following squares */ with the following:

 #c-2 { background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0); color: rgb(255, 255, 255) } #c-3 { background-color: rgb(255, 0, 0); } #c-4 { background-color: rgb(0, 255, 0); } #c-5 { background-color: rgb(0, 0, 255); }

  1. Click the “send code” button, you can see your score is 100%.

Notice that for each square we define the background-color property and the values inside rgb() They change every frame.

For this example we only define the 5 basic combinations, but keep in mind that you can do as many as you need, for example rgb(100, 215, 180) .

It is time to move on to the next lesson where we will see the hexadecimal colors, see you there.

hex colors

Hexadecimal colors are very similar to RGB in the sense that both allow us to choose a more personalized color palette, the difference lies in their writing and the number of combinations that we can achieve.

Its hexadecimal name means that we can have values between 0 and f ( f is equal to 16 in hexadecimal system)

Let's do it

We are going to replicate the example of the squares seen in the previous lesson, only this time we will use hexadecimal values.

  1. As usual, click on the run button to see the progress so far.

  2. Replace the comment that says /* square color 1 */ in the CSS editor with the following:

 #c-1 { background-color: #ffffff; }

Note that the correct way to define a color in hexadecimal is by using the hash symbol ( # ), followed by a combination of values that come in pairs, that is, if we separate the previous example it would look like this #ff_ff_ff, like RGB colors, the first pair represents the color red, the second the green and finally the blue.

  1. Click once more on the run button, the first square should change to a white color just what we need.

Now let's change the color of the other squares.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* color of the following squares */ with the following:

 #c-2 { background-color: #000000; color: #ffffff; } #c-3 { background-color: #ff0000; } #c-4 { background-color: #00ff00; } #c-5 { background-color: #0000ff; }

  1. Now click the submit button to check your results.

As you can see, the use of colors in hexadecimal is very similar to RGB, at least in terms of functionality, since with both we can achieve similar results.

Congratulations for having come this far, in the next lesson we will study the types of size that we can apply, be it to the letter, containers, etc.

absolute sizes

There are two ways to size things in CSS, one is by using relative values and the other, which we'll see next, is by using absolute values.

Absolute values are simply the ones that always remain stable no matter what screen size it is displayed on, for example, 50 pixels will be *the same on a computer or on a cell phone.

Let's see some of the absolute measures that we can use, for this we create some squares in order to visualize it better.

the pixel

It is perhaps the smallest unit of measurement and, in terms of absolute trafficking sizes, it is undoubtedly the most widely used.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Measure in pixels here */ with the following:

 #pixeles { height: 75px; width: 75px; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see, the way to use measurement units is through the value you want it to have, generally it is a number, and the measurement identifier, in this case the letters px to represent pixels.

  1. Go back to the CSS editor and copy the following by changing the /* Measurement in centimeters comment here */:

 #centimetros { height: 2cm; /* cm es la representación de los centímetros */ width: 2cm; }

Finally we will use millimeters.

  1. Now replace the last comment that says /* Measurement in millimeters here */ with:

 #milimetros { height: 20mm; /* mm is the representation of millimeters */ width: 20mm; }

  1. Finally click the submit button to check your result.

    Remember that the absolute units will always have the same value no matter what device they are on, so when we implement responsive design it is better not to use them much, since for this we have the relative units that will be the subject of our next lesson.

relative sizes

Relative sizes, as their name indicates, are those that react depending on the size of the screen on which it is displayed.

There are several types of relative sizes that we recommend you investigate, for now we will focus on 3 of the most common.

rem: It is relative to the font size of the root, generally the font of the root is 16px , unless we change it manually, so if we specify 3rem the size in pixels will be 48px.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* rem unit here */ in the CSS editor with the following:

 #rem { height: 5rem; width: 5rem; }

  1. Click the run button.

em: It is relative to the font size of the container, for example if the container has a font size of 25px and we specify 2em , this means that the total size will be 50px.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* unit em here */ in the CSS editor with the following:

 #em { height: 5em; width: 5em; }

  1. Click the run button.

Note: Although the rem and em units are relative to the font size, this does not mean they always have the same size since CSS is responsible for calculating a relative value depending on the size of the screen.

Percentages: The percentage is relative to the size of the screen, for example, if we want some container to occupy half of it, then we should put 50%.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* percentage here */ in the CSS editor with the following:

 #porcentajes { height: 26%; width: 31%; position: absolute; }

  1. Click the submit button and check your result.

Very well you have completed this session of the CSS course where you learned about colors and sizes in addition to their uses. Don't forget to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✔ "check" button in the top right corner of your screen.

Combination of selectors and Pseudo-classes

Welcome to this CSS course lesson where you will learn about advanced selectors and pseudo classes both in concept and in practice.

Combination of selectors

Without a doubt, there is a great variety of possibilities to select an element in the HTML document and thus be able to add styles with CSS, this time we will focus on those selectors that can be a little more complex but also provide us with a great advantage over the selectors. traditional by allowing us greater precision and scalability.

Space

When we use a space between two selectors, for example ( div p ) we are telling CSS that we want it to select all <p> tags that are inside a <div> tag.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Write your code here */ with the following:

 div p { background-color: #444444; color: #f1f1f1; }

  1. Click the run code button.

As you can see the first two paragraphs of the content have a dark gray background color and their font color is white, unlike the last two that do not have any styles applied.

If you look at the HTML editor you will notice something like this:

 <div> <p>Primer párrafo<p> <p>Segundo párrafo<p> </div> <section> <p>Tercer párrafo<p> <p>Cuarto párrafooo<p> </section>

As you can see the two <p> tags inside the <div> container are the ones that received the styles, the rest were ignored.

  1. Click the submit button so you can check your results.

Very well you have completed this lesson see you in the next one.

Multiple choice

Multiple selection allows us to give general styles to the selected parts, for this we use the comma ( , ) as a separator. Take a look at the following example:

 selector1, selector2 { font-size: 3rem; }

What the above code snippet does is apply the same styles to both selector1 and selector2.

Let's do it

Let's see how we can apply the above in CSS code.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Common styles here */ with:

 #titulo, .parrafo { font-family: sans-serif; text-decoration: underline; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see we have applied the same font to both the title and the paragraph, this is achieved by using the comma to separate those selectors that we want.

Now we are going to apply different styles to each selector.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* Individual styles here */ with the following:

 #titulo { color: blue; } .parrafo { color: dark; }

  1. Finally click the submit button to check your results.

Notice that the individual styles appear just as we needed them to, ie the title is blue and the paragraph is black.

You're doing great, don't slow down and keep going.

pseudo-classes

The pseudo-classes are nothing more than properties that come by default with the CSS language, they allow us to perform many tasks such as animations and specific selections, among others.

All pseudo-classes start with a colon ( : ) followed by their name.

Pseudo-class :hover

This pseudo-class is activated every time the mouse passes over the element to which it was applied, for example, if we have a paragraph which we want to change color every time the mouse hovers over it, then we apply the following:

 p:hover { color: green; }

Let's do it

We are going to apply the same previous example but this time on a larger scale so that it is clearer for you.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Write your code here */ with the following:

 #p-1:hover { color: blue; } #p-2:hover { color: green; } #p-3:hover { color: purple; }

Note that the correct way to use pseudo-classes is very simple, we simply use this syntax: selector:pseudo-clase .

  1. Click the run button.

  2. Pass your mouse over each of the paragraphs, you can see how they change color.

The :hover pseudo-class It is widely used when making basic animations like the one in the previous example, you may have seen it very often on web pages, for example in buttons that change state, etc.

  1. Click the submit button and check your results.



You're doing well, keep it up, in the next lesson we'll be looking at another widely used pseudo-class such as :focus, see you there.

Pseudo-class :focus

This pseudo-class is activated every time an element is focused, for example an input field, if we stop on it to be able to write, it would be at that moment that the pseudo class :focus is activated.

As it is always better to see it with examples, let's get to it.

Let's do it

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* First :focus here */ with the following:

 #primer-input:focus { background-color: rgb(50, 50, 50); color: #ffffff; }

  1. Click the run button.

  2. Click on the field you just generated.

You will see that when you click on the field, the background color changes to a dark gray and the font turns white.

  1. Now replace the comment that says /* Second :focus here */ with this:

 #segundo-input:focus { background-color: rgb(0, 217, 255); color: #222222; }

  1. Again click on the run button.

If you do the exercise of hovering over the second input field again, you'll see its color change to light blue.

You almost have it, let's continue with the next lesson where you will learn about another of the most used pseudo-classes, we are talking about :active , see you there.

Pseudo-class :active

This pseudo-class is activated every time we click on an element, for example, when we click on a button we can make it change its color, or any other property, momentarily.

Continuing with the form example in the previous lesson, we've modified it a bit to be a typical login form (you can see it in the HTML editor).

Let's do it

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* General button styles here */ with the following:

 #boton-login { margin: 3px; background-color: green; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see now the button has a green color, now let's see how to make it white when we click it.

  1. Now replace the comment that says /* Pseudo-calse styles :active here */ with this:

 #boton-login:active { background-color: white; color: green; }

  1. Again click on the run button.

For now the button doesn't seem to have changed, but if you click on it you will see its background color change to white.

Very well you have completed this session of the CSS course where you learned about the combination of selectors and pseudo-classes in addition to their uses, if you want to continue delving into these topics click here .

flex box

Welcome to this tutorial where you will learn flexbox, which is a relatively recent way of working with items and containers, making its use much easier and more sustainable.

Basically the flexbox property is applied to a parent container, from that container we will be able to specify the alignment of the elements inside, the size of the elements they contain and distribute the remaining space between the elements of the Flex container, and everything this in a single direction, either a horizontal or vertical.

How to apply flexbox

Applying flexbox is quite simple, all we have to do is enter the display property and assign it the value of flex , let's move on to the code so you can understand it better.

Remember to take a look at the HTML editor since the styles are applied to its tags, don't forget it.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Flex container here */ with:

 .contenedor-flex { display: flex; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can all the content within the <section> tag appears in a row, this is what flexbox does, that is, it takes care that each child item, in this each <article>, occupies only the space it needs.

Now let's add a little more styling to the items to make it look better.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* General item styles */ with the following:

 article { border: 1px solid black; height: 80px; width: 80px; }

  1. Again click run.

They look a little better now, but we can add a bit of color to them.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* Background color of items */ with:

 #a-1 { background-color: #36f599; } #a-2 { background-color: #648bf5; } #a-3 { background-color: #f207db; }

  1. Finally click the submit button to check your results.

Very well, now you know how easy it is to use flexbox, it's time to continue advancing and seeing the properties it has, see you in the next lesson.

Flexbox or flex-direction axes

When we work with flexbox we must get used to having to work on two axes, the vertical and the horizontal. There will always be a main axis which by default is horizontal but we can modify it as we will see below.

In the HTML editor you will see that there are 4 containers, all with the same content, in this way you can better visualize how the axes work.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Flex row here */ with this:

 #contenedor-1 { display: flex; flex-direction: row; }

When we enter the flex-direction property and its value is row we are referring to the default value that flexbox has, this means that if you run the program at this time you will not see anything very different from the last lesson.

  1. Let's make it display as a column, to do this replace the comment that says /* Flex column here */ with:

 #contenedor-2 { display: flex; flex-direction: column; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see we have changed the main axis, now this is the vertical one.

  1. Now click the submit button to check your results.

You do very well, do not give up and continue learning, see you in the next lesson.

Flexbox axes or flex-direction #2

In the previous lesson we saw how to work with the axes in a conventional way, but with flexbox we can also change the direction in which the items are displayed, more correctly, we can place them in reverse, let's see how.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* Flex row-reverse here */ with:

 #contenedor-1 { display: flex; flex-direction: row-reverse; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see now the items appear the other way around, that is, they are located on the right and their order is now 3, 2, 1.

We can also make the columns locate in reverse.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* Flex column reverse here */ with the following:

 #contenedor-2 { display: flex; flex-direction: column-reverse; }

  1. Again click on the run button.

Notice that now the order of the numbers inside the last blue squares is descending (3, 2, 1).

5. Click the submit button and check your results.

There you go, it's time to move on to see how we can work with multi lines in flexbox, see you in the next lesson.

multiline

When we are styling our HTML documents it is very common that we need to split our content into multiple lines, otherwise we would have a display problem that would affect users.

For example, on mobile devices it is very important to have a good layout, since space is more limited.

flex-wrap

Let's move on to see how we can generate multi-line content with flexbox.

  1. Go to the CSS editor and replace the comment that says /* Flex nowrap here */ with the following:

 #contenedor-1 { display: flex; flex-wrap: nowrap; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see all the items were displayed in a row, nothing strange since we are working with flexbox, the problem is that the content disappears on the right side, this is because when we assign the flex-wrap property the value of nowrap the content does not split when exceeding screen width.

Now let's see how to use multiline, or what is the same, that the content is automatically divided depending on the width of the screen.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* Flex wrap here */ with:

 #contenedor-2 { display: flex; flex-wrap: wrap; }

  1. Again click on the run button.

Note that now the content is divided without exceeding the width of the space set, this, as you can imagine, is because now the value of flex-wrap is wrap , which makes it very useful when working with responsive designs.

  1. Click the submit button and check your results.

You are doing well, now that you know what flex containers are like, it is time to move on to the items, that is, the children of the immediately superior container, see you in the next lesson.

flexbox items

The items as well as the parent container also have some properties that can be used in order to improve the design of our sites, this time we will see two of the most common but if you want to learn more you can click here .

Modify the order

When a tag in the HTML document has a parent container that is flex we can change the order in which they are displayed, see the following example:

 <padre> <hijo1></hijo1> <hijo2></hijo2> </padre>

As you can see the tag “ <hijo1> ” is above the tag “ <hijo2> ”, what the order property would allow us to do is change the order of both tags, that is, “ <hijo1> ” would be below of “ <hijo2> ”.

As always, it is better to learn with practice so here we go.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* Child styles one */ with the following:

 #hijo-1 { order: 2; /* Flex-grow aquí */ }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see now the number one is located in the last position, this may seem strange to you, since the desired position was 2, what happens is that we have not specified the positions of the other CSS places it there by default.

  1. Replace the comment that says /* Child styles two and 3 */ with:

 #hijo-2 { order: 1; } #hijo-3 { order: 2; }

  1. Again click the run button.

This time all the items have the desired position.

flex-grow

This property indicates how much an item should grow with respect to its siblings, these values are relative and reactive, this means that if we resize the screen they can grow or shrink.

Let's see how to apply this property, for this we will use the first child.

  1. Locate the comment that says /* Flex-grow here */, if you don't have this comment, locate it in the first id block (#child-1) and replace it with this:

 flex-grow: 3;

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see now the square corresponding to the number one has a greater width than the others.

  1. Click the submit button and check your results.

Very well you have completed this session of the CSS course where you learned about one of the most important topics such as flexbox in addition to its uses, if you want to continue delving into these topics click here .

Don't forget to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✔ "check" button in the top right corner of your screen.

Welcome to the bootstrap interface design tutorial !

This tutorial is aimed at anyone who wants to start with web development.

Suggestions : Have finished the HTML and CSS courses of the platform, or have knowledge of these two technologies.

Let's start with the basics. What is Bootstrap?

It is a CSS framework used in front-end applications to develop applications that adapt to any device.

In Bootstrap you can use all the CSS concepts you learned earlier, only in a more abbreviated way and all the styles are written as classes.

Let's learn with some examples.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--importa bootstrap acá--> comment with the following code:

     <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.1.3/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet" integrity="sha384-1BmE4kWBq78iYhFldvKuhfTAU6auU8tT94WrHftjDbrCEXSU1oBoqyl2QvZ6jIW3" crossorigin="anonymous" />

    By adding this tag we will add the Bootstrap library to our HTML.

  • Replace the <!--añade tu etiqueta de título aquí--> comment with the following code:

    Copy code:

     <h1>Título</h1>

  • Hit the “run code” button.

  • Add the following attribute to the tag you just added:

     class="m-3 bg-dark text-light text-center"

    With these classes we add margins, a background color and align the text to the center of the block.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Replace the <!--añade tu etiqueta de texto aquí--> comment with the following code:

    Copy code:

     <p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Repellendus ut.</p>

  • Hit the “run code” button.

  • Add the following attribute to the tag you just added:

     class="h3 text-center mt-5"

    With these classes we add margins, assign a size and align the text to the center of the block.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

bootstrap margins !

Let's see how to add margins in bootstrap?

To make them you have to include in the HTML class attribute the property of m followed by the value, which is a number from 1 to 5.

Format : {propiedad}{lado}-{tamaño} real example: mt-4 py-4

This property has a few positions:

  • t - equals margin-top or padding-top

  • b - equals margin-bottom or padding-bottom

  • s - (start) is equivalent to margin-left or padding-left

  • e - (end) is equivalent to margin-right or padding-right

  • x - equals the margins of the sides.

  • y - equals the top and bottom margins.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--importa bootstrap acá--> comment with the following code:

     <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.1.3/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet" integrity="sha384-1BmE4kWBq78iYhFldvKuhfTAU6auU8tT94WrHftjDbrCEXSU1oBoqyl2QvZ6jIW3" crossorigin="anonymous" />

    By adding this tag we will add the Bootstrap library to our HTML.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tus contenedores aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="bg-dark text-light text-center">sin margen</div> <div class="bg-dark text-light text-center">margen arriba</div> <div class="mb-4 bg-dark text-light text-center">margen abajo y arriba</div> <div class="bg-dark text-light text-center">margen derecha</div> <div class="bg-dark text-light text-center">margen izquierda</div>

  • Hit the “run code” button.

  • Add the following attribute to the container with the text margen arriba :

     mt-4

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Add the following attribute on the container with the text margen arriba y abajo :

     mt-1 mb-4

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Add the following attribute on the container with the text margen derecha :

     me-4

  • Add the following attribute on the container with the text margen izquierda :

     ms-4

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

bootstrap containers !

We can create containers that adapt to the size of the screen easily with bootstrap

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--importa bootstrap acá--> comment with the following code:

     <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.1.3/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet" integrity="sha384-1BmE4kWBq78iYhFldvKuhfTAU6auU8tT94WrHftjDbrCEXSU1oBoqyl2QvZ6jIW3" crossorigin="anonymous" />

    By adding this tag we will add the Bootstrap library to our HTML.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tus contenedores aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="container-sm bg-dark text-light mt-1"> toma el 100% de la pantalla hasta los 540px</div> <div class="container-md bg-dark text-light mt-1">toma el 100% de la pantalla hasta los 720px</div> <div class="container-lg bg-dark text-light mt-1">toma el 100% de la pantalla hasta los 960px</div> <div class="container-xl bg-dark text-light mt-1">toma el 100% de la pantalla hasta los 1140px</div> <div class="container-xxl bg-dark text-light mt-1">toma el 100% de la pantalla hasta los 1320px</div>

  • Hit the “run code” button.

    As you can see we add the container class with different sizes such as container-md , with this we can generate containers that fit different screens.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Generating Buttons!

Let's see how to generate custom buttons with bootstrap.

Types of colors for the buttons :

There are several types of colors for buttons, I'm going to show you some using the bootstrap classes.

  • primary

  • secondary

  • success

  • danger

  • warning

  • info

  • light

  • dark

Let's see some examples.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--importa bootstrap acá--> comment with the following code:

     <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.1.3/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet" integrity="sha384-1BmE4kWBq78iYhFldvKuhfTAU6auU8tT94WrHftjDbrCEXSU1oBoqyl2QvZ6jIW3" crossorigin="anonymous" />

    By adding this tag we will add the Bootstrap library to our HTML.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade los botones primary y secondary aquí--> with the following code:

    Copy code:

     <button type="button" class="btn btn-primary">Primary</button> <button type="button" class="btn btn-secondary">Secondary</button>

    How you can see to create a button with bootstrap you use the btn class and to give it the color you use btn-tipo , like this example that uses btn-primary and btn-secondary

  • Hit the “run code” button.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade los botones success y danger aquí--> with the following code:

    Copy code:

     <button type="button" class="btn btn-success">Success</button> <button type="button" class="btn btn-danger">Danger</button>

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade los botones warning e info aquí--> with the following code:

    Copy code:

     <button type="button" class="btn btn-warning">Warning</button> <button type="button" class="btn btn-info">Info</button>

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade los botones light y dark aquí--> with the following code:

    Copy code:

     <button type="button" class="btn btn-light">Light</button> <button type="button" class="btn btn-dark">Dark</button>

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Button sets!

With the btn-group class we can create a group of buttons, for example:

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the <!--importa bootstrap acá--> comment with the following code:

     <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.1.3/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet" integrity="sha384-1BmE4kWBq78iYhFldvKuhfTAU6auU8tT94WrHftjDbrCEXSU1oBoqyl2QvZ6jIW3" crossorigin="anonymous" />

    By adding this tag we will add the Bootstrap library to our HTML.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu contenedor aquí--> with the following code:

    As you can see, we are adding the btn-group class, which is able to group many buttons within that container.

  • Inside the container div you just created add the following code:

     <button type="button" class="btn btn-outline-primary active">Left</button> <button type="button" class="btn btn-outline-primary">Middle</button> <button type="button" class="btn btn-outline-primary">Right</button>

    As you can see, you are creating another type of button with the class btn-ouline-primary , which is a button with borders of the color you choose, for example the color primary .

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations, you have finished the module!

bootstrap images !

Handle addresses with flexbox in bootstrap !

Horizontally realign elements with flexbox in bootstrap !

Let's see how to align content on the x -axis in a container.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment of <!--añade tu contenedor con el contenido horizontal al inicio aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="container-sm bg-secondary d-flex flex-row justify-content-start" style="height: 30%"> <div> <p>contenido-1</p> </div> <div class="ms-1"> <p>contenido-2</p> </div> </div>

    • You can see that we're adding the justify-content-center class, which aligns the content horizontally and places it in the center of the container.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Replace the <!--añade tu contenedor con el contenido horizontal al final aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <div class="container-sm bg-warning d-flex flex-row justify-content-end" style="height: 20%"> <div> <p>contenido-1</p> </div> <div class="me-1"> <p>contenido-2</p> </div> </div>

    • You can see that we're adding the justify-content-end class, which aligns the content horizontally and places it at the end of the container.

     <div class="container-sm bg-dark text-light d-flex flex-row justify-content-between" style="height: 30%"> <div> <p>contenido-1</p> </div> <div > <p>contenido-2</p> </div> </div>

    • You can see that we are adding the justify-content-between class, which aligns the content horizontally and places it with spaces between each other inside the container.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

Change alignment vertically to elements with flexbox in bootstrap !

Let's see how to align content on the y axis in a container.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu contenedor con el contenido vertical al inicio aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="container-sm bg-secondary d-flex flex-row justify-content-start align-items-start" style="height: 30%"> <div> <p>contenido-1</p> </div> <div class="ms-1"> <p>contenido-2</p> </div> </div>

    • You can see that we are adding the class align-items-start , which aligns the content vertically and places it at the beginning of the container.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu contenedor con el contenido vertical en el centro aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="container-sm bg-danger d-flex flex-row justify-content-center align-items-center" style="height: 40%"> <div> <p>contenido-1</p> </div> <div class="ms-2"> <p>contenido-2</p> </div> </div>

    • You can see that we are adding the class align-items-center , which aligns the content vertically and places it in the center of the container.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Replace the <!--añade tu contenedor con el contenido vertical al final aquí--> comment with the following code:

     <div class="container-sm bg-dark text-light d-flex flex-row justify-content-between align-items-end" style="height: 30%"> <div> <p>contenido-1</p> </div> <div> <p>contenido-2</p> </div> </div>

    • You can see that we are adding the align-items-end class, which aligns the content vertically and places it at the end of the container.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Rows and columns with Grid in bootstrap !

Grid is a system of rows and columns, it is used to create more responsive applications (that adapt to any type of screen)

Let's see a little more.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu primera fila aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="row mb-1 mt-1 " style="height: 30vh"> <div class="col bg-danger"> Column </div> <div class="col bg-dark text-light"> Column </div> </div>

    You can see what we are adding the class

    • row : Generates a row inside the container.

    • col Generates a column within the row.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes.

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu segunda fila aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="row" style="height: 30vh"> <div class="col bg-danger" > Column </div> <div class="col bg-dark text-light"> Column </div> <div class="col bg-primary"> Column </div> </div>

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu tercera fila aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="row mt-1" style="height: 30vh"> <div class="col-3 bg-danger" > <p style="font-size: 12px;">Column</p> </div> <div class="col-3 bg-dark text-light"> <p style="font-size: 12px;">Column</p> </div> <div class="col-3 bg-primary"> <p style="font-size: 12px;">Column</p> </div> <div class="col-3 bg-secondary text-light"> <p style="font-size: 12px;">Column</p> </div> </div>

    • Note that you can modify the field of your container to add more content, in this example so that 4 containers fit on our screen we assign 4 columns of 3, we are dividing 12 spaces by 4.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes .

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Let's continue to see a little more about Grid!

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  • Replace the comment for <!--añade tu fila aquí--> with the following code:

     <div class="row row-cols-3 h-50 bg-light m-1"> <div class="col">Column</div> <div class="col">Column</div> <div class="col">Column</div> <div class="col">Column</div> <div class="col">Column</div> <div class="col">Column</div> </div>

    You can see that we add the class row-cols-3 , which helps us to generate a row with 3 columns on each side.

  • Hit the “run code” button and observe the changes.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!
