Welcome to the JavaScript tutorial for web development!

The goal of this tutorial is to give you the basics of JavaScript for web development.

Suggestions: Know the main technologies for Front-End development (HTML, CSS, JS).

Let's understand what getElementById is: It is a method with which we can access an element through its id.

For example:

  • Look at this structure:

 <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8"> <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"> <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"> <title>Document</title> </head> <body> <h1 id="title">hola mundo</h1> </body> </html>

As you can see, the h1 element inside the body has an id="title" .

We can access such an element using getElementById as follows:

  • Add the following code in the JavaScript editor:

     document.getElementById('title').style.color = 'red'

    With this we access the h1 element and change its color to red

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

How to access a text of a tag in HTML and print it in the console?

Just as one can modify the UI from JS, one can also access text from the HTML and print it to the console. At PeakU we have implemented a console which you can access in the lower left corner of the Your Result window.

To print values in this console we do the following:

  1. Add the JS code, in the JavaScript tab:

     let titulo = document.getElementById('title'); let texto = titulo.innerText; console.log(texto);

    This code takes the title from the HTML , looks it up by ID in the document and declares a variable titulo . Once you have it, declare a second variable ( texto ) with the text of the tag, use the innerText property. Finally prints the text in console.

  2. Run the code.

  3. Go to the console tab in the Your result window. You should see the text "hello world" printed on the console.

What is getElementsByClassName?

It is a method with which we can access the elements that contain the same class, the difference to the previous method is that it returns an object similar to an array of the elements that said class contains.

For example:

  • Look at this structure:

 <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8"> <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"> <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"> <title>Document</title> </head> <body> <h1 id="title">hola mundo</h1> <h2 class="sub-title">hola mundo otra vez</h2> </body> </html>

As you can see, the h2 element inside the body has a class="sub-title" .

We can access such an element using getElementByClassName as follows:

  • Add the following code in the JavaScript editor:

     let resultado = document.getElementsByClassName('sub-title')

    With this we access the h2 element with the sub-title class and it will return a group of elements with that class, in our case it would only be an h2.

  • Now add the following code:

     let subtitle = resultado[0]

    With this line of code you will access the first element of that response, in your case the [0] would be the h2 element.

  • Now add the following code:

     subtitle.style.fontSize = "40px"

    This part modifies the font size of the text.

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

What is getElementsByTagName?

It is a method with which we can access the elements that contain the same HTML tag. This is similar to the previous method because it returns an object similar to an array of the elements that contain said HTML tag.

For example:

  • Look at this structure and add it in the HTML editor:

 <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8"> <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"> <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"> <title>Document</title> </head> <body> <h1 id="title">hola mundo</h1> <h2 class="sub-title">hola mundo otra vez</h2> <ul> <li>item-1</li> <li>item-2</li> <li>item-3</li> </ul> <button id="change-lists" onclick="changeListDom()">change DOM</button> </body> </html>

  • Hit the “run code” button at the top, and watch the changes.

We are going to access the list elements and change their values using getElementByTagName as follows:

  • Add the following code in the JavaScript editor:

     const changeListDom = () => { let allContentList = document.getElementsByTagName('li') allContentList[0].style.fontSize = "26px" allContentList[1].style.background = "red" allContentList[2].style.color = "blue" }

    This function accesses all the <li> elements in our document, and changes the values of each list.

    • For list-1 it changes the font size.

    • For list-2 it changes the background color.

    • For list-3 it changes the color of the text.

  • Hit the “run bot” button at the top, and watch the changes.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

What is the DOM?

Explanation : The DOM is a tree-like structure as you see in this example:

 nodo-padre hijo-1 hijo-2 nieto-3 nieto-4 nieto-5 nieto-6

Example in a real document:

 html header body div div div div

Concept: For its acronym in English DOM ("Document Object Model"), is the way how we can access the HTML document of our website from JS.

How can we see the HTML structure?

We're going to access that structure by printing document .

  • Go to the JavaScript editor and add the following code:

     console.log(document)

  • Open Developer Console: Right click on these instructions and select "inspect".

  • Open console tab: In the upper right part of the console, next to the item elements, you are going to select the console item, in case the item console does not appear, you are going to select the item ">>" and select console .

  • Clean console: Click on the button indicated in the image below.

Now as the last step

  1. Press the “execute code” button at the top, and see the entire HTML structure of your project in the console .

  2. Close the developer console.

  3. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Important data types for handling the dom!

Next we will see some types of data that will help us to manage the content of elements of our document.

  • document: It is the entire html document of the application.

  • element: Refers to an element or an element type node of the document, such as an <h1> tag or an unordered list, this data type has some very important methods that are:

    • element.innerHTML : Returns the HTML syntax of the element and everything inside the element.

    • element.innerText : Returns the text content of the element.

      Note : These methods are modifiable.

  • Look at this structure and add it in the HTML editor:

 <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8"> <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"> <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"> <title>Document</title> </head> <body> <h1 id="title">hola mundo</h1> <h2 class="sub-title">hola mundo otra vez</h2> <ul> <li>lista-1</li> <li>lista-2</li> <li>lista-3</li> </ul> <button id="change-lists" onclick="changeListDom()">change DOM</button> </body> </html>

  • Hit the “run code” button at the top, and watch the changes.

We are going to access the list elements and change their values using getElementByTagName as follows:

  • Add the following code in the JavaScript editor:

     var changeListDom = () => { let mainTitle = document.getElementById('title'); mainTitle.innerHTML = '<p>ahora es un parrafo</p>' let allContentList = document.getElementsByTagName('li'); allContentList[0].innerText = 'cambiamos el texto' console.log(mainTitle) }

    This function accesses all the <h1> and <li> elements in our document, and changes the values.

    • For the <h1> element it changes the text and adds a <p> element to it.

    • For list-1 it changes the text.

  • Open Developer Console: Right click on these instructions and select "inspect".

  • Open console tab: In the upper right part of the console, next to the item elements, you are going to select the console item, in case the item console does not appear, you are going to select the item ">>" and select console .

  • Clean console: Click on the button indicated in the image below.

Now as the last step

  • Hit the “run bot” button at the top, and watch the console add the <p> element to it inside the h1.

  • Close the developer console.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations, you have completed the course!

getElementById.

Do the exercise with QuerySelector

What is an API?

API(Application Programming Interface).

But what is it?

Let's use the analogy of a restaurant, you go to your favorite restaurant and the waiter attends to you, and you ask the waiter for your favorite food from that place, the waiter gives your message to the chef and once the chef finishes cooking your favorite food the waiter brings it to the table.

With this analogy, the waiter would be the API where it takes the data from the client, sends it to the server, and once the server has what the client requested, the API returns the information to the client.

So the API is the intermediary between the server and the client.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  1. Replace the comment in <!--Añade tu código acá--> with the following code.

     <button id="button-get-data" href="#" class="btn btn-primary w-50" onclick="getPerson()">Show</button>

  2. Hit the "Run Code" button at the top of the screen and watch it get the data.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

HTTP request methods

Also called HTTP verbs, they are methods used to indicate the action that you want to perform when calling an API.

The main methods are:

  • GET: It is a request that is used to get/retrieve data in an API.

  • POST: It is a request that is used to send data to an API.

  • PUT: It is a request that is used to send data to be completely replaced, in short, some data is sent and completely replaces the old data of a resource with the new ones that were sent.

  • DELETE: It is a request that deletes a specific resource.

  • PATCH: It is a request that is used to update specific elements unlike PUT, what this method does is that if we have a person object and we want to update only the name of the person, we will use PATCH, while if we want to update all the data of that person object, we will use is PUT.

Let's see a bit about this in code.

Add the following instructions in the HTML editor :

  1. Replace the //Añade tu código acá comment with the following code.

     method: 'GET',

    As you can see, we are adding a GET request to get data from that API.

  2. Hit the "Run Code" button at the top of the screen and watch it get the data.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Working with JSON

JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is a text-based format whose similarity resembles JavaScript object syntax. It is commonly used to transmit data in web applications (for example: send some data from the server to the client, so this data can be displayed on web pages, or vice versa).

What does a JSON response look like?

 [ { "name": "pepito", "city": "Bogotá", "university": "Universidad De los Andes", "company": "peaku" } ]

Let's see how to manipulate those json

Add the following instructions in the JavaScript editor :

  1. Replace the //Añade tu código acá comment with the following code.

     const myJson = `[ { "name": "pepito", "city": "Bogotá", "university": "Universidad De los Andes", "company": "peaku" } ]`

    We are adding a json as if it came from an API response.

  2. Click the "Run Code" button at the top of the screen.

  3. Hit the "Run Bot" button at the top of the screen and watch it get the data.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Using Fetch

It is an interface that JavaScript provides to make requests to an API.

How is it used?

 fetch(url, { Acá van los metodos HTTP, y headers }) .then(response => response.json()) .then(data => console.log(data)); .catch(error => console.error(error));

fetch receives a url and an object({}) where the metodos HTTP and headers would go (we will see what it is later), this gets a response, we convert that response to json and then we get a data that can be manipulated or visualized, those responses are called promises which would be both .then .

GET method with fetch

We are going to use the GET method with fetch for this: Add the following instructions in the JavaScript editor .

  1. Replace the //Añade tu url acá comment with the following code.

     let url = 'https://rickandmortyapi.com/api/character/2';

    We create our url

  2. Replace the //Añade tu código acá comment with the following code.

     fetch(url, { method: 'GET', headers:{ 'Content-Type': 'application/json' } }) //añade tus promesas aquí

    With this we are making a GET request to said url to obtain the data of that API.

  3. Replace the //Añade tus promesas aquí comment with the following code.

     .then(response => response.json()) .then(data => { let card = document.getElementById('main-content') card.innerHTML = ` <div class="card d-flex justify-content-center align-items-center" style="width: 70%;"> <img src="${data.image}" class="card-img-top mt-1 p-0" alt="..." style="width: 70%; height: 40%;"> <div class="card-body d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center"> <h5 class="card-title">${data.name}</h5> <p class="card-text">${data.species}</p> </div> </div> ` }) .catch(error => console.error('Error:', error));

    We add the .then to manipulate the response of said API and be able to visualize it.

  4. Click the "Run Code" button at the top of the screen.

  5. Hit the "Run Bot" button at the top of the screen and watch it get the data.

Congratulations advance to the next module!

Manipulating a JSON.

Create a JS function for the "show" button that will manipulate your JSON and display the values of that JSON like in the "expected result" example

call that function in an onCLick event

JSON:

 const myJson = `[ { "name": "Juan", "city": "Bogotá", "university": "Universidad De los Andes", "company": "peaku" } ]`

JavaScript for Beginners

We welcome you to our JavaScript tutorial in this and the following modules we will teach you the most important things you need to know about this magnificent language standardized for front-end development but versatile enough to be used in almost any project you have in mind .

In the area below you will find a live code editor where you will have the opportunity to test your skills. As you progress and execute the proposed exercises, one or more test cases will be shown with which you will be able to see how you are doing. ; without further ado let's start with the tutorial.

In the text editor you will see something like this.

 function holaMundo() { // Escribe tu código aquí }

This is known as functions, but don't worry for now if you don't understand what it is, as we will explain them in more advanced courses.

variables

JavaScript allows us to store any type of data by defining variables, we will see the data types in the next lesson, for example if we want the program to save our name then we declare a variable in the following way:

 nombre = "John"

On the left side of the equal sign is the name of the variable, which in this case is "name" , and on the right side is the value, which in this case is "John".

 let nombre = "John"

By typing the word “ let ” we are telling JavaScript that we want to define the variable in a local environment. There are 3 ways to define variables:

var: Used to define variables that can be used in many places.

let: It is used to define variables that are used in a certain place.

const: Stores a value that will not change in the future.

Cool! There you go, now let's move on to creating our first “Hello World!” in JavaScript for this go to the editor replace the content with this.

 function holaMundo() { let saludo = "¡Hola mundo!"; return saludo; }

As you can see we have defined a new variable called saludo to which we store the value of “Hello world!” Finally, with the code " return saludo; " we return the value of said variable. Note that each line ends with a semicolon ( ; ). This is not strictly necessary in JavaScript but it is a very widespread and accepted practice, partly because its use is mandatory for other languages.

Now just click on the “execute” button and you will be able to see how you did it, if you got a good result, a green color will appear in the final part of the exercise and you will be able to compare the expected result with your result.

congratulations you have completed your first lesson, keep up the pace!

Reference Error: ReferenceError

A very common error that usually occurs when working with variables is ReferenceError, this occurs when we try to refer to a variable that is not defined in the code.

Let's see how to identify an error, for this we write again a "Hello world" in the editor:

  1. Define the greeting variable with the text "Hello world!"

 let saludo = "¡Hola mundo!";

  1. returns a variable that you have not defined, for example, hello .

 return hola;

  1. Click on the execute button.

If you go to the test cases you will see that these are in red, also, in the section that says "your result:" the following lines are shown:

 Error: hola is not defined Tipo de error: ReferenceError Lugar: Error en la línea número 3 (" return hola;")

This, as we have already explained, occurs when we try to refer to a variable that is not defined, in this case we are referring to the variable hello , which as you can see was not created before, that is, there is no line like this :

 let hola = "hola";

How to fix the error?

Although this error is very simple, it is also very common, occurring even to very experienced programmers; now, correcting the error is quite simple, all we have to do is return the variable that is defined.

  1. Change the variable that will be returned.

 return saludo;

  1. Again click run

Now if you can see that the test cases are green and the error no longer appears, this means that we have been able to solve it.

Congratulations now you are ready to deal with these types of errors, keep up that pace and let's continue with the next lesson.

Type of data

Now that we know what variables are, let's move on to knowing what types of data we can store in them.

JavaScript supports a wide number of data types, these are the main ones that we can find in this language:

String: Represents a text.

Number: Represents a number in any range of values.

Boolean: Represents a true or false value, that is, true or false .

null: Represents the absence of a data.

Array: List of data that can be iterated (iterated) is formed with ( [...] ).

Object: Stores a group of data like the previous ones, it is formed with square brackets ( {...} ).

Let's put it to the test, within the tiposDeDatos() function, we are going to define the following variables with their respective values.

 function tiposDeDatos() { let saludo = "¡Hola mundo!"; // tipo de dato String let siete = 7; // tipo de dato Number let auto = { color: "azul", marca: "mitsubishi" }; // tipo de dato Object let tareas = ["Cepillar mís dientes", "Hacer mís tareas"] // tipo de dato Array let booleano = true; // tipo de dato Boolean let nada = null; // tipo de dato Null return [saludo, siete, auto, tareas, booleano, nada]; }

Can you identify what type each of them is?

In the penultimate line we return the values. Notice that the return also has a data type, can you identify what it is?

Copy the content of the above code into the editor.

test your code and see you in the next lesson.

Note: The text that appears in blue to the right of // is a comment and does not affect the code.

Mathematical operators

Mathematical operators, as their name suggests, allow us to operate with numbers to obtain an expected result, as with data types, there are several, some more advanced than others, in this case we focus on the 5 main ones, which are:

  • The sum represented with the sign +

  • Subtraction represented by the sign -

  • The multiplication represented with the sign *

  • The division represented with the sign /

  • Module represented with the % sign; the modulus is the remainder of the division

Let's see how we can use them in JavaScript, to do this declare 5 variables and add the following example values.

 let suma = 14 + 5; // 19 let resta = 10 - 3; // 7 let multiplicacion = 6 * 7; // 42 let division = 45 / 3; // 15 let modulo = 5 % 5; // 0 return [suma, resta, multiplicacion, division, modulo];

Replace the comment on line 2 with the code above and execute.

Keep up the pace!

Concatenation in JavaScript

Concatenation is a basic but powerful topic that can be used for various purposes, one of which is joining values to give more detailed information about something.

The + operator is what we use if we want to perform a concatenation between Strings.

Well let's put it to the test, go to the code editor, to the concatenacion() function and declare a variable to which we assign the string "JavaScript" like this.

 let lenguaje = 'JavaScript';

Now declare a new variable in which you are going to concatenate the value in language with more information as follows.

 let saludo = 'Hola soy ' + lenguaje + " tu mejor amigo por siempre";

Note that we have used double quotes “...” and single quotes '...' both representations of a string are valid in this language.

Finally return your result like this.

 return saludo;

JavaScript exercise

The best way to learn is by practicing, for this we are going to do a small exercise with the skills you have developed so far.

We are going to calculate the area of a square whose sides are 6x and return an answer like the following 36

Try to do it first and put yourself to the test, if you don't succeed don't worry, come back and we'll find the solution together.

You already have it? This is the solution to the problem:

 function ejercicio() { let lado = 6; let area = lado * lado; return area; }

Perfect, you have finished this first JavaScript course, we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other levels, good luck :)

Mathematical Operators

Welcome to this beginner level JavaScript challenge here you will have the opportunity to test yourself and demonstrate your knowledge.

How to proceed?

  1. In the editor on the right you will find a code snippet like the following

 function operadoresMatematicos(numero1, numero2) { // Escribe tu código aquí }

  1. As you can see the MathOperators operadoresMatematicos() function receives two parameters, these are numero2 numero1 represent the test cases that will be applied to your solution.

Statement: apply the 4 basic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication and division) to each test case and return a list with the following order:

 [suma, resta, multiplicación y división]

Tip: store each result in a different variable.

Examples:

  1. Given the case that the numbers sent as test cases are 10 and 5, the program must return [15, 5, 50, 2]

  2. Given the case that the numbers sent as test cases are 8 and 4, the program must return [12, 4, 32, 2]

  3. Given the case that the numbers sent as test cases are 20 and 2, the program must return [22, 18, 40, 10]

Get to work and good luck ;-)

variables

How to proceed?

}

Tip: store the result in a variable and return that variable, see the

Type of data

Welcome to this beginner level JavaScript challenge here you will have the opportunity to test yourself and demonstrate your knowledge.

How to proceed?

     function tiposDeDatos() {
 // Escribe tu código aquí
}

Statement: Create two variables that return the following values.

  1. The first variable will have the name of miObjeto and should return the object {"clave": "valor"} .

  2. The second variable will have the name of miArray and should return the array [1, 2, 3] .

Tip: see the

Print to console with console.log()

Welcome to our basic JavaScript tutorial, in this and the next course ( basic JavaScript part 2 ) you will learn how programming languages make comparisons and make decisions logically, but before starting let's see how to use impressions in the console something that will undoubtedly be very useful both in this course and in the following ones and in the workplace.

Console output ( console.log )

Screen printing is one of the superpowers that we software developers enjoy, since it allows us to preview a value such as a number, a string, and so on, all this without the end user noticing what is happening inside of our code.

We can use console.log as many times as we need in the same program, so let's see what its use is with an example, to do this type the following in the editor:

 let animal = "perro"; console.log(animal);

In the lower area, display the test cases and you will be able to see a section with the name of “Console output” it is there where you will have the opportunity to see how the console.log works graphically.

Note that we have defined a variable called animal which stores the value of "dog", so far nothing new, let's go to the next instruction console.log(animal) what we did was pass our variable inside the parentheses of the instruction This way we tell JavaScript something like this "JavaScript friend, I want you to show me the value that is stored in the animal variable please", once JavaScript listens to your request it starts to fulfill what you asked for, it's amazing :)

As we said the console.log() statement is not only useful with a type, for example it can be used with numbers, arrays or almost any other, you can check this if you write and execute the following lines of code.

 let numero = 12; let numeros = [1, 2, 3, 4 ,5]; console.log(numero); console.log(numeros);

Return the list of numbers and check your results.

 return numeros;

Perfect, now that you have your super power you can continue your learning process effectively, let's go to the next lesson.

Comparison operators

Like the people who all the time we find ourselves making decisions such as choosing what to eat today or what to wear, computer programs can also be endowed with this ability, this is achieved through the use of comparison operators, let's see what is treat.

As its name indicates, we use them to compare values, generally of the same data type, for example two numbers. The list of operators is as follows with their respective graphical representation:

  • > greater than…

  • < less than…

  • >= greater than or equal to…

  • <= less than or equal to...

  • === same as…

  • !== different than…

When performing a comparison, the program always returns a boolean value, that is, true or false ( true - false ), for example, the following expression 4 > 6 will return false since the number 4 is not greater than 6.

You can check this if you go to the editor and write the above as follows:

 console.log(4 > 6)

Press "execute" and in the lower area display the test cases, you will see a section with the name "Console output" there you can preview the result generated by an operation.

Now let's see each comparison operator in JavaScript code, to do this type the following in the editor:

 let var1 = 43 > 28; let var2 = 1 < 3; let var3 = 6 >= 4; let var4 = 10 <= 8; let var5 = 'hello' === 'Hello'; let var6 = 9.765 !== 9.8;

tip: a characteristic that many programming languages share is that they are case sensitive, so the value in var5 will be false since technically “hello” is different from “Hello”

Finally build your list or array so we can verify your code, like this.

 return [var1, var2, var3, var4, var5, var6];

Cool! Now you are ready for the conditionals, let's go to the next lesson.

Conditionals in JavaScript, if statement

Conditionals is how programming languages make decisions. Just as a person decides what to wear or where to go, this also applies to programming and can be achieved through instructions that we encode so that, in this case, JavaScript interprets it.

There are three instructions which we will see throughout this tutorial starting with the if

if: It is the first level of the conditionals and in turn the most important since it represents the initial structure; the way in which this condition or statement works is through comparisons for example if a child is under 14 years old then he can go to the birthday party let's see how we can program this in JavaScript, to do this go to the code editor and write the following inside the condicionales() function

 let edadMichael = 11 if(edadMichael < 14) { return "Michael puede ir a la fiesta" }

If we could read the above code verbatim, it would say something like: if Michael is under 14 years old then he can go to the party, note that the variable let michaelAge is equal to 11, that value is the one that will be read in the expression inside the parentheses of the conditional ie ( edadmMichael < 14 ) is equal to ( 11 < 14 ).

Run your code and check your results.

See you in the next lesson.

Conditionals in JavaScript, else statement

The else statement will be executed whenever the previous condition or conditions are not met, for example:

 if ("you" ===  "me") { console.log("We are the same person") }else { console.log("We are not the same") }

In this case, since the condition in the if is not true, what is inside the else statement will be executed. If you want you can copy the previous code and check what happens.

In the birthday party exercise on the previous page we said that Michael could go to the birthday party if he was under 14, what if Michael was 17?

Let's modify our code a bit. To do this, write the following in the editor:

 let edadMichael = 17; if(edadMichael < 14) { return "Michael puede ir a la fiesta"; }

We already know that the condition will not be met. How would you modify this exercise so that it returns an answer like the following “Michael cannot go to the party”? try it yourself, remember to use the else statement.

If you tried it, your answer might be similar to the following:

 let edadMichael = 17; if(edadMichael < 14) { return "Michael puede ir a la fiesta"; }else { return "Michael no puede ir a la fiesta"; }

Run your code and go to the next lesson, Congratulations, you're doing great!

Conditionals in JavaScript, else if statement

During the previous two lessons we have seen the use of conditionals in their simplest forms, but what if we have more than one condition to check? in that case we can use the else if statement, this allows us to declare new conditions to evaluate, let's see it with an example.

Imagine that you want to buy an ice cream and there are 3 stores where you could do it, you go to the first one and you don't find the product so you go to the next one, when you arrive you realize that there isn't either then you go to the third where you do find the product available. If you realize we have made three decisions to be able to buy the ice cream, which have been to change the store in case the product does not exist, it is time to represent this example in JavaScript code. To do this, go to the editor and type the following:

 let hayHeladoTienda1 = false; let hayHeladoTienda2 = false; let hayHeladoTienda3 = true;

We have defined our variables, note that store 3 is the only one that has ice cream, now let's define the conditionals so that the program returns the following "there is ice cream in store number 3" to do so write the following below the variables that you just defined.

 if(hayHeladoTienda1 == true) { return "Hay helado en la tienda 1"; }else if(hayHeladoTienda2 == true) { return "Hay helado en la tienda 2"; }else if(hayHeladoTienda3 == true) { return "Hay helado en la tienda 3"; }else { return "No hay helado en ninguna parte"; }

If you run your code you should be able to see the expected result, notice that this time we have used the three conditionals ( if , else if and else ) you can imagine this as a pearl necklace where the first “if” pearl is of a different color and represents the beginning of the necklace, followed by one or more pearls of the same color “else if” and ending with a different color “else” this represents the end.

Tip: remember that if you have doubts about what the expected result is, you can preview it using console.log() as we saw in previous lessons.

Perfect, you have finished this part, let's move on to the next lesson.

JavaScript exercise

Remember that the best way to learn by practicing, for this we propose the following exercise on conditionals, here you can put everything you have learned to the test.

Statement: create a program that indicates who is the youngest person between John and Mary whose ages are the following:

John = 23 years old

Mary = 18 years old

The program should return the response like the following:

name + “ is the youngest ” example “George is the youngest” , or, if they are the same age, return “ They are the same age ”

Try to do it on your own, in case you don't succeed, don't worry, just go back to the instructions and we will find a solution.

You already have it? This is the solution to the problem:

 function ejercicio() { let john = 23; let mary = 18; if(john < mary) { return "John es el mas joven" }else if(mary < john) { return "Mary es la mas joven" }else { return "Ellos tienen la misma edad" } }

Congratulations, you have completed the basic JavaScript course part 1, we invite you to continue learning and become an expert of the language :)

Syntax error: SyntaxError

When coding it is very common that we forget some things, this generally results in syntax errors, which precisely means that we have forgotten something or written something in an incorrect way.

Let's go on to see how to identify an error, to do this let's write again the if conditional that we had in the previous lesson.

  1. Create the conditional.

 let edadMichael = 11; if edadMichael < 14 { return "Michael puede ir a la fiesta"; }

Notice that the parentheses surrounding the condition after the if they are not, this as you can imagine is a syntax error.

  1. Click on the execute button.

If you go to the test cases you will see that these are in red, in addition, in the section that says "your result:" the following lines are shown:

 Error: SyntaxError: Unexpected number Tipo de error: Runtime.UserCodeSyntaxError Lugar: Error en la línea número desconocido ("desconocido")

This type of error is sometimes quite annoying and difficult to identify since it is not clear in what form it can be presented, that is, the error we currently have is because we are missing the parentheses but we may have many more in the future that we do not are related, so we invite you to investigate more cases in which this may occur and thus be prepared.

How to fix the error

You may already have it clear or even if you are curious you have already solved the error, but in case you have doubts we will explain it to you.

  1. Since our current problem is the missing parentheses in the if conditional , let's add it, you can either replace the whole code or just copy the line you need.

 let edadMichael = 11; if (edadMichael < 14) { return "Michael puede ir a la fiesta"; }

  1. Again click the run button.

Now you can see how the test cases have a green color, this means that the problem is solved.

Perfect, now you can deal with syntax errors that your code may have, let's continue with the next lesson.

Welcome to our basic JavaScript tutorial, part 2!

On this occasion you will learn about logical operators and truth tables, we will also see what the for cycle is and how we can use it in our programs to go through lists.

Recommendation: to understand what logical operators are you must have knowledge about conditionals and comparison operators, if you don't know what they are we recommend our basic JavaScript course part 1.

truth tables

Remember that when we compare 2 or more variables with each other, the expected result will only have two possible values true or false, the truth tables and therefore the logical operators work on these values, so let's see how they do it.

There are 3 logical operators, in JavaScript its representation is as follows:

  • AND ( && ) = makes sure all expressions are true

  • OR ( || ) = makes sure that at least one expression is true

  • NOT ( ! ) = negates the result of an expression, for example if false makes it true and vice versa

Let's see how the first one works, for this we will have two possible values A and B, remember that they only have 2 possible values.

AND table ( && )

To | B | result

false | false | false

false | true | false

true | false | false

true | true | true

As you can see, the only way for the result to be true is for both A and B to be true, which is to say that if we read it verbatim it would say something like this “If, and only if, A and B are true then the result is true otherwise it's false".

Using the AND operator ( && )

So let's see how we use this in JavaScript code. For this, imagine that you want to prepare an omelette with eggs and ham, the only way to do it is that you have both ingredients to be able to prepare it, let's represent this in JavaScript, to do so type the following in the editor:

 let huevos = true; let jamon = false;

Now let's use the conditionals to know if we can prepare the tortilla in this way:

 if (huevos === true && jamon === true) { return "¡Yupí, puedo prepararlo!"; }else { return "no puedo prepararlo"; }

What do you think will be the result? Run your code and check it out.

Excellent, you already know how the AND && operator works, let's see the following, see you in the next lesson

Logical operator OR ( || )

What would happen if we only need one condition to be true regardless of the rest, for this we use the or operator || which means "this OR the other" if we represent it in a truth table it looks like this:

OR table ( || )

To | B | result

false | false | false

false | true | true

true | false | true

true | true | true

As you can see, the only way for the result to be false is if A and B are false.

Using the OR operator ( || )

Example, imagine that you want to paint your house but you don't know if there is green or blue paint so you decide to paint it in the color that is available at the moment, let's create a program that tells us if you can paint your house or not, to do this write the following in the editor:

 let azul = false; let verde = true; if(azul === true || verde === true) { return "Puedo pintar mi casa"; }else { return "No tengo pintura"; }

In this case, as if you could paint the house since there is green paint even if there is no blue.

remember you can check other results using console.log()

You're doing great, keep going.

Logical negation operator NOT ( ! )

The negation operator ( ! ) symbolizes the negation of a variable or result, for example if A is true it will become false and vice versa, its truth table is quite simple, let's see its example.

NOT table !

To | result

false | true

true | false

As you can see, the result is the opposite of A. Simple, isn't it? As always let's see this in an example using JavaScript.

Using the NOT operator ( ! )

Let's say you have a guitar that you want to play but you can't do it due to lack of time, in this case the lack of time denies you the opportunity to play your guitar, now if we go to the code for it, write the following instructions in your editor:

 let guitarra = false; if(!guitarra === true) { return "No tengo tiempo para tocar mi guitarra :("; }else { return "¡Puedo tocar mi guitarra!"; }

As you can see the NOT( ! ) operator is placed just before the expression we want to negate !guitarra in our example we can read this verbatim like this “I don't have time to play my guitar :(” .

Remember to run your code and skip to the next lesson where we'll start looking at the for loop's uses and strengths, see ya.

for loop in JavaScript

Cycles are blocks of code that are executed a certain number of times depending on a condition, this prevents us from having to rewrite lines that we have already written, and also makes us better programmers ;)

Note: There are more ways to declare a for loop in JavaScript that we recommend you check out.

The for…of cycle goes through each element in a list or array and stores it in a temporary variable that will change its value on each return, for example if we had a list of fruits with mango, pear and apple in addition to a basket where it can only be stored one fruit at a time, the first time we would have a mango, the second a pear and finally a pineapple.

Creating a for...of loop

  1. Let's see how to represent the previous example in JavaScript code. To do this, create a list like the following in the editor.

 let frutas = ["mango", "pera", "manzana"];

  1. Now let's create the for loop that loops through the list like this:

 for(let fruta of frutas) { console.log(fruta); } return frutas;

  1. If you run these you can see how each fruit is printed individually on the console.

You do amazing, now let's move on to a final little exercise :)

Use of for and if

Statement: you have a list of fruits like the following ["mango", "pera", "manzana"] your job is to iterate through it using the for…of loop and if the fruit is equal to “pear” return the following message “Found! the pear!" , we know that this can be a little more complex than the exercises proposed in previous courses, so we leave you this little hint, you must use an if conditional inside the for loop.

Without further ado, try to do the exercise yourself, if you are not able to return to the instructions and we will find a solution...

You already have it? this is the answer to the problem:

 function ejercicio() { let frutas = ["mango", "pera", "manzana"]; for(let fruta of frutas) { console.log(fruta) if(fruta === "pera") { return "¡Encontré la pera!" } } }

Congratulations you have completed the basic JavaScript course part 2, continue learning with our other courses, until next time.

Basic JavaScript Part 3, important concepts

Welcome to our basic JavaScript tutorial part 3, this time you will learn about positioning in a list, the push method and the length attribute and finally we will see in depth what code blocks or scopes are and how we can put blocks inside other blocks (nesting), without further ado, let's start the course.

Recommendation: If you don't know what arrays, conditionals, or loops are, we recommend starting with lower-level courses.

Positions in an array or list.

The positions of a list in programming, unlike the commonly used human language, start their count from the number zero, that is, if we had a race with three participants A, B and C and we want to name the positions, we normally express it as A is in first place, B in second and C in third place; but since programming languages are not human, they would express it as follows: A is at position zero, B is at position 1, and C is at position 2.

Representation in code

What do you think if we bring the previous example and represent it in JavaScript, for this we are going to give our corridors an appropriate name, what do you think Juan, Laura and Thiago, well let's move on to the code.

 let participantes = ["Juan", "Laura", "Thiago"];

Accessing each position in the array

Now that we have the participants of the race we are going to see in what position each of them is, remember that JavaScript and programming languages in general count from the number zero, therefore, what should we do if we want to access the first participant? ? Look at the following example and replicate it in the editor:

 console.log(participantes[0]);

If you notice we have taken the entire list of participants and we told JavaScript to print on the console only whoever is in position zero, thus participantes[0] , this means that the number that we specify inside the square brackets [...] It will be the indicated position, very well, now let's see what position Laura is in, for this, type the following:

 console.log(participantes[1]);

Returns the list of participants so you can compare your results.

 return participantes;

Remember in human language this would be the first position but for the laura machine it is second, now try to find where Thiago is, once you find him you will have what you need to continue advancing in this course; See you in the next lesson.

A common mistake when working with indexes or positions

It is very common that when working with lists we reference a position that is not in the array, for example, if a list has 3 positions and we want to access 5, the program will return undefined as a result, this in itself is not an error , at least in JavaScript, but it can be quite frustrating not knowing what's going on or because the program doesn't return the expected result.

Let's see the above in an example.

  1. Create a list of participants in a race, as we did in the previous lesson.

 let participantes = ["Juan", "Laura", "Thiago"];

Notice that the list only has 3 positions that we can access (0, 1, 2), what if we wanted to access position 5?

  1. Returns position 5 of the array to the console, below the already defined list.

 return participantes[5];

  1. Click the run button.

Look at the “Your result” section, you will see that “null” comes out, this, as you can imagine, is caused by a bad implementation of the positions.

How to correct it?

Maybe by now you already know how to correct the “error” , but we are still going to see it in detail.

  1. Change the required position to one that does exist, for example position 0.

 return participantes[0];

  1. Again click the run button.

Now you can see that the result in the console is “John”.

This "error" may seem simple to you, however be careful since in a very extensive program its identification can be somewhat tedious in addition to taking up a lot of time.

We know that errors can be boring but they are a natural part of software development, the important thing is that you never give up and look for the solution, see you in the next lesson.

push and length statements

In the last tutorial we saw how we could access the positions of an array in JavaScript, likewise in previous courses we reviewed how to go through these arrays element by element using the for loop, one more step in mastering this topic will be knowing what push does and length when we apply them in our programs.

Previously we had this list of brokers:

 let participantes = ["Juan", "Laura", "Thiago"];

insert new items

What if someone else wanted to sign up for the race? for that we use the push() method, this will add the last registered participant to the end of the list, see the following example:

 let participantes = ["Juan", "Laura", "Thiago"]; participantes.push("Jonathan"); console.log(participantes);

As you can see we have added “Jonathan” to the list of participants, note that the correct way to use the push method is by using a dot " . " as a union between the list and the method itself.

Know the length of the list or array

Well now let's count how many participants there are currently in the race, for this we use the length statement Let's see how it is done, to do this create a new line of code with the following content:

 console.log(participantes.length);

This time the program will print the length of the list, which if we counted 3 initials plus one that was joined at the end, the result will be 4.

Returns the list of participants so you can compare your results.

 return participantes;

practice what you learned

What would be the final length of the list if 3 more people joined the race? Try to solve this question by yourself by adding 3 more people and accessing the final length, when you achieve it, go to the next lesson where we will begin to see what the code blocks are, see you there.

JavaScript code blocks

Generally, a computer program is divided into several parts to facilitate its reading and maintenance, one of the most basic ways in which we can make these separations is through the implementation of code blocks, so in this chapter we will explain what they are and what they are. is how it works in JavaScript.

Block Representation

To begin with, it may help you to think of blocks as small boxes where you can store a set of instructions. If you look closely, this definition can be similar to what arrays are, only this time we do not store data.

Now you may be surprised to know that you have already used code blocks throughout all our tutorials so understanding them will not be difficult, for example the following code snippet contains a block, take a good look.

 function bloques() { if (true) { // comienzo del bloque let variableLocal = 'variableLocal '; var variableGlobal = 'variableGlobal ' console.log(variableLocal + 'dentro de bloque'); console.log(variableGlobal + 'dentro de bloque'); } // final del bloque console.log(variableGlobal + 'fuera de bloque'); return variableGlobal }

As you can see, both console.log() that report being inside the if conditional have something in common and that is that they are enclosed by brace signs {...} that open and close, for its part the third console.log() is outside the scope of that conditional's block.

Why use blocks?

Blocks are very important in our code since they can control the execution of the code or the scope of the variables. For example, if in the previous exercise we changed the condition of the if to be false, everything inside said block will not be executed, try it yourself and run the program to see what comes out.

Finally, it returns the main "End of block" phrase so that you can see where the execution ends.

 return variableGlobal;

Congratulations, you are doing very well, keep going.

nested blocks

In the previous lesson we saw how we could use blocks and most importantly how they are identified and behave in our code, now it is time to see what nesting means, which is nothing more than putting blocks inside others.

Example of nested blocks.

Let's take a house as an example, this is divided into blocks such as the kitchen, the living room and the rooms, therefore the house itself would be the parent or main block, that is, the one who stores the others.

Representation in code

Let's go to see the previous example in JavaScript code to do this write the following in the editor, inside the casa() function

 let cocina = true; let sala = true; const habitaciones = ["principal", "familiar", "visitas"]; if(cocina === true) { console.log("Hay una cocina en esta casa"); } if(sala === true) { console.log("Hay una sala en esta casa"); } for(let habitacion of habitaciones) { console.log(habitacion) }

As you can see, the house in the example is the function itself, this represents the main block, we have 2 conditional blocks and one more with a for loop, remember that the way to identify where a block begins and ends is by the symbols of braces {...} after a statement.

Finally return the list of rooms and check your results.

 return habitaciones;

Great, now you are ready for a little guided exercise that we have prepared in the next lesson, here we go

For with a nested if

In the last lesson we defined what a block was and how we can use it in our programs; Continuing with the example of the house and its different blocks, we are going to solve a small exercise which will give you the opportunity to see how to deal with a problem and solve it through programming.

The progress that we had up to the previous lesson will appear in the code editor, now our job will be to create one more block to represent a bathroom that was built in the main room, for this we must use the if conditional, let's analyze the problem.

The first thing we must do is understand the requirements, in this case we are asked to create one more block for a bathroom that will only exist in the main room, and we also have a clue as to how we should build said bathroom and this is through the use of the if conditional.

Well, it is time to identify in which block the new bathroom should be, for this the first step will be to find the main room, if you look at the editor you will see that there is a for cycle that runs through each of the rooms, in this way:

 for(let habitacion of habitaciones) { // Recorre las habitaciones una a una }

This means that the new block or "bathroom" must be built inside the block belonging to the for loop.

Great, now we only need to build this block, which, as we already know, is an if conditional, let's see why, to do this, go to the editor and inside the for loop type the following:

 console.log("Hay un baño")

Now that we have the bathroom block, the last step will be to place it in the main room, note that the if block It does not have a real condition yet, this means that if we execute the code it will print "There is a bathroom" 4 times in the console and we only need it to print once, let's see how we can achieve this, to do this type the following:

 if(habitacion === "baño") { console.log("Hay un baño en la casa") } else { console.log("Encontramos un habitación:" + habitacion + " , seguiremos buscando el baño") }

Perfect we already have it, if you execute it again you will see that the phrase "There is a bathroom" will only be printed once.

Finally we add a return so that the code is correct "return room" , the final code would look like this:

 for(let habitacion of habitaciones) { if(habitacion === "baño") { console.log("Hay un baño en la casa"); return habitacion; } else { console.log("Encontramos un habitación:" + habitacion + " , seguiremos buscando el baño"); } }

Congratulations, you're doing amazing, don't give up and keep learning :)

Arrays and conditions

Welcome to this basic level JavaScript challenge here you will have the opportunity to test yourself and demonstrate your knowledge.

How to proceed?

  1. In the editor on the right you will find a code snippet like the following

 function reto(listaDeCompras) { // Escribe tu código aquí }

  1. As you can see the reto() function receives a parameter called listaDeCompras this represents the test cases that will be applied to your solution.

  2. Each case will contain a list like the following ["spaghetti", "pollo", "zanahoria" ] with more or less number of elements.

  3. Analyze the statement of the exercise and try to solve it

Statement: Mauricio has several shopping lists of different lengths, your job will be to find out the length of these lists and return a different answer depending on the following cases:

  1. If the length of the list is less than or equal to 4, the program will return the first element of the array.

  2. If the length of the list is greater than four and less than 7, the program will return the last position of the array.

  3. If the length of the list is greater than or equal to 7, the program will return the last position of the array minus 2.

Examples:

  1. Given the case that the list is this ["spaghetti", "pollo", "zanahoria" ] the program must return "spaghetti"

  2. In the event that the list is this ["yuca", "papa", "platano", "arracacha", "tomate", "cebolla"] the program must return "onion".

  3. If the list is this ["yogurt", "leche", "gelatina", "queso", "mermelada", "uvas", "fresas", "moras"] the program must return "grapes"

Get to work and good luck ;-)

Challenge: Logistics operators

Welcome to this basic level JavaScript challenge where you will have the opportunity to test yourself and demonstrate your knowledge.

How to proceed?

  1. In the editor on the right you will find a code snippet like the following

 function operadoresLogicos(cajas, transporte, pedido) { // Escribe tu código aquí }

  1. As you can see, the operadoresLogicos() function receives three parameters, these are cajas , transporte and pedido , which represent the test cases that will be applied to your solution.

  2. Each variable stores a true or false value ( true - false ).

  3. Analyze the statement of the exercise and try to solve it

Statement: A souvenir shop in Egypt sells its handicrafts both abroad and locally, but there are certain conditions for their shipment or clearance which condition the response of the program, these are:

  1. If there are cajas , transporte and an pedido , then the package will be sent abroad and the program should return the following:

 "Pedido del extranjero"

  1. If there is transporte or cajas and an pedido , then the package will be shipped locally and the program should return the following:

 "Pedido local"

  1. If there is no pedido , then the package will not be sent and the program should return the following:

 "No se ha hecho ningún pedido aún"

  1. If there are no cajas or transporte , the program must return the following:

 "No se puede enviar el pedido"


Tips:

  1. Use conditionals.

  2. Maybe you need to use all the logical operators.

Examples:

  1. Given the case that cajas=true , transporte=true , pedido=true the expected output would be: "Foreign order".

  2. Given the case that cajas=false , transporte=true , pedido=true the expected output would be: "Local order".

  3. Given the case that cajas=false , transporte=false , pedido=true the expected output would be: "The order cannot be sent".

Get to work and good luck ;-)

Challenge: conditionals

Welcome to this basic level JavaScript challenge here you will have the opportunity to test yourself and demonstrate your knowledge.

How to proceed?

  1. In the editor on the right you will find a code snippet like the following

 function condicionales(edadAlumnos) { // Escribe tu código aquí }

  1. As you can see the condicionales() function receives a parameter, this is edadAlumno and represents the test cases that will be applied to your solution.

  2. Each case will have a list of ages with random numbers.

  3. Analyze the statement of the exercise and try to solve it

Statement: A university has a list of ages for business and finance students. Your job is to count how many underage students are on the list and how many are older. A student under 18 years of age is considered a minor; those who exceed that number will be of legal age.

The program should return a string like the following:

 "Menores: 5, Mayores: 4"

Tips:

  1. It uses concatenation to achieve the expected result.

  2. Use a loop of your choice to traverse the list

Examples:

  1. In the event that the list of ages sent is [16, 21, 18, 20], the program must return “Minors: 1, Majors: 3”.

  2. In the event that the list of ages sent is [17, 20, 16, 24], the program must return “Minors: 2, Majors: 2”.

Functions in JavaScript

Welcome to the intermediate level JavaScript course, this time you will learn one of the most relevant topics when it comes to programming, we are talking about functions; We have already had approximations and worked with functions in previous tutorials, however for this opportunity it will finally be clear to you what these statements are and how they work in JavaScript.

During all our JavaScript courses you will realize that there is always a block of code like the following:

 function nombreDeLaFuncion() { // código JavaScript }

This time you will know once and for all what this means and how you can create your own functions.

A function, in a few words, is a block of code that has a function in charge, hence its name. These functions can be called at any time using their name, this is called referencing.

The above may not make much sense to you, so we are going to simplify it more with the example of a small calculator, this will have the ability to perform 4 basic operations (add, subtract, multiply and divide).

Creating functions

Let's start by creating the suma() function.

  1. Type the following replacing the comment // función de suma aquí

 function suma() { let a = 3; let b = 4; console.log(a + b); return a + b; }

  1. Call the suma() function you just created inside the calculadora() function

     function calculadora() { suma(); }

As you can see we have invoked the suma() function by referring to its name, simple isn't it?

Note: Inside these parentheses we can pass values as parameters, but we will see these in the next lesson.

The rest works normally; as you already know everything inside the curly braces will be executed as part of the function block.

  1. create a function for the subtraction by replacing the comment // función de resta aquí :

 function resta() { let a = 3; let b = 4; console.log(a - b); return a - b; }

In this case we want to subtract a which is equal to 3 minus b which is equal to 4 this will result in -1.

  1. At the end it returns the values of all the functions and adds them as follows:

 function calculadora() { let s = suma(); let r = resta(); return s + r; }

Congratulations, you did a great job, let's move on to the next lesson.

Parameters of a function in JavaScript

The parameters are values to which the block of a function has access, these are passed inside the parentheses that go after the name, for example function suma(numero1, numero2)

Note: For good practice, it is customary for a function to only do one type of thing, generally in relation to its name; For example, if the function were called makeT- fabricarCamisetas() It doesn't make sense for us to call on her to make pants.

Creating a calculator

Now we are going to see how we can improve the calculator from the last lesson so that it adds 2 numbers that we pass to it.

1. Type the following in the editor replacing the comment // función de suma con parametros

 function suma(numero1, numero2) { console.log(numero1 + numero2); return numero1 + numero2; }

Notice that the variables numero2 numero1 now inside the parentheses, this means that when we call the suma() function we will have to pass both values to it.

2. Create the other functions for subtraction, multiplication, and division, following the example of the previous function.

How to pass parameters or values to a function

The parameters are passed once the function is called, in the same order in which they were created or defined, that is to say that for our example we first pass numero1 and then numero2 like this:

 function calculadora() { // invocar función suma con parámetros suma(4,5); }

Note that we have passed two numbers, 4 and 5, these numbers will take the place occupied by the variables numero2 numero1 this means that the suma() function will add both values, resulting in 9.

Invoke the other functions you created and pass them the necessary arguments for their correct operation.

  1. Now declare the return value in a resultado variable and return the sum of all functions like so:

 function calculadora() { let s = suma(4,5); let r = resta(4,5); let m = multiplicacion(4,5); let d = division(4,5); return s + r + m + d; }

Alright, now you're ready for a final little exercise, see you there.

How to return values in JavaScript

So far we have used very simple functions that, although they print a value to the console, do not actually return anything, so let's see how we can return values using the return statement.

Continuing with the example of the calculator, let's go on to actually return the values instead of simply printing them on the console. For this, as is customary, let's create 4 functions that represent each basic operation, starting with the addition

  1. create the suma() function

 function suma(numero1, numero2) { let resultado = numero1 + numero2; return resultado }

Note that instead of using console.log() as we did before, the return statement is now implemented you can also notice that its syntax is very simple since we simply use return plus the value we want to return in this case resultado

  1. create the other functions for subtraction, multiplication and division based on the example from the previous step

Note: the return statement it can only be used once since once the program reads this instruction the function will end.

How to view the result

If at this moment you were to call any function from inside calculadora() and execute the code you will see that nothing actually happens, this is because the return statement it only returns a value but it is not responsible for displaying it, for this we will call the functions inside a console.log() as follows:

  1. Print the result returned by the suma() function to the console. To do this, replace the comment found in the calculator function that says // imprime el valor de suma()

 console.log(suma(6, 6));

  1. Run your code.

  2. Print the value returned by each function you created earlier (subtraction, multiplication, division), do not forget to pass each one its corresponding parameters.

  3. Returns the sum of all the functions, passing as function arguments the same numbers that appear in the following example:

 return suma(8,4) + resta(14,7) + multiplicacion(7,4) + division(8,4);

  1. run your code again.

Congratulations, you already know the most relevant concepts when working with functions, it's time to raise the level a bit by implementing test cases, see you in the next lesson.

Introduction to test cases

Test cases are not something that belongs to JavaScript or any language in particular, they are actually opportunities to test your code that we implement at PeakU think of it as something like having a personal tutor.

How do they work?

In the lower area you can see two dropdowns called precisely " test cases #n" if you open any of them you will find a subtitle in bold that says "Arguments" these, as you can imagine, are the arguments that we have been passing manually to each function.

We are going to continue using the calculator function so that you understand well how the test cases work.

In the code editor you can see that there are already 2 functions, suma() and calculadora() , also they have 2 parameters or arguments which are num1 and num2 .

Finally notice that we have already called and returned the sum() function inside calculator.

 function calculadora(num1, num2) { return suma(num1, num2); // invocación y retorno }

How to proceed?

  1. Run your code and once it loads, go down to the test cases, you will see that both are in red , this means that we have a programming error that we must correct.

  2. Locate the suma() function in the editor maybe you can identify that there is an error, let's see.

 function suma(num1, num2) { let resultado = num1 - num2; return resultado; }

As you can tell the suma() function is actually subtracting so we need to correct it.

  1. change the operator - for his counterpart +

 function suma(num1, num2) { let resultado = num1 + num2; return resultado; }

  1. Run your code again, now the test cases will have a green color, this means that you have tested and now your result is the same as expected.

Perfect now you are ready to complete the calculator and return your code to be reviewed applying test cases, just remember if the cases are red it means you have a bug, when all are green then your code is perfect ;)

Finalizing the calculator

In the editor you will see that there is already an important advance with the example of the calculator and the 4 basic operations, note that the calculator function receives 3 arguments inside its parentheses, these are operador , num1 and num2 , we want to build a program that identifies which operator is arriving and calls the corresponding function for each case, eg if the operador is equal to the string “+” then it will execute the suma() function, if it is “-” it will execute the resta() function and so on, now let's move on to the code.

  1. Create the conditionals for each possible operator in the calculadora() function like so:

 if (operador === "+") { // suma }else if (operador === "-") { // resta }else if (operador === "*") { // multiplicación }else if (operador === "/") { // división }

  1. Calls and returns each function in its respective conditional.

 if (operador === "+") { return suma(); }else if (operador === "-") { return resta(); }else if (operador === "*") { return multiplicacion(); }else if (operador === "/") { return division(); }

  1. Pass the arguments num1 and num2 to each function.

 if (operador === "+") { return suma(num1, num2); }else if (operador === "-") { return resta(num1, num2); }else if (operador === "*") { return multiplicacion(num1, num2); }else if (operador === "/") { return division(num1, num2); }

  1. run your code

If you followed all the steps correctly, now the test cases should be green, this means that you have passed and your code is perfect.

The magic of this system is that it allows you to put your code to the test since in programming it doesn't matter how much you got to an answer or how many steps you did, but rather that the answer is always the expected one and not something different since this would mean a programming error. programming commonly known as bugs.

Congratulations, you have finished this course on functions in JavaScript, we invite you to continue learning with the other courses that we have prepared for you. Don't forget to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✔ "check" button in the top right corner of your screen.

Object literals in JavaScript

Welcome to this second intermediate JavaScript tutorial, this time you will learn to master one of the most used data types in front-end programming, such as the literal object, let's start.


Definition: A JavaScript object literal is a set of data stored in key-value form, delimited by curly braces {...} and usually assigned to a variable .

The above definition, although it may be correct, may be quite confusing and too abstract to understand at first glance, so we are going to simplify it a little more, for this you can imagine that you have a dictionary of words like the following:

dog: 4-legged canine animal

glasses: object used to protect the sight

water: a liquid substance made up of hydrogen and oxygen

In this example the words in bold are the keys and the definitions are the values.

How to create an object literal

  1. Let's move on to building an object using the example above, to do this type the following in the editor, replacing the comment that says crea tu objeto aquí

 let diccionario = { perro: "Animal canino de 4 patas", gafas: "Objeto utilizado para proteger la vista", agua: "Sustancia líquida compuesta por hidrógeno y oxígeno" }


As you can see we have stored the object in the dictionary variable, also note that the keys (dog, glasses, water) are followed by a colon : and do not use quotes, meanwhile the definitions or values are a data type, in this case strings or text strings, so we must use the quotes "..." , finally each pair of key and value ends with a comma ( , ) this is very important as otherwise the program will give an error.

  1. Prints the diccionario variable to the console. To print objects in this interpreter and display the content, it is necessary to first convert them to String with JSON.stringify() , like this:

     console.log(JSON.stringify(diccionario));

Review

  1. Finally we are going to represent a car in the form of a JavaScript object so that the concept is clearer for you. Delete the dictionary object we created earlier and replace it with the following:

 let automovil = { marca: "Renault", color: "Rojo", modelo: 2006 }

Note that in this case we have stored more than one type of data in the object since we have the strings "Renault" and "Rojo" and a numerical value that would be 2006 , this means that we can store multiple types of data in the same object .

  1. Remove the console.log() and return the automovil variable.

     return automovil;

Congratulations you have completed this lesson, in the next one you will learn how to access the data or values of an object we do not see there.

How to access the values of an object in JavaScript

Now that you know what they are and how to create literal objects in JavaScript, the next step will be to be able to access each of the data stored in these objects.

As a preview you should know that there are two ways to access the values of a literal object, these are by using a period or using brackets [...] , however for this occasion we will focus on the most standardized and commonly implemented which is the nomenclature of the point.

In the previous lesson we had a car object like the following:

 let automovil = { marca: "Renault", color: "Rojo", modelo: 2006 }

The question now is how we access each value individually, for example if we wanted to access the color of the car, this is where we use the aforementioned dot nomenclature.

Access car color

1. Write the following example in the editor replacing the comment that says acceder al color

 console.log(automovil.color);

If you focus on what is inside the parentheses of the console.log() you will see that by using a dot ( . ) as a union between the car object and its components we have called the color attribute this is equivalent to Let's tell JavaScript something like this: "JavaScript friend, I want the car object to tell me what its color is."

  1. Execute the current code, you will see how the word "Red" is printed in the console, which is just the color we need, simple right? Now let's get to the make of the car.

Access the car brand

1. Write the following line replacing the comment that says access the markup

 return automovil.marca;

  1. Run the code again. What do you think the result will be? Finally try to access the car model and run your code to see the results.

You do very well, let's continue with the next lesson.

How to modify values in a JavaScript object

In the previous lesson we saw how we could access the values of an object, this time we will see how we can add and remove those values.

Let's start by learning how to add, for example we have a guitar object like the following:

 let guitarra = { cuerdas: 6, color: "negro" }

How to insert values

  1. Now we want to add a new property that tells us the type of guitar, for example acoustic, electric, etc. For this we will also use the nomenclature of the point in this way, replace the following line in the comment añade el tipo de la guitarra aquí .

 guitarra.tipo = "Acustica";

Note that the process is very similar to the one used to create a variable, only this time that value will be stored inside the object. You can check this if you print the guitar object in the console.

  1. In the comment, imprime el objeto aquí write the following.

 console.log(JSON.stringify(guitarra));

3. Run the code.

You will see that the new property was added to the end of the object.

How to delete values

  1. Now let's see how to delete an existing value, for example the color, for this we use the reserved word delete followed by the value to be deleted, again using the point, it may sound complicated but it is not at all, look at the following example:

 delete guitarra.color;

This simple statement has just removed the color attribute from the guitar object.

  1. Run your code again.

How to edit values

  1. Finally let's see how we can update a value, for example the number of strings of our guitar, this time we will use the nomenclature of the point again, in fact the instruction is quite similar to the one we used previously to add a new property, observe how:

 guitarra.cuerdas = 8;

  1. Return the guitar object and check your results.

 return guitarra;

Keep up the pace, let's continue with the next lesson.

List of objects in JavaScript

In previous courses we have defined and worked with arrays or lists, also throughout this chapter we have worked in depth with literal objects in JavaScript, one of the greatest possibilities that programming offers us is to be able to mix different concepts to create new functionalities, in In this case we will see how to store multiple objects in the form of a list, let's start.

Commonly we are going to need to group many objects in a single list, this is due to the ease that these lists have to be traversed with a loop, either for or while , which allows a better ordering and access to the data.

Create a list of objects

Let's then go on to create the list, to do this imagine that you are in a car dealership where there are 3 cars available, each car has a color, a number of windows and a model, now it is time to represent this in JavaScript code.

  1. Type the following where the Crea tu lista de coches comment is located:

 let concesionarioDeCoches = [ {marca: "Chevrolet", color: "verde", ventanas: 4, modelo: 2015}, {marca: "Mustang", color: "azul", ventanas: 6, modelo: 2022}, {marca: "Renault", color: "gris", ventanas: 6, modelo: 2009} ];

  1. Replace in comment // imprimir lista completa

     console.log(JSON.stringify(concesionarioDeCoches));

  2. Run the code and you will see the full list of cars.

    Now, what would happen if, for example, a dealership employee wanted to show the cars one by one? To do this, we can use the for…of cycle, which, as you know, goes through each element in the list individually, just what we need.

Loop through a list of objects

  1. Now go to the editor and type the following replacing the comment that says Recorrer lista de coches

 for(let coche of concesionarioDeCoches) { console.log("Estás viendo el coche " + coche.marca) }

What this for loop will do is behave like the employee presenting the cars by brand to the customers one by one, reporting which one he is showing each time.

  1. Run the program again.

  2. Return the concesionarioDeCoches list and check your results

 return concesionarioDeCoches;

Alright, remember to run your code and check the results.

See you in the next lesson.

One day at the dealer

In the last lesson we had a dealership with three cars which were displayed one by one using a for loop. In this little exercise as a story where we will try to simulate the arrival of more vehicles at the dealership, at the same time that the employee informs us of the situation, to finally end up with the purchase of a car by a customer.

Right now the dealership looks like this:

 let concesionarioDeCoches = [ {marca: "Chevrolet", color: "verde", ventanas: 4, modelo: 2015}, {marca: "Mustang", color: "azul", ventanas: 6, modelo: 2022}, {marca: "Renault", color: "gris", ventanas: 6, modelo: 2009} ];

You can see that this part already appears in the code editor.

The following steps will show the process that the employee must carry out to receive the new vehicles and finally manage to sell one of them.

How to proceed

Write each of the steps in the editor and run the code in each of them to understand how they work.

Step 1: The clerk reports how many cars there are currently.

 console.log("En este momento tenemos " + concesionarioDeCoches.length + " coches");

 concesionarioDeCoches.push({marca: "Sedán", color: "rojo", ventanas: 5, modelo: 2018}); concesionarioDeCoches.push({marca: "Toyota", color: "negro", ventanas: 6, modelo: 2021});

 console.log("Acaba de llegar un nuevo cargamento con 2 vehículos, por lo tanto ahora hay " + concesionarioDeCoches.length + " coches en el concesionario");
