 console.log("Empleado: Hola, puedo ayudarle en algo señor/a"); console.log("Cliente: Hola, estoy buscando un auto, podría mostrarme los que tiene disponibles, por favor"); console.log("Empleado: Claro, pase por favor");

while and do…while loops

Welcome to this JavaScript tutorial in which you will learn about while and do…while , their uses and strengths within a program, we will also see what break and continue statements are along with their usefulness in the code.

while loop

The while is quite similar to the for loop, that is, both are designed to be executed over and over again depending on the condition, the difference lies in how many times they are executed, while the for loop is commonly used to loop through lists or ranges, the while is most often used when we have no idea when the loop itself is going to end.

You can imagine the while as a snake chasing its own tail, it will stay around at the same point until it realizes it is chasing itself, but until the snake realizes it can happen one or many laps.

How about we render this snake in JavaScript code.

  1. Type the following in the editor:

 let vueltas = 1; while (vueltas <= 10) { console.log("Estoy dando la vuelta: " + vueltas); vueltas = vueltas + 1; // vueltas ++; }

This code works as follows, we have defined a variable vueltas which will act as a counter and start its value at zero, then the while , in this case “the snake”, evaluates if vueltas is less than 10, if it is true the snake will say “I am turning 1” and increase the count in 1, that is, now the vueltas variable will have the value of 1 + 1, and it will go to the next lap where it will say the same thing and the vueltas variable will take the value of 2 + 1, the cycle will continue until laps is greater than or equal to ten since in that case the condition is not met.

Tip: the commented line vueltas++ is equivalent to vueltas = vueltas + 1 , that is, it will increase the count of the vueltas variable by 1.

  1. Click on the execute button.

We can tell when the snake realizes it's chasing itself by adding the following line outside the curly braces of the while :

  1. Add one more line to understand when the loop ends.

 console.log("Me dí cuenta que era mi cola :(");

  1. Finally, return the final number of laps and check your results.

     return vueltas;

    Congratulations you have completed this lesson, in the next one we will talk about the do…while cycle and its uses, see you.

do…while loop in JavaScript

The do…while has only one difference from the simple while , and this is that no matter what the condition is, the program will execute the corresponding block at least once. This makes it very useful in case we need a program to implement said condition. functionality.

Continuing with the example from the previous lesson where we had a snake chasing itself, this time we will change the circumstances a bit by adding a mouse, let's imagine that the snake chases the little mouse and suddenly it starts to go around in a circle, the snake will have no choice but to chase its prey in circles at least once until it manages to catch it, let's see how to represent this in JavaScript code.

  1. Parse and write the following code in the editor:

     while(!ratonFueAtrapado && vueltasDelRaton <= 3) { if(vueltasDelRaton >= 3) { ratonFueAtrapado = true; console.log("¡Yupí, atrapé al ratón!"); }else { console.log("El ratón dió una vuelta"); vueltasDelRaton++; } }

    1. Click the run button and check your results. This code catches the mouse and returns the boolean variable ratonFueAtrapado to true as expected by the exercise.

    2. Now change the initial conditions and put let vueltasDelRaton = 4 , in this case we don't trap the mouse. We need the code inside the while to be executed yes or yes at least once. For that we will use the do...while loop which guarantees that at least the iteration is done once.

    3. Delete the while loop and replace it with:

 do { if(vueltasDelRaton >= 3) { ratonFueAtrapado = true; console.log("¡Yupí, atrapé al ratón!"); }else { console.log("El ratón dió una vuelta"); vueltasDelRaton++; } } while(!ratonFueAtrapado && vueltasDelRaton <= 3)

  1. Click the run button and check your results.

As you can see, the snake caught the mouse when it was on lap number 3, so when the program reaches the line of the condition while( ratonFueAtrapado !== true ) the do…while will end since the variable ratonFueAtrapado not is different from true.

The do…while is very useful when you need to implement a while loop where at least one iteration over the code has to be guaranteed.

See you in the next lesson.

A common mistake when working with while loops.

When we work with while We must be careful that this is not an infinite loop since this would cause problems when executing the code and we will end up consuming all the resources of our computer.

This is known as “task time out” . In our case, the program terminates itself after a certain time, but it is possible that when working with an IDE (integrated development environment) the program simply runs indefinitely, forcing you to terminate it yourself or even restart the machine.

By now you know why we use a counter variable when working with while , but what if it is not used? Let's see it with an example.

  1. Create a counter variable.

 let contador = 1;

  1. Create a while loop with the condition (counter <= 10) that prints the variable we just defined.

 while(contador <= 10) { console.log(contador); }

  1. Click on run

You can see that after a while the program stops after printing many ones (1) in the console, also in the "Your result:" section in the test cases you will see an error like this:

 Error: 2022-05-03T00:38:58.046Z 5cc9fe44-e3b8-4f57-af9b-3583649f868e Task timed out after 3.04 seconds Tipo de error: None Lugar: desconocido

In a few words, this tells us that the cycle is infinite, it is as if it were a runner who never reached the goal because he was not able to reach it.

How to fix the error.

Obviously the best way to ensure that the loop completes is, in this case, to ensure that the counter variable always increments its count by one as we saw in previous lessons.

  1. Add the following line inside the curly braces of the while loop just below the console.log() :

 contador++;

This will increase the count as you already know.

  1. Click run and check the result.

Once you run you will see that the numbers from 1 to 10 are printed on the console, just what we expected, and the error disappeared.

  1. Finally return the final number of laps and check your results.

 return vueltas;

Alright, you've completed this lesson, keep going.

Use of the continue statement

The continue statement usually has a fairly recurring use when working with cycles, both for and while , this statement is used to jump to the next execution or iteration of the cycle.

Mostly, the continue statement is used inside a conditional in order to control the flow of program execution.

One of the simplest examples that we can find to understand what this sentence does is through a counter that reports the turns that the cycle has made, let's see this in JavaScript code.

  1. Create a variable that will act as a counter.

 let contador = 1;

  1. Build the while with the condition ( contador <= 10 ).

 while(contador <= 10) { console.log("número: " + contador); // aumenta en uno la cuenta contador++; }

As you can see we want to print the value of the counter variable in each round of the cycle, in addition to increasing the count by one as you already know.

  1. Click on execute, you will see that the numbers from 1 to 10 are printed on the console.

Using the continue statement

So far you may not find anything new, now what would happen if we wanted to skip a number, for example 5, for this we will use the word continue as you can imagine, let's see how.

  1. Create a conditional above the console.log() like so:

 if(contador === 5) { console.log("me salté un número"); contador++; continue; }

  1. Run the code again, you will see that this time the program will print the phrase "I skipped a number" instead of the number 5 itself.

  2. Finally return the final value of the counter variable and check your results.

 return contador;

Alright, you've finished this lesson, keep up your pace and keep learning.

Use of the break statement

Like continue , break is also usually used inside a loop but with the difference that when the program reads the break statement, the iterations will end, that is, the loop, whether while or for , will end immediately.

How to stop a cycle

Stopping a cycle means getting out of it as already explained, now let's see it in action

  1. Define a new variable that will help us with the execution.

 let contador = 1;

  1. Create the while loop with a conditional in the same way as in the previous lesson.

 while(contador <= 10) { if(contador === 5) { console.log("me salté el número: " + contador); contador++; continue; } console.log("numero: " + contador); contador++;  // aumenta en uno la cuenta }

  1. Click on execute, you will see that for now the only thing the program does is skip number 5 as in the last lesson

  2. Now change the while loop to look like the following, notice the use of the break statement.

 while(contador <= 10) { if(contador === 5) { console.log("Rompí el ciclo en la vuelta número: " + contador); break; } console.log("vuelta numero: " + contador); contador++;  // aumenta en uno la cuenta }

  1. Run again, now you will see that only the numbers from 1 to 4 have been printed on the console along with the phrase "I broke the cycle on lap number: 5" .

This is just what the break statement does , it simply terminates the execution of the loop ignoring whether or not the defined condition is met.

  1. Finally, return the final value of the contador variable and check your results.

 return contador;

Great, you have finished this lesson, now you can go to the last one where you can see a small example of the use of break in the for loop, see you there.

Using break in the for loop

Both the break and continue statements can also be used inside the for loop and its operation is basically the same.

On this occasion we will work with lists since they are usually very common in the programs we make, and you will also be able to realize that these sentences are not only used when working with numbers but with other types of data.

  1. Create a list of fruits and a fruit to search for.

 let listaDeFrutas = ["fresa", "mora", "maracuyá", "naranja"]; let frutaBuscada;

  1. Build a for…of loop to display each fruit in the list.

 for(let fruta of listaDeFrutas) { console.log(fruta); }

  1. Click on run and you will see that each fruit is printed individually on the console.

Find a specific fruit.

It may be that sometimes you want a loop to run until you get an expected result, for example, we want to run the loop only until the fruit "passion fruit" is found, from then on we are not interested in the others, let's move on to the code.

  1. Create a conditional by replacing the statement console.log(fruta) written in a previous instruction

 if(fruta === "maracuyá") { console.log("Yupí, ya encontré la fruta que buscaba y es: " + fruta); frutaBuscada = fruta; break; }else { console.log(fruta +  " no es la fruta que busco"); }

  1. Click on run.

On this occasion you will be able to observe that the program prints twice the phrase "it is not the fruit I am looking for" but the third round of the cycle, since the fruit is the expected one, the program prints "I already found the fruit I was looking for and it is: passion fruit” and the program will end without taking into account the last fruit, which in this case is the orange .

  1. Finally type the following line just after the closing of the block belonging to the for cycle:

 return frutaBuscada;

Congratulations, you have completed this course of cycles and sentences, we invite you to continue learning with the other courses that we have prepared for you, remember to save your changes by clicking on the "check" button that appears in the upper right.

Object-oriented programming

Welcome to this tutorial where we will learn what object-oriented programming is and how it is implemented in JavaScript code.

Definition

Object Oriented Programming (OOP) is a form of programming that seeks to structure the code by creating objects, being an object anything, for example, a ball, a plant or even a person or animal, all this can be represented as an object and that's what we'll be looking at during this step-by-step tutorial.

Lessons

Object-oriented programming consists of several parts which we will learn throughout this course, in that order of ideas we will start with the classes, which, in a few words, are a mold with which we can create objects, this is easier than understand with examples so let's go to the code where we will represent a rock band, take your guitar and drums and... Let's rock!

  1. Write the following class in the editor replacing the comment // build your class here

 class BandaDeRock {   // cuerpo de la clase }

As you can see, creating a class is quite simple, all we have to do is type the reserved word class followed by the name of our class, which in this case is BandaDeRock , finally we open and close curly braces since, as you might guess, this is a block of code.

attributes

The attributes are everything that an object can have, in our case the band can have a name, number of members, popular songs and much more, to keep it simple for now we will only give the band a name.

Create name attribute, replace // body of class .

 class BandaDeRock { nombre = "Titans"; }

Note that an attribute is very similar to a variable with the only difference that we do not use the let , var keywords. either const to create them.

Create the “band” object.

Now that we have the mold for our band, it's time to create it for the whole world to know about.

  1. Create the myBand object by replacing the comment // Create your first object here inside the principal() function, as follows:

 let miBanda = new BandaDeRock();

So, what we did was create a variable miBanda that will store an object of type BandaDeRock , notice that we have used another reserved word which is new , this is used every time we want to create a new object and it is very convenient since it is literally as if we said “I want to create my new band”

  1. Now that you've created your band, let's see what it's made of. To do this, let's return the miBanda variable inside the principal() function.

 return miBanda;

  1. Click the run button.

Finally in the expected output you will see the following:

 {'nombre': 'Titans'}

This means that everything went well and now your band is a reality. Congratulations it's time to move on to the next lesson to see what else we can do with your band.

Access the attributes of an object

In this lesson you will learn how to access the attributes of an object, remember that attributes are everything that an object can have.

Continuing with the band example, let's create it again so you don't forget what the process is.

  1. Create the BandaDeRock class with its nombre attribute replacing the comment // build your class here

 class BandaDeRock {   nombre = "Titans"; }

  1. Now create your band inside the principal() function replaced comment //Create your band here

 let miBanda = new BandaDeRock();

Tip: notice that when we create the myBand object or variable the miBanda BandaDeRock() class has opening and closing parentheses, these are used to pass data as if they were the parameters of a function. We will see this later.

Access your band name

You will not always want to refer to the entire object, in fact most of the time you will only need one thing at a time, for this we will use a syntax that, if you have followed our courses, you will already know what it is, we refer to the nomenclature of the point.

  1. Use the dot to access your band name like this, inside the principal() function:

 console.log(miBanda.nombre);

  1. Click the run button.

On console you can see how the only thing that was printed was the name of the band, in this case “Titans” .

a new attribute

As we already explained, an object can have more than one attribute, for example, your gang can have a number of members, so let's move on to creating said attribute.

  1. Create the attribute numeroIntegrantes just below the nombre attribute of the BandaDeRock class So:

 miBanda.numeroIntegrantes = 4;

  1. Access that new attribute using dot nomenclature again, remembering to place yourself in the main function below the console.log() .

 console.log(miBanda.numeroIntegrantes);

  1. Now return the entire miBanda.

 return miBanda.numeroIntegrantes;

  1. Press the run button again.

On this occasion, 2 results should appear in the console output, which are the name of the band "Titans" and the number of members, which in this case would be 4, in addition to returning this same number.

How well you do it, it's time to raise the level a little and know what the methods are, see you in the next lesson.

methods of an object

The methods are the actions that an object can perform, for example, your rock band can perform, perform concerts, play music, among others, note that each action has an associated verb, perform, perform and play, although it is not a rule unbreakable by convention verbs are often used as they express exactly what action the method will perform, this is known as good programming practice.

Creating methods

To create methods, its syntax is very similar to that used when creating functions, with the difference that the reserved word function is not used, let's see an example in JavaScript code.

Note: A preview of past lessons already appears in the editor.

One of the first actions that your band can carry out when going to a concert is to present itself, we are going to see how to do it.

  1. Write the following lines of code, replacing the comment that says // Create your method here .

 presentarse() {    // cuerpo de la función }

  1. Return the presentation of your band, replace the comment // body of the function .

 presentarse() {   return "Hola nosotros somos Titans, una banda de Rock con 4 integrantes"; }

Remember that methods are essentially functions, so they can also return values.

Access the methods of an object

At this point, you may already be imagining that the way to access the methods of an object is through the nomenclature of the point, as we have already done on many occasions.

  1. Type the following, replacing the comment that says // Return your band's presentation here , inside the principal() function.

 return miBanda.presentarse();

Note that the methods are called with their opening and closing parentheses.

  1. Click on the execute button.

This time you run you will see that the message "Hello, we are Titans, a Rock band with 4 members" appears on the console. which is just the presentation of your band.

Excellent now you know what the methods of an object are and how they are created, let's keep learning, go to the next lesson.

Using this in classes

Many times we are going to need to reference an attribute or method within the class, for that we need to use the this statement , which in words can be a bit difficult to explain without using too technical language, but in itself, its understanding is easier if we simplify it with an example.

Continuing with the creation of the rock band, let's see how to use this within our program.

In the previous lesson we created a method with which the band can perform, said method is the following, which, by the way, you can see is already in the editor.

 presentarse() {   return "Hola nosotros somos Titans una banda de Rock con 4 integrantes"; }

Now notice we return is a simple text that does not have concatenations or any other type of operation, this brings with it a problem and that is that if we changed the name of the band we would have to do it twice, once in the nombre attribute and the other in the text that the method returns. Let's then move on to concatenating the name and the number of members of the band with the rest of the message.

  1. Replace the comment // Submit your band here with the following:

 return "Hola nosotros somos " + this.nombre + ", una banda de Rock con " + this.numeroIntegrantes + " integrantes";

Note that we have concatenated a message using the this statement. followed by a dot and the name of the attributes in this case name and members, now, the function that fulfills this is to represent the created object, in this case said object is miBanda , that is to say that this is similar to writing miBanda.nombre only that it is done inside the class.

  1. Print the slideshow method overriding the comment that says // Imprime la presentación de tu banda aquí in the principal() function.

 console.log(miBanda.presentarse());

  1. Click on the run button.

It may surprise you that the result is exactly the same as the one we already had, but this avoids us, as already said, having to manually modify the message, for example, if your band is now called “Dragons” and has a number of members from 6 you no longer have to manually modify it 2 times.

Give it a try, change the value of the nombre and numeroIntegrantes attributes to “Dragons” and 6 respectively.

  1. Change the attributes.

 nombre = "Dragons"; numeroIntegrantes = 6;

  1. Returns the entire miBanda object.

 return miBanda.presentarse();

  1. Click run one more time.

This time the message is different and obviously we did not have to modify it twice.

Congratulations you have completed this lesson, in the next one we will be looking at what class constructors are, see you there.

builders

A constructor is a method that is used, as its name implies, to build an object, let's say in a slightly more personalized way.

The constructor method is the best way to initialize attributes as we will see later, its operation is very similar to a function with parameters, think that if the class is the mold of an object then the constructor is the one who takes care of it being assembled perfectly said object.

In the code editor you will see an important advance on the project of the rock band, in addition to several commented lines that are the ones that we will replace throughout this lesson, let's begin.

Create the constructor method

  1. Locate the line with the comment // Crea el constructor aquí and replace it with the following:

 constructor(nombre, numeroIntegrantes) {   this.nombre = nombre;   this.numeroIntegrantes = numeroIntegrantes; }

Notice that the constructor receives 2 parameters, nombre and numeroIntegrantes , then we used this to create the attributes inside the constructor and match them to the corresponding parameters, this might sound complex, but just remember this.nombre Y this.numeroIntegrantes are the attributes of the class, while the values to the right of the equal are the parameters that we must pass.

Pass the corresponding parameters

Do you remember that every time we create an object of type BandaDeRock did it end with opening and closing parentheses? Well, it's time to see what they are for.

  1. Create an object of type BandaDeRock by replacing the comment that says // Create your band here

 let miBanda = new BandaDeRock("Titans", 4);

Notice that in the parentheses of BandaDeRock() We have passed 2 arguments or values, these are "Titans" which corresponds to the name of the band and 4 which represents the number of members of your band, these values will be used to build your band.

If it works for you, you can imagine that you are registering your band on the site " BandaDeRock.com " and to do that you must enter the name of the band and the number of members, simple, don't you think so?

  1. Print your band's introduction replacing the comment // Print your band's introduction .

 console.log(miBanda.presentarse());

  1. Click on the execute button.

You will see that the result is similar to what we already had in previous lessons, that does not mean that it is wrong, quite the opposite, in fact, now we have a more sustainable, professional code and the most important thing is that it can be reused as many times as we need.


Create another object of type RockBand

Finally, so that you understand the true utility of the constructor method, we are going to “register” another band, or better said, we are going to create a new object.

Let's say you are now a music promoter and you want to help a person named Daniela create her rock band.

  1. Create a new object of type BandaDeRock replacing the comment that says // Crea la banda de Daniela aquí

 let laBandaDeDaniela = new BandaDeRock("DanDan-Band", 5);

Now we have a new band called laBandaDeDaniela whose name is "DanDan-Band" and its members are 5 .

  1. Print the presentation of the new object you just created, to do this locate the comment that says // Imprime la presentación de la banda de Daniela and write the following:

 console.log(laBandaDeDaniela.presentarse());

  1. Run your code again.

You will see that the following presentation messages will appear on the console:

 Hola nosotros somos Titans una banda de Rock con 4 integrantes Hola nosotros somos DanDan-Band una banda de Rock con 5 integrantes

Finally realize that the builder was the one in charge of putting together both rock bands, the only thing we did was give him what he needed, that's great, don't you think?

  1. Finally, return the phrase laBandaDeDaniela.presentarse() and check your results.

 return laBandaDeDaniela.presentarse();

Congratulations you have completed this lesson, let's move on to the next one where we will see an error that can be annoying and confusing if you don't know what it is.

Failures with the use of this

In previous lessons we discussed what this is , it's time to see why its use is so important within classes.

In the code editor you will see a progress regarding the rock band project, take a good look since something is missing, what do you think if you analyze it a bit and try to find the flaw.

  1. Return your band's introduction replacing the comment that says // Return your band's introduction

 return miBanda.presentarse();

2. Click on the run button

Notice that in the console we have a reference error ( ReferenceError ) and the test case box is red, now the question is what is happening?

Identify the error.

Perhaps at this point you already know what is happening, but if you still do not realize it, we will explain it to you step by step.

Locate the presentarse() method of the BandaDeRock class.

  1. In the return statement of said method add the corresponding this to each attribute, like so:

 return "Hola nosotros somos " + this.nombre + " una banda de Rock con " + this.numeroIntegrantes + " integrantes";

  1. Run the code again.

This time you will see that what is printed on the console is exactly the result we expected

Remember, the use of this It is very important when we work with classes and objects since it can generate this type of errors, but since you know how to identify them, it will be easier to solve it.

Congratulations, you have completed this tutorial on objects and classes, we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other courses that we have prepared for you. Remember to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✔ button that appears in the upper right corner of the screen.

Inheritance in JavaScript

Welcome to this advanced JavaScript tutorial, this time you will have the opportunity to learn about the concept of inheritance and why it is so important when working using the object-oriented programming methodology, let's start.

Note: For a complete understanding of this course you should already have knowledge about what a class is, what it is made of and what the constructor method is.

In previous courses we have already explained what OOP is, however, in this lesson we will delve into the definition of object since it will be of the utmost importance when working with inheritance.

What is an object?

Technically speaking, an object is the result of assigning the methods and attributes of a class to a variable, this is known as an instance, but its understanding can be confusing, so we simplify it with the following example.

Imagine that you want to make cookies and you need a mold for it, but not just any mold but one that suits your needs, so if you decide to build one on your own, said mold would be the class in JavaScript code, let's proceed to represent it.

  1. Create the MoldeGalleta class by replacing the comment that says // Build the class here.

 class MoldeGalleta { constructor(sabor, forma) { this.sabor = sabor; this.forma = forma; } }

Now in this mold we can make cookies of any flavor and shape that we want, it is time to make the cookies.

  1. Create three different objects or “cookies” , write the following replacing the comment that says // Make the cookies here.

 let galletaVainilla = new MoldeGalleta("vainilla", "estrella"); let galletaChocolate = new MoldeGalleta("chocolate", "rombo"); let galletaRonConPasas = new MoldeGalleta("ron con pasas", "octágono");

As you can see we have created 3 “cookies” ( galletaVainilla , galletaChocolate , galletaRonConPasas ) from the MoldeGalleta class , each one has a different flavor and shape, these “cookies” are what are known as objects.

  1. Print each "cookie" or object to the console, replace the comment that says // Print the cookies here.

     console.log(JSON.stringify(galletaVainilla)); console.log(JSON.stringify(galletaChocolate)); console.log(JSON.stringify(galletaRonConPasas));

  2. Click the run button.

  3. Finally it returns an array with the cookies:

 return [galletaVainilla, galletaChocolate, galletaRonConPasas];

Finally, notice that the name of the class we created is MoldeGalleta , this is good to exemplify in more detail what an object is and what a class is, but be careful, since normally the classes are only named in relation to what they are going to do. to create, for example, in this case the most accurate name for the class is Galleta .

Congratulations you have completed this lesson, we hope that now you have a clearer idea of what an object is since we will be seeing it throughout this course.

See you in the next lesson.

How to implement inheritance

We speak of inheritance when a child class inherits or extends the attributes and methods of a parent class, think of it as if it were normal inheritance between people, for example, a parent with light eyes can inherit their genes to the child so that the child also has the clear eyes.

Now that you understand the concept of inheritance a bit, let's move on to the code, where we will represent a vehicle class.

  1. Create the Vehiculo class, with its respective constructor, locate yourself in the comment that says // Build the Vehicle class here and replace it with the following:

 class Vehiculo { constructor() { this.color = 'Rojo'; this.marca = 'Suzuki'; } }

  1. Create a new Motocicleta class that inherits from the Vehiculo class (inheriting in JavaScript language is written as extends ), replace the comment that says // Construct the Motorcycle class here with the following:

 class Motocicleta extends Vehiculo{ /* Aunque el cuerpo de esta clase este vacío, un objeto creado a partir de esta clase tendra color y marca */ }

Notice that right after the Motocicleta class name, there is a new keyword which is extends and then the name of the parent class which is Vehiculo , this is how to implement inheritance in JavaScript.

Once Motocicleta inherits from Vehiculo , all objects created from the Motocicleta class they will also have access to the attributes of the Vehiculo class, this may sound complicated in words, so let's get on with the code.

  1. Create an object of type Motocicleta replacing the comment that says // Create the motorcycle here

 let miMotocicleta = new Motocicleta();

Review: Since the Motocicleta class inherits from the Vehiculo class, then the miMotocicleta object will have a color and a brand.

  1. Returns the color and make of the new motorcycle object, replacing the comment that says // Returns the color and make of the motorcycle.

 return "color: " + miMotocicleta.color + ", marca: " + miMotocicleta.marca;

  1. Click the run button.

Note that although the Motocicleta class does not have anything inside it, the object we create from it does contain the color attributes Y marca , that's the magic you get from working with inheritance.

Congratulations, you have completed this lesson, don't slow down.

super() method

When working with inheritance it is very common that we want to pass data from a child class to the parent class, especially when creating an object since said parent class surely also has a constructor method, for that we use the super() method which is already incorporated in JavaScript ready to use, then we will explain what its use is.

In the previous lesson we had two classes Vehiculo Y Motocicleta , this time you will see that they are already in the editor, it is time to create a Coche class which also inherits the Vehiculo class .

  1. Create a new class Coche that inherits from Vehiculo , to do so type the following replacing the comment that says // Create the Car class here

 class Coche extends Vehiculo { constructor(color, marca, numeroPuertas) { // Crea el metodo super() aquí this.numeroPuertas = numeroPuertas; } }

Note that numeroPuertas is the only attribute that belongs to the Coche class , the rest, color and marca , belong to the parent class.

  1. Pass the color and marca to the Vehiculo class using the super() method inside the constructor method, replace the comment that says // Create the super() method here

 super(color, marca);

What the super() method will do is go to the Vehiculo class and pass the attributes that it requires, in this case color Y marca .

  1. Create the cocheDeDylan object from the Coche class , place the comment // create Dylan's car here, and replace it with the following:

 let cocheDeDylan = new Coche('Negro', 'Toyota', 4);

The attributes passed to the car class are color , marca Y numeroPuertas respectively.

  1. Prints the cocheDeDylan object in console by replacing the comment that says // Print Dylan's car here in the principal() function.

 console.log(JSON.stringify(cocheDeDylan));

  1. Return cocheDeDylan 's car by replacing the comment that says // Return Dylan's car here :

     return cocheDeDylan;

  2. Click the run button.

In short, the super() method is used to send values to the parent class through a child class, so you can see that the cocheDeDylan object It has three attributes, one of them is its own and the other two are inherited.

Congratulations you have completed this lesson, do not slow down and let's continue with the next one.

Method Overriding

As its name indicates, method overriding is the action of rewriting what a method that belongs to a class does, generally methods that are inherited are overridden although it is not a strict rule.

The abstract form of this idea can be confusing if you're new to OOP but it's not particularly difficult, for example, if we all have the presentarse() method each of us can “overwrite” it to present ourselves in a different way, not easy. It is time to continue advancing with the exercise seen throughout this course, so let's move on to the code.

Note: Notice that in the editor the Vehiculo class has one more attribute from the last lesson, this is ruedas .

Since vehicles have attributes, it's time to give them the ability to move.

  1. Create a move method on the Vehicle class by replacing the comment that says // move method of the parent Vehicle class

 moverse() { return "Este vehículo de color " + this.color + " se desplaza en " + this.ruedas + " ruedas"; }

Note that the message returned by this method is very abstract, that is, it does not report what type of vehicle it is or anything with which we can identify whether it is a motorcycle, a car, a truck, etc.

  1. Override the move method in the Coche class replacing the comment that says // move method of child class Car

 moverse() { return "Este coche de color " + this.color + " se desplaza en " + this.ruedas + " ruedas"; }

Now notice that this new method of moving does imply that it is a car that is moving.

  1. Prints the move method of the miMotocicleta object replacing the comment that says // Print the move method of the myMotorbike object

 console.log(miMotocicleta.moverse());

  1. Click the run button.

In the console output you can see that the method we printed was that of the Vehicle class, that is, the message is "This red vehicle moves on 2 wheels"

  1. Now return the moverse() method of the cocheDeDylan object, replacing the comment that says // Returns the move method of the carOfDylan object

 return cocheDeDylan.moverse();

  1. Again click the run button.

This time you will notice that the method that was printed was that of the Coche class which contains the message “This Black car moves on 4 wheels” , just what we wanted.

You do very well, keep up the pace and let's continue with the next lesson.

Getters and Setters

The getters and setters are special methods that we use to obtain information from the attributes in a class or modify it, although its use is not a general rule, it is considered a good programming practice that is worth learning, since you can find its syntax in many places.

Before we start, notice that in the editor we have changed the names of the attributes of each class a bit, now they all start with an underscore, for example, _marca , this is what is usually done when working with getters and setters.

getters

Getters are the methods that are responsible for bringing the information stored in the attributes of a class.

  1. Create a getter method to get the color of a vehicle, to do this write the following replacing the comment that says // build the get method here located in the Vehiculo class

 get color() { return this._color }

Note that the way to create a getter is quite simple, we just type the keyword get followed by the name of the attribute that we want to obtain, without the underscore ( _ ) and inside its braces we return the actual attribute, which in this case is this._color .

  1. Locate in the principal() function and print the color of the miMotocicleta object, to do this type the following replacing the comment that says // Print the color of the motorcycle

 console.log(miMotocicleta.color);

  1. Click the run button.

Now notice that we've called the color() method we just created without using parentheses at the end of the name, this will output “Red” which is just what we needed.

setters

Setters are the methods used to modify the value of an attribute, for example, if the object miMotocicleta change color then we should use this method, its syntax is quite similar to that of getter methods, let's see it.

  1. Create a setter method to modify the color of the vehicles, to do this write the following replacing the comment that says // Build the set method here that is inside the Vehiculo class .

 set color(newColor) { this._color = newColor; }

This time we use the reserved word set followed by the name of the attribute to modify and in the parentheses will come the new color that the vehicle will have.

  1. Modify the color of the myMotorcycle object by replacing the comment that says // Modify the color of the motorcycle inside the principal() function.

 miMotocicleta.color = 'Negro';

Note that the new value for the attribute is defined using equals and not inside parentheses as would be done in a normal function.

  1. Returns the color of the miMotocicleta object replacing the comment that says // Returns the color of the motorcycle

 return miMotocicleta.color;

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see, the result on the console is "Black" , this means that we have effectively changed the color from "Red" to "Black" just what we expected.

Congratulations, you have completed this tutorial on inheritance in JavaScript, we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other courses that we have prepared for you. Remember to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✓ “check” button that appears in the upper right corner of the screen.

Become an expert

The world never stands still, and new technologies and disciplines emerge every moment to which we must adapt as best as possible to respond to the needs, challenges and opportunities that arise daily.

One of our duties as programmers is to keep ourselves constantly updated, this shows that you are a curious person and hungry for knowledge, so on this occasion we bring you a series of concepts, which, although they are not essential for programming, they make us more efficient .

Ternary operators.

A ternary operator in JavaScript is, in a few words, a contraction of the if and else , the main difference that we can find is that using this operator is much shorter, and in most cases it is more understandable.

A ternary operator looks like this, don't worry if you don't know what it says as we'll explain it later.

 condicion ? expresión1 : expresión2;

To better explain the concept, we are going to divide it into two parts, the long form and the short form. Let's start with the long form.

Using if and else

Imagine that you want to build a chair, for this the most basic thing you need is nails and wood.

  1. Create two variables that represent the existence of nails and wood, to do this replace the comment that says // Write your code here with the following:

 let hayClavos = true; let hayMadera = true;

Now we need a condition that tests if you have both materials available.

  1. Type the following under the variables you created earlier:

 if(hayClavos && hayMadera) { return "Puedo hacer la silla"; }else { return "No puedo hacer la silla"; }

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see in the test cases, the program returns the message “I can do the chair” , this is fine but nothing new, it is time to use the ternary operator.

Use of the ternary operator

  1. Click the restart button.

  2. Create the variables hayClavos and hayMadera .

     let hayClavos = true; let hayMadera = true;

  3. Type the following under those variables:

 return hayClavos && hayMadera ? "Puedo hacer la silla" : "No puedo hacer la silla";

Note that the way to use the ternary operator is through a condition that will evaluate to true or false , in this case that condition is ( there are hayClavos && hayMadera ), then the question mark ( ? ) followed by what it will do if the condition is true ( true ), finally a colon ( : ) is used and what will happen if the condition is false ( false ).

  1. Click the run button.

In the test cases, the same message that we got previously will appear, just what we need, but this time we use fewer lines of code to do the same task.

Congratulations now you know what the ternary operators are, let's move on to the next lesson.

switch statement

The switch statement is commonly used when working with chains that require more than one condition, the use of the switch statement replaces, on certain occasions, the if , else if Y else using simpler syntax.

Let's see how we can use the switch statement, for this we will create a program that returns the name of a month that corresponds to a number, example, if the number is 5 the program will return "May" , if it is 1 it will return "January" and so on.

Let's do it.

In the editor, you can see that the switchCase() function receives a parameter, this is mes and represents an integer, for example, 1, 6 or 12.

  1. Create the switch statement replacing the comment that says // Write your code here, to do this write the following in the editor:

 switch(mes) { // posibles casos }

Notice that we have entered the reserved word switch followed by parentheses and the variable that we want to compare, in this case mes , finally opening and closing braces {...} are used since, as you can imagine, this is a block of code.

  1. Create the possible cases, by using the case statement, type the following replacing the comment that says // possible cases

 case 1: return "Enero"; case 2: return "Febrero"; case 3: return "Marzo"; case 4: return "Abril";

Notice that we have a chain of cases, note that they all have the same syntax, for example, the first one says “ case 1: ” the second one says “ case 2: ” and so on, this is equivalent to writing the following:

 if(mes === 1) { // hacer algo }else if(mes === 2) { // hacer otra cosa }...

  1. Write the remaining 8 cases for the other months of the year, make sure that the name of the month starts with a capital letter as it can generate errors when qualifying the test cases.

  2. Click the run button.

Now you should be able to see how the expected result comes out in the test cases.

You do very well, do not slow down and let's continue with the next lesson.

Interpolation or template string

Interpolation or also known as template string, is a much shorter and more understandable form of concatenation than the one normally used with the plus sign + , this time we will see what its difference is in terms of syntax and most importantly, we will put into practice what learned by continuing with the example of the months seen in the previous lesson.

Syntax

The syntax used in the interpolation is quite simple since it is not necessary to divide the message into parts to join strings, let's see a comparison between the two ways of concatenating.

Conventional method:

 let numero = 5; console.log("El " + numero + " es un número");

Interpolation:

 let numero = 5; console.log(`El ${numero} es un número`);

The message that will be printed in the console for both examples is "5 is a number" , but note that the syntax used in the interpolation is much simpler and more understandable since, as stated above, we do not have to divide the message and use the + sign every time we need to join two parts.


How is it used?

To use interpolation, backticks or inverted quotes ( `...` ) are used and, where you want to replace a value, add a dollar sign plus opening and closing braces ${...} , inside said braces locates the value we want to concatenate.

Let's do it

Continuing with the months example, let's return a more appropriate message, such as “Month 1 is January” .

In the editor you will see a preview along with several lines that contain the following comment: // Message with interpolation, we are going to replace said comment with the message that we want to return.

  1. Replace the first comment with the following:

 `El mes ${mes} es enero`;

In this way we have concatenated the message plus the number stored in the mes variable .

  1. Replace the second comment with the following:

 `El mes ${mes} es febrero`;

  1. Replace the other comments with the suggested message, do not forget to change the name of the month corresponding to the number, note that the months this time are in lowercase.

  2. Click the run button.

Now you should be able to see how the test cases are painted in green color and the expected result comes out.

Very good, since you have mastered this part, let's move on to the next lesson where you will learn about arrow functions, see you there.

arrow functions

Arrow functions are another way to write functions but in a shorter way, for example, while a normal function looks like this:

 function nombreDeLaFuncion(argumentos) { // Cuerpo de la función }

An arrow function looks like this:

 (argumentos) => { /* Cuerpo de la función */ }

Arrow functions are also known as anonymous functions since they don't need a name as you can see from the example above.

Let's go to the code

This time we are going to create an arrow function that receives 2 numbers and adds them, storing its result in a variable.

  1. Create an arrow function and store it in a variable, to do this replace the comment that says // Create the arrow function here with the following:

 let sumar = (num1, num2) => num1 + num2;

As you can see this is much more summarized than writing:

 function sumar(num1, num2) {    resultado = num1 + num2;    return resultado; }


Tip: Notice that the arrow function in this case does not have a return statement. this is because the operation we are performing is very short, but if we wanted to use return it would be like this:

 let sumar = (num1, num2) => { return num1 + num2 }

  1. Call the function and pass its respective parameters, to do so replace the comment that says // Invoke the arrow function here with the following:

 sumar(num1, num2);

Notice that we have called this function with the same name as the variable created earlier.

  1. Return your result so that it can be validated, to do so replace or update the function call with the following:

 return sumar(num1, num2);

  1. Click the run button.

If you did it right you should be able to see that your result is the same as expected, it's time to move on.
You're almost there, let's move on to the last lesson where you will learn about the spread trader.

spread trader

The spread operator is something relatively recent added in ECMAScript 6 , its uses and functionalities are very broad, so we recommend you delve deeper into this concept ( click here to learn more ). This time we will see how to use the spread operator to join two lists, one of its most common uses in the daily life of programmers.

Note: ECMAScript is a standard or set of rules for development in the JavaScript language.

In the past, joining two lists was a long and cumbersome process, now obtaining the same result is much easier and in most cases it can be done in just one line of code.

Let's do it

Imagine that you are going to the supermarket and you have 2 separate lists, one for fruits and the other for vegetables, the best thing would be to join them into one for greater comfort, let's see how to do it in JavaScript code.

  1. Create two lists, one containing names of fruits and the other names of vegetables. Replace the comment that says // Write your code here with the following:

 let frutas = ['fresa', 'guayaba', 'manzana']; let verduras = ['pepino', 'lechuga', 'espinaca'];

  1. Create a third list by joining the previous two.

 let frutasYVerduras = [...frutas, ...verduras];

As you can see, the spread operator is nothing more than three points added before the name of a list or variable, in this case frutas and verduras , also note that the new result will also be a list since we have enclosed the operation with 2 square brackets. opening and closing [...] which, as you know, represent a list or array.

  1. Return your result as follows:

 return frutasYVerduras;

  1. Click the run button.

In the test cases you will be able to see how the result is precisely the union between both lists. Simple, isn't it?

Congratulations, you have finished this advanced JavaScript course, we invite you to continue learning with the other courses that we have prepared for you. Don't forget to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✔ "check" button in the top right corner of your screen.

Challenge: Prime Numbers

Welcome to this intermediate level JavaScript challenge where you will have the opportunity to test yourself and demonstrate your knowledge.

How to proceed?

  1. In the editor on the right you will find a code snippet like the following:

 function numeroPrimo(numero) { // Escribe tu solución aquí }

  1. As you can see the numeroPrimo() function receives one parameter, this is numero which represents the test cases that will be applied to your solution.

  2. The mentioned numero parameter contains any number that may or may not be prime, for example, 5 or 24.

  3. Analyze the statement of the exercise and try to solve it

Statement: Create an algorithm that, given a number x , returns true if that number is prime or false otherwise.

Examples:

  1. If the number is 3 the program will return true .

  2. If the number is 8 the program will return false .

Get to work and good luck ;-)

Challenge: ascending order

Welcome to this advanced level JavaScript challenge where you will have the opportunity to test yourself and demonstrate your knowledge.

How to proceed?

The code you see in the editor has bugs that prevent it from working properly. Do you think you can find them?

What the program does is return an ordered list from one that may not be, for example, if the list is [5, 1, 4] the program will return [1, 4, 5] .

Bonus: Once you finish you can try to improve the proposed algorithm so that it gives the same result. How would you do it? Don't hesitate to try.

Get to work and good luck ;-)
