topics.name: Introduction to Vue JS (Variables and Directives)

lessons.text:
Introduction to VueJS

Vue JS is a Javascript -based work tool that helps us to develop quickly and is very easy to learn, it allows us to easily interact with HTML elements. Follow the steps:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor, replacing the text <!-- My first Vue code --> and hit the Run button:

 <h1>Texto normal</h1> <!-- Mi primera interpolación -->

  1. Now copy and paste the following content into your Javascript editor and hit the Run button:

 const app = new Vue({ el: "#root", // No borres ni modifiques esta línea data() { return { texto: "Texto desde Vue" } } })

In the first line we initialize Vue and then we indicate certain properties, the first is the el property, which indicates where we can access with Vue from. Then we have a data property, which basically helps us to access the variables that we will use all the time, in this case we have a texto variable.

How do we access Vue variables from HTML?

It's really simple, to achieve this we'll use something called interpolación , where we simply use two curly braces like {{ texto }} .

  1. Write the following code, replacing the text <!-- My first interpolation --> from your HTML editor:

 {{ texto }} <!-- Interpolación -->

By pressing the Run button you will see that the Vue variable is already visible from the HTML , it almost seems like magic. With this you have written your first lines in Vue JS , see you in the next lesson.

Variables in Vue

As we saw in the previous lesson, variables within Vue are defined in the data block which is always written as follows:

 data() { return { variable: "valor" } }

Note that it is declared as a function (because of the parentheses), it always requires a return , and the variables are part of an objeto (similar to a JSON element).

Copy and paste the following code replacing the text // My first variables in Vue of your Javascript editor and hit the Run button:

 texto: "Texto desde Vue", fecha: new Date().toLocaleString(), arreglo: [1, 2, 3, 4], objeto: { curso: "Vue JS", autor: "PeakU" }

As you can see we have just printed all the Vue variables in our HTML , we display text, more complex content like dates, arrays and objects, you can also see in line 17 of the HTML editor that we can execute Javascript directly from the HTML

With this we conclude the lesson of variables, see you in the next one.

directives

In Vue we have the possibility to interact in a very simple way with the HTML code, one of the most powerful ways is through directives, which basically can interact with a specific element, the most used directives are: v-if , v-else , v-show , v-for , v-model and v-bind . As you can see, they all start with v- indicating that they come from Vue .

Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor replacing the text <!-- My first directives --> and press the Run button:

 <p v-if="texto === 'hola'"> Se cumple la condición del v-if </p> <p v-else> No se cumple el v-if, mostramos el v-else </p> <p v-show="texto2 === 'saludo'"> Se cumple la condición del v-show </p>

We can notice that all the directives are declared within the opening HTML . Try changing the values in your Javascript editor so that the content changes (remember to hit the run button).

Let's see what each directive does:

  • v-if: It allows us to delete or create an element from scratch, so when inspecting the code the element will never exist.

  • v-else: works like a Javascript else , basically it returns an element if the v-if condition is not met (it must always be after a v-if).

  • v-show: It is similar to v-if , since it allows to hide an interface element, but it does not remove it from the document, so if we inspect the code the element will always exist, basically a CSS display: none or display:block depending on the case.

We have concluded this lesson, in the next one we will look at the v-for directive.

v-for directive

It is very common to use ciclos or bucles to repeat blocks of code in arrays , in Vue we can perform cycles in a very simple way directly from the HTML code, we achieve this thanks to the v-for directive that we had mentioned in the previous lesson.

  1. Copy and paste the following code, replacing the text <!-- My first v-for --> from your HTML editor.

 <li v-for="numero in numeros" :key="numero"> {{ numero }} </li>

Note: The iterated element is always required to have a unique key , to avoid problems when rendering (displaying on the frontend).

As you can see, we just printed our entire list of numbers by writing just one line of code, v-for is very useful when you need to display many records in the frontend with the same layout.

Sometimes our arrays don't have unique values, so we shouldn't use the same value as key , an alternative can be to use the índice element (position of the element within the array), let's edit a bit what we wrote above.

  1. Replace the code we wrote in the previous step of your HTML with the following and press the Run button:

 <li v-for="(numero, indice) in numerosRepetidos" :key="indice"> {{ indice }} - {{ numero }} </li>

As you can see, there are repeated numbers in our Array , however we can see that its index is unique and this way Vue will not throw us any errors.

See you next time.

v-model directive

This directive is one of the most used when working with Vue and specifically with text fields ( inputs ), since it allows us to write a value in an input and at the same time fill a variable with that new value, let's see it.

  1. Copy and paste the code into your HTML editor replacing the text <!-- My first v-model --> and then hit the Run button:

 <input id="input-id" type="text" v-model="texto"> <br> Texto escrito: {{ texto }}

Now when you write any text inside the input you will see that it is also reflected in the lower part, this is thanks to the fact that the v-model automatically assigns the value of the input to the text variable, we call this action reactivity and it is one of Vue 's strongest points.

Note: The v-modelo can be used in text input tags like input , select , and textarea .

v-bind directive

Basically the v-bind allows us to assign native HTML attributes but with values that come from Vue variables, let's see the following example.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor, replacing the line with the text <!-- my first v-bind --> .

 <img v-bind:src="urlImagen">

As you can see, we assign the src attribute, which is typical of the <img> , and we put one of our variables as a value, it is a very frequent use when developing a web application.

Note: there is a shorter way to do a v-bind and that is to simply write from the colon, see the example:

 <img :src="urlImagen">

You can use this directive to dynamically assign almost any attribute of a tag, for example you can assign a value to an input with :value , assign classes with :class and you can even perform validations like in this example:

  1. Replace your code with another:

 <img :src="urlImagen" :class="fondoRojo ? 'fondo-rojo' : 'sin-fondo'">

  1. Change the value of the redBackground variable from false to true

Can you see how you can turn the red background on and off by changing the redBackground boolean from JS?

With this we conclude the lesson, if you have reached this point you will soon be an expert in Vue .

topics.name: Methods, events, life cycle and components

lessons.text:
Methods

In Vue we can use functions similar to how we do in Javascript , the difference is that we must write them in a new block called methods , which means methods.

Copy and paste the following code replacing the comment // My first method in Vue into your Javascript editor and hit the Run button.

 methods: {
 invertirTexto() {
 return this.texto.split('').reverse().join('')
 }
}

On the screen of Your result you should see how first the value of the texto variable is printed and then when calling the invertirTexto() method, what it returns is printed, that is, the text in reverse.

Note: Whenever you are going to use a variable or a method from the Javascript section, it is necessary to put this first, since it is the way in which Vue locates its own values.

In the methods you can do operations with a lot of complexity and the idea is that most of the logic goes at this point and very little in the HTML . With this we conclude the lesson.

events

When we work on web development, it is very common to execute actions after an interaction of the end user, such as writing some text or clicking a button, we call these actions eventos , which are normally processed in Javascript by means of Listeners , however, Vue has its own way of listening and processing them, let's see how to do it:

Copy and paste the code into your HTML editor, replacing the line <!-- My first event in Vue -->:

 <h1>{{ texto }}</h1>
<button @click="invertirTexto()">Invertir</button>

Through the @click shortcut we listen to the click event of the button, likewise you can listen to native HTML events such as @input or @change , within the event we must always execute some action, in this case we call a method (the same one we saw in the previous lesson).

Try clicking the Invest button and you will see how our event works, really simple, see you next time.

Note : @click="" can also be written as v-on:click="" , the way we showed you above is a shortcut that allows us to save time and length in the code.

Let's review a little

Let's see a practical example of the summary of the concepts that we have taught, follow the steps:

  1. Copy and paste the following code, replacing the text <!-- Summary of concepts --> in your HTML editor:

     <h2>Lista de tareas</h2>

<input type="search" placeholder="Escribe y presiona enter para crear" v-model="nuevaTarea" @keyup.enter="agregarTarea()"> 
<!-- Escuchamos el evento keyup, específicamente cuando el usuario presiona la tecla Enter -->

<ul>
 <li v-for="(tarea, indice) in tareas" :key="indice">
 {{ tarea }} <button @click="eliminarTarea(indice)">×</button>
 </li>
</ul>

  2. Copy and paste the following code replacing the text // Summary of concepts in your Javascript editor and press the Run button:

     data() {
 return {
 nuevaTarea: null, // Podemos inicializar las variables en null
 tareas: [
 "Regar las plantas",
 "Hacer las compras"
 ]
 }
 },
 methods: {
 agregarTarea() {
 // Agregamos la tarea al array de tareas existente
 this.tareas.push(this.nuevaTarea)
 
 // Al agregar limpiamos el input para seguir agregando contenido
 this.nuevaTarea = null
 },
 eliminarTarea(indiceTarea) {
 // Encontramos el índice de la tarea seleccionada y con splice la eliminamos
 this.tareas.splice(indiceTarea, 1)
 }
 }

    Note: The @keyup.enter event, with which we basically listen to Javascript 's keyup event, allows us to listen when a key is pressed, the .enter lets us identify that the key pressed was enter.

    With this we have created a basic application to register and delete tasks, getting closer to a more real example of web development.

    Until next time!

Lifecycle

A very interesting part of Vue is the life cycle, which allows us to execute actions before displaying a page, when it is displayed and before leaving it, these moments are very useful to call methods without affecting the loading time of our web application, among other uses, let's see an example:

Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor replacing the text // Lifecycle in Vue and hit the Run button:

 beforeCreate() {
 console.log("BEFORE CREATE", "SE VA A CREAR LA PÁGINA")
 },
 created() {
 console.log("CREATED", "SE CREÓ LA PÁGINA")
 },
 beforeMount() {
 console.log("BEFORE MOUNT", "SE VA A MONTAR LA PÁGINA, PUEDES EJECUTAR MÉTODOS ACÁ")
 },
 mounted() {
 console.log("MOUNTED", "SE MONTÓ LA PÁGINA, PUEDES EJECUTAR MÉTODOS ACÁ")
 },
 beforeDestroy() {
 console.log("BEFORE DESTROY", "VAS A SALIR DE LA PÁGINA")
 },
 destroyed() {
 console.log("DESTROYED", "SALISTE DE LA PÁGINA O RECARGASTE")
 }

We have just executed all the life cycles, click at the bottom of Your result , on the Console button, there you will see the result of all the console.log and their order of execution.

Let's look at a bit about each lifecycle method:

  • beforeCreate : Indicates that the page is going to be mounted, here we can make requests to APIs or external servers to start collecting information, however it cannot access variables or methods.

  • created : Similar to the previous one, only certain values already exist in memory, however variables and methods cannot be accessed yet.

  • beforeMount : From this point variables and methods can already be accessed, it is also used to make API calls.

  • mounted : At this point the page has already been rendered, that is, it is already visible to the end user, here we can execute methods that interact with interface elements.

  • beforeDestroy : Typically used to remove Listeners created for the current page, and also to call methods that typically remove information that is no longer needed.

  • destroyed : Indicates that the page has already been deleted and was probably redirected to another route or the same view was reloaded.

With this explanation we close today's lesson.

Components

It is common that when developing a web platform we repeat many blocks of similar code in different project files, to save time and have a more organized code, the componentes were created, which basically can contain HTML , CSS and Javascript code, this is written only one once and used as many times as we want, without having to rewrite everything. Follow the steps:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor replacing the text // My first component and hit the Run button.

 Vue.component('item-tarea', { // Creamos un componente con nombre item-tarea
 props: ['texto'], // Aquí se recibirá el dato desde el elemento padre
 template: `<li>
 {{ texto }} <!-- Imprimimos la propiedad -->
 <button>×<button>
 </li>`
})

We create a new component named item-tarea that contains several configurations, the first one is props , we can consider this name as a variable that will be filled from wherever we call the component, we will see it in more detail later. Additionally, in the template we put HTML elements that we will constantly repeat and where we print values that come from the props . Let's continue.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor replacing the text <!-- My first component --> and hit the Run button.

     <ol>
 <!-- Para utilizar el componente lo llamamos como si fuera una etiqueta -->
 <item-tarea :texto="tarea" v-for="(tarea, indice) in tareas" :key="indice"></item-tarea>
<ol>

    As you can see, when calling the component we do it as if it were an HTML tag ( <item-tarea> ), additionally we are indicating a value to the texto property, which we create in the component as a prop , that is, the component will be able to access to the value we send from where it was created.

Note: You can create as many props as you want in the component, although it is not highly recommended. Additionally, the component can contain its own methods, variables, and lifecycle, all as you require.

We finished a very important lesson and one of the most fundamental bases of Vue, see you in the next one.

product letter

Welcome to this entry-level Vue challenge.

Your job will be to replicate the example provided in the "Expected result" tab, run your code as many times as you need and when you think it's ready, click the submit button to check your results.

Don't be afraid to fail, you can try until you succeed, good luck.

emoji list

Welcome to this entry-level Vue challenge.

Your job will be to replicate the example provided in the “expected result” tab, run your code as many times as you need and when you think it's ready, click the submit button to check your results.

Don't be afraid to fail, you can try until you succeed, good luck.

Filters in Vue

A filter in Vue is a function to be executed before painting a data in a view, that is, they are normally used to format data and style it.

Imagine that you have a number and you want to assign the points of the tens, hundreds and thousands to make it look like an amount of money, we are going to see how to do it through a filter, follow the steps.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor, replacing the line <!-- Applying a filter in Vue --> :

     {{ numero | convertirADinero }}

    As you can see, the way to call a filter is using a slash ( | in English is pipe) and then we put the name of the filter, without sending more arguments.

  2. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the line // My first filter in Vue :

     filters: {
 convertirADinero(value) {
 // Utilizamos Intl.NumberFormat, que es una función nativa de Javascript
 return new Intl.NumberFormat("es-CO", { style: "currency", "currency":"COP" }).format(value);
 }
}

  3. Hit the Run button.

The result obtained should take the raw number we had initially and give it a new currency format, in this case we decided to convert it to Colombian Pesos (COP), but you can edit the example to take any other currency such as USD.

Note: It is possible to apply several filters to the same value, you simply have to put more bars and call the filters, which will be applied in the order in which you put them, example: {{ numero | primerFiltro | segundoFiltro }} .

Filters are very useful in Vue and save a lot of time, this concludes the lesson.

Watch Method

On many occasions we want to execute an action when a variable changes its value, for example, show what the previous value was and what the new value is, let's see how it would be done using the watch method.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text // My first watch :

 watch: {
 numero(nuevoValor, valorAnterior) {
 console.log("Valor anterior: ", valorAnterior)
 console.log("Nuevo valor: ", nuevoValor)
 }
}

  1. Hit the Run button.

  2. Now go to the Your result tab and press the Increase button, this action will increase the value by 1 every time you touch the button.

  3. At the bottom of the Your Output tab, click the Console button to see the console.log that prints when you change the value.

As you can see, the watch method automatically returns the previous value and the new value , analyze this data and perform operations within the keys, for example it is useful to assign or change values of other variables and it is even valid to call methods, it all depends on what what you want to do

Note that the watch is always called with the same variable name, that is, if your variable is called texto , in the watch it must be called as texto(nuevoValor, valorAnterior) .

Until next time.

Computed Properties

When working in web development it is normal that there are times when we want to be observing the changes of certain variables or values and execute calculations immediately, imagine that you go to a supermarket and for each product that passes through the payment band the total value to pay is increasing, we can easily achieve this sum with a computed property. Follow the steps to reproduce the example.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor, replacing the text <!-- Product Listing --> :

     <table>
 <thead>
 <th>Producto</th>
 <th>Precio</th>
 </thead>
 <tbody>
 <tr v-for="producto in listaProductos" :key="producto.id">
 <td>{{ producto.nombre }}</td>
 <td>
 $<input type="number" v-model.number="producto.precio">
 </td>
 </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>
<h4> {{ total }} </h4> <!-- Aquí mostramos el total -->

    We have just created a table with two columns: Product and Price, the latter is inside an input , so we can edit it as we please, here we review concepts such as v-for and v-model .

  2. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text // My first computed :

     computed: {
 total() {
 let suma = 0;
 this.listaProductos.forEach(producto => { // Recorremos el listado de productos
 suma += producto.precio; // Sumamos el precio definido
 })
 return suma;
 }
},

  3. Hit the Run button.

  4. Change the prices of the products to see how the computed property is updated.

Computed properties have an interesting feature, which is that they are always recalculated when they detect a change in the HTML , this is very useful when we need to perform operations. In this case, what we do is iterate the array of products, take the price of each one and add them, then to show the result, we just need to print the total variable in the HTML , which, as you can see, we do not need to define in the data section.

NOTE: It is important that you notice that in our input we put a v-model.number so that it is respected that the new value will be of a numeric type.

With this we advance further on the path of Vue, encourage yourself to continue with the course.

Entry and exit transitions

In Vue we can apply transition effects when elements are inserted, updated or removed from the document. We can achieve this with the transition component, which allows us to add entry and exit transitions for any element or component in the following contexts:

  • Conditional rendering (using v-if )

  • Conditional display (using v-show )

Let's see how it is used:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor, replacing the text <!-- My first transition --> :

     <button @click="mostrarTexto = !mostrarTexto"> <!-- Cambiamos el valor de mostrarTexto por su opuesto al dar clic -->
 Mostrar/Ocultar
</button>

<transition name="fade">
 <h6 v-if="mostrarTexto">Transición</h6>
</transition>

    When we want an element to have a transition, we place it inside the <transition> tags, we must also indicate the name of a transition created from CSS , in this case it is fade .

  2. Copy and paste the following code into your CSS editor, replacing the text */ Transition from CSS */ :

     .fade-enter-active, .fade-leave-active {
 transition: opacity .5s
}
.fade-enter, .fade-leave-to {
 opacity: 0
}

    In this CSS code we will basically animate the opacity of the element for 0.5 seconds, i.e. half a second.

  3. Hit the Run button.

  4. Play around with the Show/Hide button to see how the transition behaves.

    There are four classes applied for input/output transitions.

    • enter : Initial state for input. Applied before the element is inserted, removed after one frame.

    • enter-active : Active and completion state for input. Applied before the element is inserted, it is removed when the animation/transition ends.

    • leave : Initial state for exit. Applied when the exit transition is activated, it is removed after one frame.

    • leave-to : Active and ending state for exit. Applied when exit transition is activated, removed when animation/transition ends.

    It is necessary to respect the names of these class names since it depends on it that Vue manages to animate correctly.

What Vue does internally is to analyze if the element contains the CSS classes and if not, it adds them, each transition is a switch between the input classes ( enter ) and the output classes ( leave ).

Transitions are very useful when you want to show or hide elements without the interface jumping abruptly and you can use multiple CSS effects, let your imagination run wild, that's what programming is all about.

Transition groups

In the previous lesson we saw the entry and exit transitions, however they only work for one element at a time, so it is not so optimal when we have multiple elements to which we want to apply these transitions, for this the component transition-group , let's see how it works.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HML editor, replacing the text <!-- My first group of transitions --> :

     <transition-group name="list">
 <span v-for="numero in numeros" :key="numero" class="list-item">
 {{ numero }}
 </span>
</transition-group>

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your CSS editor, replacing the /* Transitions group */ text:

     .list-item {
 display: inline-block;
 margin-right: 10px;
}
.list-enter-active, .list-leave-active {
 transition: all 1s;
}
.list-enter, .list-leave-to {
 opacity: 0;
 transform: translateY(30px);
}

  2. Hit the Run button:

  3. Play with the Add and Remove buttons to see the in and out transitions animate for the entire group of elements.

Note: For group transitions to work correctly, elements within <transition-group> tags must have a unique key .

With this we conclude this lesson and you already understand very well how transition animations are managed from Vue , see you in the next one.

Main Navigation

For this point we assume that you already have basic knowledge of HTML regarding the initial structure of a web page, in this lesson we will replicate the same structure, but using Vue components.

Normally a simple page is made up of a main menu that contains a nav or navigation bar, a main that contains all the main content (articles, blog entries, etc.) and a footer with information that sometimes indicates the author of the page. o useful links to visit; sometimes it can be complemented with an aside that would function as a banner for information of common interest on the website. These spaces can hold very variable and sometimes extensive data, so separating each one into a component helps us to have a more organized project and make it easier to read.

We will style all the components with Bootstrap version 5.2 , we will start with the header .

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text // MainNavComponent :

 Vue.component('nav-principal', { props: ['enlaces'], template: `<div> <!-- Debemos tener todo el contenido dentro de un único elemento padre --> <header> <nav class="navbar bg-primary"> <div class="container-fluid"> <!-- Este botón se encarga de abrir el menú --> <button type="button" class="btn btn-light" aria-label="Mostrar/Ocultar menú" data-bs-toggle="offcanvas" data-bs-target="#menu" aria-controls="menu"> <span class="navbar-toggler-icon"></span> </button> <!-- Nombre de tu sitio web --> <a class="navbar-brand text-light" href="#">Navbar</a> </div> </nav> </header> <!-- Aquí va nuestro menú --> </div>` })

  1. Hit the Run button.

You will see that a blue upper bar was painted on the interface, that is our nav , this contains the name of our website and a button that will help us open the menu that we will design in the next step, you will also see several classes, these Bootstrap offers them so that we have styles quickly.

The name of the page is usually inside an <a> tag (anchor or link) since clicking on it usually redirects to the main page. We are going to create the menu, it is going to be displayed from the side, as if it were a mobile app.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text <!-- Our menu goes here --> :

     <div class="offcanvas offcanvas-start" tabindex="-1" id="menu" aria-labelledby="menuVertical"> <div class="offcanvas-header"> <h5 class="offcanvas-title" id="menuVertical">Menú lateral</h5> <button type="button" class="btn-close" data-bs-dismiss="offcanvas" aria-label="Cerrar"></button> </div> <div class="offcanvas-body"> <ul class="navbar-nav justify-content-end flex-grow-1 pe-3"> <li class="nav-item" v-for="(enlace, indice) in enlaces" :key="indice"> <a class="nav-link" aria-current="page" href="#">{{ enlace }}</a> </li> </ul> </div> </div>

This menu contains the offcanvas class, this belongs to Bootstrap and is used to create an element that appears in the interface from the side, perfect for our use case.

Within this new content there is a v-for of the links or elements that we will show in the menu, we receive these as properties from the HTML , since they could change dynamically.

With this we finish our main navigation, we will continue advancing in the next lessons.

main content

In the previous lesson we managed to finish the navigation of our project, one of the most important aspects of a website, however, it would be useless if we do not have content to show, which is of interest to the end user, in this example we will show articles of interest in programming.

We need to create a container for the articles, this is usually done as a <main> tag, after that we will create a publicacion component which will have all the content inside, we will put only a short text to exemplify, let's start:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the // Post Component text:

     Vue.component('publicacion', { props: ['contenido'], template: `<div class="card mb-2"> <div class="card-body"> <h6 class="card-title">{{ contenido.titulo }}</h6> <div class="mb-2 text-muted">{{ contenido.autor }}</div> <p class="card-text">{{ contenido.texto }}</p> <a href="#" class="card-link">Ver más</a> </div> </div>` })

  2. Hit the Run button.

    This component will show a summary of the article and will allow you to click on it to redirect to a page where you can read all the text, the information necessary to paint the component is passed through the contenido property, from where we get the id, title, author and text.

    Think that if for example we have 100 posts, it would be a very slow process to copy and paste the same HTML for each article, while this component together with a v-for saves us a lot of work and allows us to keep a very clean code.

    Note : All the classes we use are provided by Bootstrap and you can find them if you read their documentation at getbootstrap.com .

Footer

A footer or <footer> typically serves us to display information about the author of the site, copyright data or links to related pages that would be of interest to the end user. In our case we only want to show the copyright, however, it is almost a standard to put social networks and contact forms there.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text // Footer Component :

 Vue.component('pie-pagina', { template: `<footer class="fixed-bottom"> <nav class="navbar bg-secondary"> <div class="container text-white"> PeakU 2022 </div> </nav> </footer>` })

  1. Hit the Run button.

We have just created a footer that will allow us to share final information with those who visit our page, feel free to use it as you prefer, one point to note is that we use a Bootstrap class called fixed-bottom that will help us keep the footer always in the bottom of the screen.

With this finished the component and the lesson, see you in the next one.

Final score

Throughout the previous lessons we saw how to structure three main components of a web page, the navigation or main menu, the content and the footer, from these we can implement many internal components, such as buttons, cards, comment boxes, voting , etc.

Let's integrate everything we did in the previous lessons:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your HTML editor, replacing the text <!-- HTML Components --> :

     <nav-principal :enlaces="enlaces"></nav-principal> <main class="container"> <publicacion :contenido="publicacion" v-for="publicacion in publicaciones" :key="publicacion.id"></publicacion> </main> <pie-pagina></pie-pagina>

  2. Hit the Run button.

  3. Check the content of your Javascript editor, there we have already put the components and variables necessary for the code you just wrote to work.

We did it! We just put all the components together and managed to make a mini web page that works, we made use of the concept of componentes , props , v-for , variables and some HTML structure issues, it was a very basic example, you can add even more complexity to the exercise , the idea is that you learn to program with components so that your code has very good quality.

We have finished this lesson. We hope that you have learned a lot throughout this course, encourage yourself to continue learning for yourself and improve your skills.

move the robot

topics.name: Set, Delete, forceUpdate and nextTick method

lessons.text:
Set method

So far we have worked by reading data from variables, but there are cases where we want to add elements or properties to objects dynamically, when we add a new property Vue is not able to react to this change, since the value did not exist when the object was created , to force Vue to recognize and be reactive to the change it is necessary to make use of the set method, which basically makes the new property reactive.

Let's see a practical example:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor replacing the text // Alternative 1 and hit the Run button:

     this.libro.autor = "Gabriel García Marquez";
console.log(this.libro) // Imprimimos en consola el resultado

  2. Now press the Add Author button Did it work?

  3. We put a console.log to see what it should look like go to the Console button at the bottom, the libro object should print with the property we just added, but... Why doesn't the Content screen print like this? As we mentioned at the beginning, if this property does not exist at the time of mounting the page, Vue will not be able to see or print it.

  4. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor replacing the text // Alternative 2 and hit the Run button:

     this.$set(this.libro, "autor", "Gabriel García Marquez")
// Los argumentos que recibe set son: objetoInicial, nuevaPropiedad, nuevoValor en su orden respectivo.

  5. Press the Add Author button 2 Does it work? Let's move on to the explanation.

The second method works because Vue designed the $set to make new properties reactive so you can see them from the HTML . This trick can save us a headache in the future.

Delete method

Just as there is a method to add properties to an object, we also have a method to remove them, since natively Vue cannot listen to a delete primitive on an object.

Let's look at an example very similar to the previous lesson:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor replacing the text // Alternative 1 and hit the Run button:

     delete this.libro.autor
console.log(this.libro) // Imprimimos en consola el resultado

  2. Now hit the Remove Author button. Did it work?

  3. We put a console.log to see how it should look, press the Console button at the bottom, the libro object should print without the property we just deleted, but... Why is the Content screen the same as before? Something similar to the previous lesson happens, if at the moment of mounting the page the property exists, Vue will not be able to see that it was removed with the traditional Javascript way.

  4. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor replacing the text // Alternative 2 and hit the Run button:

     this.$delete(this.libro, "autor")
// Los argumentos que recibe set son: objetoInicial, propiedadAEliminar en su orden respectivo.

  5. Press the Remove author button 2 Does it work? Let's move on to the explanation.

The second method works because Vue designed $delete to be able to react to deleted properties of an object so you can see them from the HTML .

$forceUpdate method

In the previous two lessons we saw that we can use Vue 's own methods when we create or remove properties to reactive objects, however this is not the only option that exists, we can also use the $forceUpdate method to force Vue to recognize the changes that we make. perform on that object, let's see in more detail.

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text // Force add author :

     this.libro.autor = "Gabriel García Marquez"; // Forma tradicional
this.$forceUpdate()

  2. Hit Run and then hit the Add Author button, it should work fine.

  3. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text // Forcefully remove author :

     delete this.libro.autor; // Forma tradicional
this.$forceUpdate()

  4. Hit Run and then hit the Remove Author button, it should remove the author with no problem.

Let's understand a little how this alternative works.

With the methods that we have just used, both the add and delete were done in the traditional way, however after each alternative we use a this.$forceUpdate method, this internally forces a new rendering of the page, that is, it reassembles it from scratch, which directly causes the objects to be recreated and remain as reagents with the new properties.

Note: Try to use this method very little since it is seen as a bad practice and as an alternative there are the methods that we already mentioned in the previous lessons.

$nextTick() method

This is one of the more abstract concepts Vue has and it's rare to have to use it, so it exists for cases where other alternatives don't work. Imagine that you have a number and a button that calls a method to increase the value one by one, even if we assign the new value, it is not effective immediately, but takes a few thousandths of a second to be ready, the nextTick allows us wait that time and execute an action only when we are sure that the change was made, let's do the same example:

  1. Copy and paste the following code into your Javascript editor, replacing the text // My first nextTick :

     this.$nextTick(() => {
 // En este punto estamos seguros de que el valor fue actualizado exitosamente.
 console.log("El numero fue incrementado")
})

  2. Hit the Run button.

  3. Press the Increment button to call the method in charge of doing the addition.

  4. Open the Console of Your result so that you can visualize the console.log() that we propose.

As you can see in the example the nextTick simply allows us to execute some action when Vue confirms that it updated the variable (or the DOM) successfully, it is unlikely that you should use it, but it is better to know the concept.

fill the glass

Welcome to this advanced level Vue challenge.

Your job will be to replicate the example provided in the expected result tab, in the HTML and CSS editors you will already be able to see a preview, modify them only if you consider it necessary in your solution.

Although you can add and remove almost anything, make sure you do NOT remove the "fill" and "empty" IDs as they are needed for the BOT to check your solution.

Tip: Click the "run BOT" button to find out what the program does.

Don't be afraid to fail, you can try until you succeed, good luck.

Welcome to the beginner level React tutorial!

The objective of this tutorial is to give you an introduction to this wonderful framework, here you will learn step by step and from scratch the most important concepts of React.

Suggestions: Knowing the main technologies for Front-End development (HTML, CSS, JS) is a plus that will help you advance faster.

Let's learn how to use our interface.

How to Proceed: Each exercise has two text editors at the top (JSX, Css) and 2 screens on the right “your result”, “expected result”.

The goal is that when you run the code the result is the same as expected to get the highest rating. Let's do it!

Let's write our first "Hello world"

Hit the “send code” button at the top, and you'll get an approximate 80-91% rating, let's improve it.

  • Click on the JSX editor and on line 10 add the following code:

     <p>My first Hello world! :D</p>

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations you have completed your first hello world in React, keep it up :)

What is JSX?

JSX is a JavaScript extension created by Facebook, it is used to transform React code to pure JavaScript.

Advantages:

  1. Better code organization.

  2. Open source with the support of a great community.

  3. Ensures faster rendering (Hot Reloading).

We continue with the tutorial:

  1. Press the “Run Code” button at the top, and you can see that we need the text, let's create it.

  2. In the JSX editor on line 10 replace with this code.

     <p className="learn-react-beginner">Learn React beginner :D</p>

    What this does is create the text of "Learn React beginner :D" without styles, now we are going to add its styles.

  3. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  4. In the CSS editor on line 25 replace with this code.

     .learn-react-beginner { background: black; color: #fff; }

    What this does is add the black background to that text and change the color of the text to white.

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Come on, you're making progress!

Create HTML structures in React

Let's create our first HTML structure inside the components.

Don't worry if you don't understand what a componente is, you'll learn that later.

Hint : HTML is the way to structure the interface of our application. Example: the plans of a building.

Let's build a basic HTML structure:

Add the following code snippets in the React editor:

  1. Replace the comment in {/*añade tu encabezado acá*/} with the following code:

     <div className="bg-black text-white mini-container"> <h2>Learn React beginner :D</h2> </div>

    This will create the Header of your application

  2. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  3. Now that you've added the header let's create the main content, replace the {/*añade tu contenido principal acá*/} comment with the following code:

     <div className="all-content"> <p className="learn-react-beginner" id="myText">Learn React beginner :D</p> <button className="btn btn-success" id="submit-btn">Change color</button> </div>

    This will create the main content that is the text and the button.

  4. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  5. Now that you've added the main content let's create the "footer", replace the comment of {/*añade tu pie de pagina acá*/} with the following code:

     <div className="bg-black text-white mini-container"></div>

    This will create the footer of the application.

  6. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  7. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Come on, you're making progress!

Note: To use HTML classes in REACT we will use the word className since the word class is used to create class components.

Comparison between HTML and REACT classes:

HTML: <p class="my-first-class">this is my text</p>

REACT: <p className="my-first-class">this is my text</p>

Create CSS styles in React

We are going to learn how to create styles in our applications in REACT.

Tip: It is recommended to know about basic CSS

Let's style our app:

Add the following code snippets in the CSS editor:

  1. Hit the “Run Code” button at the top, and you can see the example without CSS.

  2. Replace the /*añade los estilos de tu pie de página acá*/ comment with the following code:

     .mini-container { height: 10vh; width: 100vw; display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: center; align-items: center; }

    What this does is add the black background and size of the footer of our application.

  3. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  4. Now that you've added the footer styles, let's style the header text, replace the {/*añade los estilos de tu contenido principal acá*/} comment with the following code:

     .mini-container h2 { margin: 0; font-size: calc(1rem + 1vw); }

    This will center the text in the Header.

  5. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  6. Now that you've added the styles for the header text, let's style the main content, replace the {/*añade los otros estilos de tu contenido principal acá*/} comment with the following code:

     .all-content { height: 80vh; width: 100vw; padding: 0; margin: 0; display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: center; align-items: center; }

    What this does is give it a fixed size and center the elements, to all the "main content" that is text and button.

  7. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  8. Now that you've added the styles to the main content, let's style its text, replace the {/*añade los estilos de tu encabezado acá*/} comment with the following code:

     .learn-react-beginner { background: black; color: #fff; }

    This will make the text background black and change the text color to white.

  9. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  10. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Come on, you're making progress!

Note: Don't worry if you don't understand what a componente is, you'll learn that later.

We continue!

We have handled HTML and CSS, now we are going to see JS(JavaScript) in REACT.

The JS code is written inside the componente, but outside the return as you can see in this example:

 const App = () => { const myEvent = () => { console.log('show the browser console') } return ( <div> <p>hello</p> </div> ); };

Let's build a JS event:

Add the following code snippets in the React editor:

  1. Hit the “Run Bot” button at the top, and you can see the interaction of our exercise :D.

  2. On line 4 replace with this JS code:

     const myEvent = () => { document.getElementById('myText').style.background='#FF0000 '; }

    What this does is create a JavaScript event, with which we are going to change the background color of our main text to red.

  3. Now that you've added the event for the button, let's create the text that will change its background color to red, replace the {/*añade tu texto acá*/} comment with the following code:

     <p className="learn-react-beginner" id="myText">Learn React beginner :D</p>

    What this will do is create the text of our main content.

  4. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  5. Now that you've added the main content text, let's create the button that will change the background color of the text, replace the {/*añade tu botón acá*/} comment with the following code:

     <button className="btn btn-success" id="submit-btn" onClick={myEvent}>Change color</button>

  6. Now Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you will see the change.

  7. Now Press the “Run Bot” button at the top, and you will see the interaction.

  8. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Come on, you're making progress!

Note: Don't worry if you don't understand what a componente is, you'll learn that later.

Congratulations, you have reached the end of the course!

Based on the "expected result" screen

  1. Press the “Run Bot” button at the top, and you will be able to see the interaction of our exercise and how it should look.

  2. Create the html structure of the example as you did in previous exercises.

  3. Create the app styles in the CSS editor.

  4. create JS(JavaScript) event for button interaction

Welcome to the class components in React tutorial!

The objective of this tutorial is to give you an introduction to this concept, you will see how to create and use the class components in this framework.

Suggestions: Know the main technologies for Front-End development (HTML, CSS, JS) and have finished the React tutorial for beginners.

Let's learn how to use our interface.

How to Proceed: Each exercise has two text editors at the top (JSX, Css) and 2 screens on the right “your result”, “expected result”.

The goal is that when you run the code the result is the same as expected to get the highest rating. Let's do it!

We continue where we left off!

In the previous exercise you had to replicate yourself a small React app with just HTML, CSS and JavaScript in a single component, in these classes we are going to look at creating, manipulating and communicating between components and other React basics.

Below you will see a small example of your previous exercise but using the componentization logic that is the "use and reuse of components".

Let's start the exercise:

  1. Hit the “Run Bot” button at the top, and you can see the interaction of our exercise using componentization :D.

Add the following instructions in the React editor

  1. On line 2 replace the // add your code here comment with the following code:

     const MyComponent = ({buttonEvent}) => { return ( <React.Fragment> <p className="learn-react-beginner" id="myText">Learn React Basic :D</p> <button className="btn btn-success" id="submit-btn" onClick={buttonEvent}>Change color</button> </React.Fragment> ) }

  2. Replace the comment in {/*add your component here*/} with this code:

     <MyComponent buttonEvent={myEvent}/>

  3. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  4. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note: Don't worry if you don't understand what a componente is, you'll learn that later.

Congratulations go to the next level!

What is a component?

They are blocks of code that allow the user interface to be separated into independent pieces, in more descriptive terms taking as an example a construction of a car, the components are the body of the car and the code that goes inside the component is the operation of that car.

Advantages:

  1. Code reuse.

  2. Organization of your projects (Clean code).

  3. Ensures faster rendering (Hot Reloading).

Have a look at the code in the JSX editor and you will see how an application is built with the use of components.

  • Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  • Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note: In the following classes we will learn how to create and use components.

Let's go to the next class!

Class Component

As its name says it is a component based on classes as in JS (JavaScript).

If you are curious here you can see the JS classes ES6 class.

This is how to create a class component in React:

 class MyComponent extends React.Component { render() { return ( <h1>Hello, World</h1> ) } }

As you can see in the example, to create this component we use the following steps:

  • Create the name of your class component:

    You do this by initializing the class and naming that class class MyComponent .

  • Convert the class to a React component:

    To convert it to a class component you extends React.component all together it would look like this:

     class MyComponent extends React.component { }

    and this is a class component

  • And as we saw in the previous course in the " HTML in REACT" class, if you want to include HTML elements in the component that we just created, you will have to use the word render() and open and close brackets, inside the brackets del render() you are going to add the return with your HTML elements that you have already seen in the previous course. This would look like this:

     class MyComponent extends React.component { render() { return ( <h1>Hello, World</h1> ); } }

    And in this way you created a class component.

We continue!

Let's create an application using class components:

Add the following code snippets in the React editor:

  1. On line 3 Replace the // añade tu componente acá comment with the following code:

     class MyComponent extends React.Component { render() { return ( <React.Fragment> <p className="learn-react-beginner" id="myText">Class component in React</p> </React.Fragment> ) } }

    With this we will create the component of the main content, that is, the one of the phrase of Class component in React

  2. Replace the comment in {/*llama a tu componente acá*/} with the following code:

     <MyComponent/>

  3. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  4. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note : Component names always start with capital letters.

Functional Components

As its name says, it is a component based on JS (JavaScript) functions.

This is how to create a functional component in React:

 const MyComponent = () => { return ( <h1>Hello, World</h1> ); }

Let's create it!

To create that component we use the following steps:

  • Create the name of your component:

    You do this by starting const MyComponent = .

  • Now to convert it to a functional component what you do is start the function as follows:

     () => { }

    and joining it with the previous step looks like this:

     const MyComponent = () => { }

  • And as we saw in the beginner's course in the " HTML in REACT" class, if you want to include html elements in the component we just created, you'll have to use the return() keyword. This would look like this:

     const MyComponent = () => { return ( <h1>Hello, World</h1> ); }

    And in this way you created a functional component.

We continue!

Let's create an application using functional components:

Add the following code snippets in the React editor:

  1. On line 3 Replace the // añade tu componente acá comment with the following code:

     const MyComponent = () => { return ( <React.Fragment> <p className="learn-react-beginner" id="myText">Function component in React</p> </React.Fragment> ); }

    With this we will create the component of the main content, that is, the one of the phrase of Function component in React

  2. Replace the comment in {/*llama a tu componente acá*/} with the following code:

     <MyComponent/>

  3. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  4. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note : Component names always start with uppercase, since if they are written with lowercase they would become JS functions.

Welcome to the Component Communication in React tutorial!

The goal of this tutorial is to give you an introduction to the basic way of how to send data between components. to create even more advanced and complex applications with React. By the end of this tutorial you will be able to create a React app that uses these features.

Suggestions: Know the main technologies for Front-End development (HTML, CSS, JS) and have finished the React tutorial for beginners.

Let's learn how to use our interface.

How to Proceed: Each exercise has two text editors at the top (JSX, Css) and 2 screens on the right “your result”, “expected result”.

The goal is that when you run the code the result is the same as expected to get the highest rating. Let's do it!

Add the following instructions in the JSX editor

  1. Replace the // añade a tu componente TextContent aquí with the following code:

     const TextContent = (props) => { const changeColor = () => { document.getElementById('myText').style.background='#000'; } return ( <React.Fragment> <p className="content-text" id="myText">Hello {props.name}</p> </React.Fragment> ) }

  2. Replace the comment for {/*llama a tu componente TextContent aquí*/} with this code:

     <TextContent name={'Juan'}/>

  3. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  4. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations go to the next level!

What is the communication between components for?

Communication between components is an essential and necessary feature in large projects, so frameworks look for solutions to make it friendly. In the case of React we have to use props that we use to pass information from a parent component to a child component.

Advantages:

  1. Returns the most dynamic component.

  2. Send or receive information.

  3. Freedom to the user.

Before seeing the use of props we will learn to understand the logic of "Parent to son"

Take a look at the following code:

 const TextContent = (props) => { ===>>>ESTE ES EL HIJO DE MainContent<<<=== return ( <React.Fragment> <p className="content-text" id="myText">Hello</p> </React.Fragment> ) } const MainContent = () => { // ===>>>ESTE ES EL PADRE DE TextContent<<<=== return ( <React.Fragment> <div className="all-content"> <TextContent/> //visualización del contenido del hijo </div> </React.Fragment> ) }

You see how MainContent calls its child which is TextContent , this is how the "Parent to Child" logic is handled in componentization.

Add the following instructions in the JSX editor

  1. Replace the // añade a tu componente TextContent aquí with the following code:

     const TextContent = (props) => { // ===>>>ESTE ES EL HIJO MainContent<<<=== return ( <React.Fragment> <p className="content-text text-white text-center" id="myText">Mi papa me envió un mensaje y es:</p> <p className="content-text-2 text-white" id="myText">{props.text}</p> </React.Fragment> ) }

  2. Replace the comment for {/*llama a tu componente TextContent aquí*/} with this code:

     <TextContent text={'Hola Hijo'}/>

  3. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  4. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note: In the previous exercise we saw that the parent component is MainContent which if we see it by color is all white content, while the child is the chat messages.

Let's go to the next class!

What are props and how to use them?

They are arguments (variables) that is "values" that you pass to your components in React.

For example : <MyComponent name={'Juan'}/> where name is the property(props) that is sent and its value is Juan .

Props in class components in React:

Props in class components are done as follows:

  1. Send the message to the component you want to communicate with:

     class MainContent extends React.Component { render() { return ( <TextContent text={'este es el texto que le voy a enviar a mi componente hijo'}/> ) } }

    in our case the text of 'este es el texto que le voy a enviar a mi componente hijo' , is what we will send to the TextContent component, this will be sent to it as a text variable.

  2. Read the data they send us:

     class MainContent extends React.Component { render() { return ( <h1>{this.props.text}</h1> ) } }

    We are using this.props to access that text variable that they send us and to be able to visualize the data in an html h1 tag.

    And this is how to use props in a class component.

We continue!

Let's create an application using class components:

Add the following code snippets in the JSX editor:

  1. Replace the comment for {/*llama a tu componente aquí*/} with the following code:

     <TextContent text={'Este es mi primer prop en componentes de clase'}/>

    As you can see you are sending the TextContent component a property called text

  2. Add the following code inside the <p> tag that is inside the TextContent component:

     {this.props.text}

    with this we will read the data that has been sent to us.

  3. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  4. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note: the props are read-only, this means that the props are not modifiable

Let's go to the next class!

Props in Functional components in React:

Props in functional components are done as follows:

  1. Send the message to the component you want to communicate with:

     const MainContent = () => { return ( <TextContent text={'Comunicación entre componentes funcionales'}/> ) }

    in our case the text of 'este es el texto que le voy a enviar a mi componente hijo' , is what we will send to the TextContent component, this will be sent to it as a text variable.

    As you can see in comparison to class components nothing changes, both are sent in the same way.

  2. Read the data they send us:

     const MainContent = (props) => { return ( <h1>{props.text}</h1> ) }

    In this case, the functional components will be passed the props as a parameter: (props) => {} .

    once they are received as a parameter there we can read them as in our example which is: props.text in which case text is the information that is coming to us.

    And this is how to use props in a class component.

We continue!

Let's create an application using class components:

Add the following code snippets in the JSX editor:

  1. Hit the “run code” button at the top, and you can see the difference between “your result” and “expected result”.

  2. Replace the comment in {/*llama a tu componente acá*/} with the following code:

     <TextContent text={'Este es mi primer prop en componentes funcionales'}/>

    As you can see you are sending the TextContent component a property called text

  3. Add the following code to the parameters of the TextContent component function:

     props

    it should look like this const TextContent = (props) => {}

  4. Add the following code inside the <p> tag that is inside the TextContent component:

     {props.text}

    with this we will read the data that has been sent to us.

  5. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  6. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Note: the props are read-only, this means that the props are not modifiable

Curiosities :

If you already have good knowledge of JavaScript, you could use the destructuring props.

example:

  1. Send the message to the component you want to communicate with:

     const MainContent = () => { return ( <TextContent text={'Comunicación entre componentes funcionales'}/> ) }

  2. Read the data they send us:

     const MainContent = ({text}) => { return ( <h1>{text}</h1> ) }

    How you see use destructuring to get the text property: ({text}) => {} directly without using the props.text .

Let's go to the next class!

Welcome to the Paths in React tutorial!

The goal of this tutorial is to give you an introduction to the basic way of creating a routing mechanism in your application. This will help us build even more advanced and complex apps in React. By the end of this tutorial you will be able to create a React app that uses these features.

Requirements

This theoretical-practical mini-course assumes basic knowledge of JavaScript and React, therefore, it is important:

  • Be familiar with React components (Previously seen).

  • Know the main technologies for Front-End development (HTML, CSS, JS)

  • Have completed previous React courses.

ReactRouter

As you already know, React allows us to create SPA (Single Page Application), that is, to show several views within the same page.

React Router helps us to have navigation between pages, a specific URL for a view or just go back/forward in the browsing history.

React Router has three packages:

  • react-router

  • react-router-native

  • react-router-dom

In this course we will only use react-router-dom to create routes, manipulate history and generate nested routes, the goal is that by the end of this article you will be able to generate routes in a React project.

Tips : The version we are using of react-router-dom is version 5.

What is react-router?

React Router is the most popular library for managing routes in a React project, it has three essential components:

  • <BrowserRouter/> → Connects our application to the browser's URL, i.e. keeps the user interface in sync with the browser's URL using the HTML5 History API.

  • <switch/> → Generates a tree of routes and from this allows us to replace the view with the component that matches the URL of our navigation bar and it will render only that component.

  • <Route/> → Represents a route in the tree, you need at least the following path and component properties, to represent a route.

Let's create our first routes component

We will only create it but in the following classes we will see in detail what each thing does.

  • Press the “run Bot” button at the top and you can see what the application that we are going to build looks like .

Add the following instructions in the JSX editor

  1. In the comment of // crea tu componente de rutas aquí you are going to create a component called MyRoutes:

  2. Inside the return you are going to add the following code.

     <React.Fragment> <Switch> <Route exact path="/" component={HomePage} /> <Route exact path="/page-2" component={WelcomeToSecondPage} /> </Switch> </React.Fragment>

  3. Replace the comment for {/*llama a tu componente MyRoutes aquí*/} with this code:

     <MyRoutes/>

  4. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  5. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations go to the next level!

switch component

It is a component whose function is to generate a route tree. this helps us to be able to visualize the routes of our navigation bar and it will only render the component associated to said URL.

In case we do not use Switch , all the routes that meet the condition will be rendered.

In more descriptive terms, it is like a route wrapper whose function is to display only the component of said URL.

When we start adding multiple routes, we will notice something strange.

Let's say we have one route for the "home" page, another for "page-2" and one more for the "about" page. Although we specify different paths, that is '/', 'page-2' and '/about' , when I visit the " page-2" or "about" page, we will see the content of the "home" component and the their respective component.

  • Hit the “run Bot” button at the top, and look at the “Your Result” view and you will be able to see the example we just read a little better .

We can fix this with the exact property, on the home route to make sure our router exactly matches the '/' route instead of '/about':

 <Route exact path="/" component={HomePage} />

But we don't just want that, we're going to do it with the Switch component.

Let's learn to use Switch.

The switch component must be included inside the Router or BrowserRouter component and we can put all our routes inside it.

Example with BrowserRouter:

 import { BrowserRouter, Switch, Route } = ReactRouterDOM; const App = () => { return ( <React.Fragment> <BrowserRouter> <Switch> <Route exact path="/" component={Home} /> <Route path="/about" component={About} /> </Switch> </BrowserRouter> </React.Fragment> ); }

Example with Router

 import { BrowserRouter, Switch, Route } = ReactRouterDOM; const App = () => { return ( <React.Fragment> <Router> <Switch> <Route exact path="/" component={Home} /> <Route path="/about" component={About} /> </Switch> </Router> </React.Fragment> ); }

In our case you won't have to use BrowserRouter , Router . Since we do that internally, you will only include Switch .

Add the following instructions in the JSX editor

  1. In the MyRoutes component, enclose the <Route /> tags with the Switch component:

    base on this example:

     const YourComponent = () => { return ( <React.Fragment> <Switch> <Route exact path="/" component={ComponentHome} /> <Route path="/about" component={ComponentAbout} /> </Switch> <React.Fragment> ); }

  2. Add inside each <Route> the exact property:

    base on this example:

     <Route exact **othersParams**/>

  3. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  4. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations go to the next level!

Route Component

This component helps us to define the different routes of our application. The function of this component is to choose what to render according to the current location. This is the case we saw earlier, all Route components always render, but sometimes they render a component and sometimes they return null .

This component receives the following properties:

  • path : the path on which the component will be rendered as a text string

  • exact : a boolean to define whether or not we want the path to be exact to render a component.

  • component : receives a component to render. Create a new React element each time. This causes the component to mount and unmount every time (does not update).

How to create a route in our application?

It is very simple we will only call the Route component with the basic parameters that are path and component .

Example:

 <Route path="/index" component={ComponentForIndexView}/>

PS: The raíz path of any application is written only with a slash(/) like this: "/" .

Let's create our routes:

Add the following instructions in the JSX editor

  1. Press the “run Bot” button at the top, and look at the “Expected Result” view and you will be able to see the example we are going to do a little better .

  2. In the comment of // crea tu componente de rutas aquí you are going to create a component called MyRoutes :

  3. Inside the return create the route system with Switch as you saw in the last class.

    example view:

     <Switch> {/*....acá van tus rutas....*/} </Switch>

  4. Inside the Switch create the following routes:

    1. Create a Route component, its path will be the raíz route and it will render the HomePage component

    2. Create a Route component, its path will be the route of page-2 and it will render the WelcomeToSecondPage.

    3. Create a Route component, its path will be the route of page-3 and it will render the WelcomeToThirdPage.

      With this you are creating the views of your application.

    4. Add the exact property to each of your routes.

  5. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  6. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations go to the next level!

Link Component

We have already configured our routes, but you have not yet seen how it is to navigate in our application.

Link creates a hyperlink that allows us to navigate our application.

Receive the following properties:

  • to : a location in the form of a text string. This will be the location we navigate to when we click on a hyperlink.

  • replace : a boolean that allows us to modify the behavior of Link. When this is true instead of adding a new location to the story, it replaces the current location.

But we are only going to focus on the to property.

Example:

 <nav> <Link to="/">Home</Link> <Link to="/about">About</Link> </nav>

In react instead of using the HTML hyperlinks(<a>) tag we will use Link .

How to create a hyperlink with Link?

It's very simple all you have to do is call the Link component like any HTML tag and add the to property and the path address and inside the tag you can name the hyperlink whatever you want.

This would look like this:

 <Link to="/tu-ruta">Home</Link>

Let's create our hyperlinks with Link:

Let's build on the previous example.

Add the following instructions in the JSX editor

  1. Press the “run Bot” button at the top, and look at the “Expected Result” view and you will be able to see the example we are going to do a little better .

  2. In the WelcomeToTheFirstPage component in the comment of {/*crea tus hipervínculos aquí*/} you are going to add the following code:

     <ul> <li></li> <li></li> </ul>

  3. In this HTML list we just created, you're going to create the following hyperlinks within the <li> tags with the Link component:

    1. In the first <li> tag you are going to add the following code:

       <Link id="go-to-second-page" className="text-dark" aria-current="page" to="/page-2">page-2</Link>

      with this you will create the hyperlink to page-2.

    2. In the second <li> tag you are going to add the following code:

       <Link id="go-to-third-page" className="text-dark" aria-current="page" to="/page-3">page-3</Link>

      with this you will create the hyperlink to page-3.

  4. In the WelcomeToTheSecondPage component you are going to replace the {/*crea tu hipervínculo aquí*/} comment with the following code:

     <Link id="go-to-home" className="text-dark list-unstyled" aria-current="page" to="/">anterior</Link>

    What this does is create a hyperlink to be able to return us to the main view of our app.

  5. Repeat the previous step in the WelcomeToTheThirdPage component.

  6. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  7. Hit the “run Bot” button at the top, and compare the behavior of "Your Result" with "Expected Result" (both have to behave the same) .

  8. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations go to the next level!

Route 404

If we try to go to a route that doesn't exist in our application, what will we see?

We're not going to see anything if we don't have a corresponding route. How do we make a global route?

If a user tries to go to a page for which we don't have a route defined, we can create a route and then set the route with an asterisk *:

 <Route path="*" component={NotFound} />

This will match any attempt to visit a page that doesn't exist and we can hook it up to a not found component to tell our users that they have "Arrived at a page that doesn't exist".

Hint : The HTTP code 404 Not Found or HTTP 404 Not Found, is an HTTP status code that indicates that it has not been possible to find the resource you are requesting.

Let's create our 404(NotFound) view:

Add the following instructions in the JSX editor

  1. Press the “run Bot” button at the top, and look at the “Expected Result” view and you will be able to see the example we are going to do a little better .

  3. Inside the return of that component you are going to add the following code:

     <div className="all-content"> <h1 className="content-text-2 text-white text-center p-2" style={{'font-size': '16px'}}>No se encontró esta ruta :(</h1> </div>

  4. In the MyRoutes component you are going to replace the comment of {/*crea tu ruta NotFound aquí*/} with the following code:

     <Route path="*" component={NotFound} />

    What this does is that when it doesn't find any route it creates a display to the NotFound component.

  5. Hit the “execute code” button at the top, the result should be the same as the “expected result” tab.

  6. Hit the “run Bot” button at the top, and compare the behavior of "Your Result" with "Expected Result" (both have to behave the same) .

  7. Hit the “send code” button at the top, the result you will get is 100%.

Congratulations!

Variables

Variables are memory spaces that allow us to store data values. Imagine them as boxes to which you assign a name and inside you can save the information you want. Every time you need to access that information, you just need to check the box with the name you gave it. Simple, right? Let's see how it works in code.

In Python, there are no commands to declare variables as they can appear in other languages. You just need to write the name of the variable, which is how we will identify the memory space that contains the information, followed by the equal sign = and finally the value we want to save. Let's do it:

  1. Write the following in the code editor, replacing the text that says # Write your code here. Remember to check that you have four spaces at the beginning.

greet = "Hello world!"

As you can see, we have defined the variable with the name greet and through the symbol = we have assigned the value “Hello world!”. From this moment on, every time we use the word greet in the code editor, Python will go to the memory of the program and bring us the value that we have stored.

Great! Now you know how to declare variables. Now to finish, do the following:

  1. Click at the end of the line where you declared the variable, press the Enter key and write the following in the code editor. Again, make sure you have four spaces at the beginning of the line.

return greet

The word return is part of the functions theme and in this case it is only to validate the test cases. Don't worry if you don't understand it; when we see the functions we will analyze it in more detail. However, notice that we use our variable greet so, when running the code, the program will go to the memory and send the value of the variable to the test case. Let's do it:

  1. Over the code editor you have a button that says Run. Click on it to evaluate your code. If it is correct, the test case will be displayed in green and its result will be the same as the expected result. If not, check that the variable is correctly written both in the declaration and in the return and try again. Anyway, in the next two lessons I will leave you some possible errors that you can make. You can always review them and return to execute the exercise correctly.
