Basic Operators: Comparison

Comparison Operators

As the name implies, they are used to perform comparisons between two values ​​of the same data type. The final result will be a boolean value True or False .

Let's see which we have:

  • < strong>Equals, represented by the symbol ==. The result is True if the values ​​are equal. Otherwise the result is False

  • Not equal to, represented by the symbol !=. The result is True if the values ​​are different. If they are equal, the result is False

  • Greater than, represented by the symbol >. The result is True if the value to the left of the symbol is strictly greater than the value to the right. Otherwise, False is returned.

  • Greater than or equal to, represented by the symbol >=< /code>. The result is True if the value to the left of the symbol is greater than or equal to the value to the right. Otherwise, False is returned.

  • Less than, represented by the < symbol . The result is True if the value to the left of the symbol is strictly greater than the value to the right. Otherwise it returns False.

  • Less than or equal to, represented by the symbol <=. The result is True if the value to the left of the symbol is greater than or equal to the value to the right. Otherwise it returns False.

We can compare numbers the same way we do in mathematics, indicating whether a number is greater , less than or equal to another. Also, something interesting is that the comparison between strings is done in alphabetical order when we use the greater and lesser operators, but it is not used much, unlike equals and not equals , which are used a lot in strings.

Let's see it in code.

  1. Declare the following variables and add the following operations of example replacing in line with comment # Write your comparison operations here

equal = 15 == 15 # True
equal_string = "Hello" == "Hello" # True
not_equal = 12 != 30 # True
not_equal_string = "Hello" != "Hello" # False
greater_than = 10 > 8 # True
greater_or_equal_than = 12 >= 12 # True
less_than = 1 < 8 # True
less_or_equal_than = 12 <= 11 # False

Remember that it is very important that operations are performed between variables of the same type and that the result will always be a value boolean.

  1. End the code with return at the end of your variables to evaluate in the test case.

    2. < /ol>
    return equal, equal_string, not_equal, not_equal_string, greater_than, greater_or_equal_than, less_than, less_or_equal_than

    Great! You already know the basic operators in Python. In the next lesson you will see a simple but very important concept in everyday business: string concatenation. I'll wait for you there!

Concatenation in python

Concatenation is a basic but powerful topic. It can be used for various purposes. The idea is to join values ​​to give more detailed information about something. We will use the + operator and you may be wondering why it is the same for addition. The reason is that in this case the operation occurs between data of type string and therefore, instead of adding, it joins the texts in a single string. Great isn't it? That's how powerful programming languages ​​are.

Let's do it

  1. Write the following variable replacing the line with the comment # Write your code here

language = 'Python'

  1. Create the following variable just below the previous one:

greet = 'Hi, I'm ' + language + "," + " your best friend forever"

Notice we used double quotes < code>"" and single quotes '' to write the strings. As I mentioned before, in python both representations for declaring a string are valid, as long as it respects its opening and closing.

  1. Finally, return your variable .

return greet

Now you know how to concatenate strings and you will realize in the world of work how important it is to can become this tool.

Introduction to basic Python tutorial, part 2

Welcome to the second part of the basic python tutorial. On this occasion you will learn about logical operators, truth tables and how this will help us to give decision power to our programs through conditionals. Without further ado, let's begin.

Logical Operators and Truth Tables

Remembering what we saw in the previous course, in comparison operators we saw that the result of a comparison is always a boolean value True or False . However, these boolean values can also be operated to give more robustness (and one could say more intelligence) to the programs you develop. Let's see then the logical operators .

There are three:

  • and → The result will be True if all statements are True , otherwise if any of the statements is False , the result will be False .

  • or → The result will be True if at least one of the statements is True . Only if all statements are False will the result be False .

  • not → Inverts the value of the declaration. If the value is True , it returns False and vice versa.

Let's see how they are used in the code editor:

  1. Write the following variables replacing on the line that says # Escribe tu código aquí

 and_operator_1 = True and True # True and_operator_2 = True and False # False and_operator_3 = False and False # False

Note that the only True response is given in the variable and_operator_1 when both variables are True .

  1. Write the following variables below the ones you already wrote

 or_operator_1 = True or True # True or_operator_2 = True or False # True or_operator_3 = False or False # False

Here notice that the only False response is given in the or_operator_3 variable when both variables are False .

  1. Write the following variables below

 not_operator_1 = not True # False not_operator_2 = not False # True

This is more intuitive since the operator inverts the input value.

  1. End your code by returning the variables.

 return and_operator_1, and_operator_2, and_operator_3, or_operator_1, or_operator_2, or_operator_3, not_operator_1, not_operator_2

Understanding them is vital to give life to our programs and that is why in the following lessons we will extend these operators with some examples to make it very clear for you. I wait for you there!

NOT logical operator

The truth table of the NOT operator is quite simple:

 | A | Result | | True  | False | | False | True |

As you saw earlier, this operator is quite intuitive. It inverts the value of the variable A .

Let's look at an example:

  1. Create the following variables to evaluate the first case by replacing on the line with the comment # Write your code here

 house_clean = False clean_house = not house_clean == True # True

Imagine you will have guests at home in a couple of hours. Clearly, it is good to have the house well arranged, so you check the house_clean variable to know what state it is in, and you realize that it is False . If you perform the not operation, the result in the clean_house variable will be True ; it's time to clean up.

Notice that the not operator is placed before the variable we are negating not house_clean

  1. Return the variable

 return clean_house

Congratulations! You now understand how logical operators work. In the next lesson you will learn one of the key concepts in development: the IF conditional. See you there!

The IF conditional

One of the milestones we seek in programming is to automate certain processes. For this reason, it is important that programs have decision-making power while they are running, and for this we have conditional statements.

As you saw earlier, we use the comparison and logical operators as indicators to know what action to take. However, at no time did we explicitly tell the program the steps to follow according to the result of the operation. This is where the IF statement becomes important.

Let's see its syntax and how it works in an example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor replacing on the line that says # Escribe tu código aquí

 edad_paul = 21 if edad_paul >= 18: return 'Ya es mayor de edad'

Several things are happening in this code:

First we define the variable edad_paul by assigning it an integer. Then we put the if keyword followed, in this case, by the comparison operation edad_paul >= 18 and end the line with a colon : indicating the start of a block of code. This second line can be read as "If paul's age is greater than 18 do the following:". We leave four more spaces and place the return 'Ya es mayor de edad'

Important! Always after the colon, in any functionality (conditional, loop, function, etc), the next line of code must have an additional indentation of four spaces. The indentation represents a block of code and each new line must have the same indentation indicating that it is grouped within the same block of code. In other programming languages like JavaScript or C, this block of code is done by grouping the statements in curly braces {} .

Finally we could interpret the entire conditional as: "If Paul's age is greater than or equal to 18, it indicates that he is of legal age".

Note that the result of the if operation is a Boolean, but it can also be a Boolean operation, a directly Boolean value, or a combination of operations.

Very well! This is the first level and the most basic way to use an if . In the next lesson we will increase the decision power of our programs. I see you there!

The conditional IF - ELIF - ELSE

We have already seen how to use the IF and ELSE keywords to perform an action based on a condition. However, what if we have more than two possibilities? For this we have the ELIF keyword, which stands for "ELse IF". This allows us to add additional conditions to our program, increasing its decision-making power.

Let's see how it works in an example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor replacing on the line that says # Escribe tu código aquí

if numero_de_personas == 0: return 'No hay nadie en casa' elif numero_de_personas == 1: return 'Hay una persona en casa' else: return 'Hay más de una persona en casa'

In this case, we are using the numero_de_personas variable as a parameter of the function. We check if the number of people in the house is equal to 0, in which case we return the string 'No hay nadie en casa' . If not, we check if the number of people is equal to 1, in which case we return the string 'Hay una persona en casa' . If neither of these conditions are met, we use the else keyword to return the string 'Hay más de una persona en casa' .

Note that we can chain as many elif statements as we want, each with its own condition. However, we can only use one else statement at the end of the chain, and it will be executed if none of the previous conditions are met.

Excellent! Now you know how to use the IF, ELIF, and ELSE keywords to add decision-making power to your programs. In the next lesson you will learn about loops, which allow you to execute a block of code multiple times. I'll see you there!

The IF-ELIF-ELSE conditional

It is very common to find in programming the need to evaluate more than two paths when making a decision. It is in this case that the use of the ELIF keyword is very useful. Its operation is a combination between an else and an if, that is, if the previous condition is not true, we evaluate a new condition. And if this is not true either, we can continue evaluating as many conditions as we need. In the end, we can use the else statement if no condition is met, although it is not mandatory.

Let's see how it works in an example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor, replacing the line that says # Write your code here

if edad >= 0 and edad <= 5: stage = 'early childhood' elif edad > 5 and edad <= 11: stage = 'childhood' elif edad > 11 and edad <= 18: stage = 'adolescence' elif edad > 18 and edad <= 26: stage = 'youth' elif edad > 26 and edad <= 59: stage = 'adulthood' elif edad > 59: stage = 'old age' else: return 'Are you sure you were born yet?' return 'You are now in the ' + stage + ' stage of life'

In this example, we assess what stage of life you are in. We start with the if statement, evaluating that you are between 0 and 5 years old. We then place an elif as the age increases. Now, no matter what rank we're in, within each block of code we store the stage of life we're in. Finally, to control negative numbers, we put an else

Excellent! You already know how to use conditionals to give ample decision power and complexity to your programs. In the next lesson, we will do an exercise with what we have already learned throughout the course. I'll see you there!

Print and Comments in Python

We welcome you to this module of the course. This time we will review some concepts that will be very useful in your day to day life. Let's start.

As a developer, you will need to place some notes within the code to, for example, explain a functionality or document a function and for this we use comments. In fact, you already know the most basic one, which is the one-line comment, which starts with the # symbol as you can see in the code editor. Anything you write in front of the symbol will not be taken into account during the execution of the program.

 # Soy un comentario de una línea

However, when you want to make multi-line comments, it can become difficult to place the symbol so many times. So in this case we use the triple quote """ """

 """ Soy un comentario de varias líneas """

In general, you will find this structure at the beginning of the functions or classes with the explanation of what it does, information on the parameters it receives, the data that we are going to return if we do so, among other types of information.

Well, with this clear, let's see another very useful topic in your learning: Console messages.

So far, every time we execute our code, we see that in the test cases the execution result is displayed but the "Console output" field is always empty. As such, it is a field that allows us to display messages in certain areas of the code, and in fact, especially when we are learning, it is very useful to evaluate what we are doing. To do this, we place the word print and between parentheses we place the message we want to display. Generally it is a string but it can also be a variable whose value we want to know.

 print("Hola, estoy en salida de consola.")

Look at the example we have in the editor.

  1. Click run and review the console output at the end of the test case.

As you can see, the string that we put between the parentheses is displayed and, connecting the topic of comments, the latter are skipped during the execution of the program.

They may be basic concepts but they will really be very useful to you on a day-to-day basis. In the next lesson we will see more interesting concepts. I wait for you there!

Handling variables in Strings

Generally when we send a message in a string either to the console or to the frontend of an application, we also want to send the value or result of a variable. You already saw a way to do it by concatenating with the + symbol, however, sometimes when reading it it can become unreadable, not to mention that you can only concatenate with variables of type string, so you must change the type of variable as you saw it in the previous modules. That is why I will show you other options to achieve the same result.

The first way is using the format method . Do the following:

  1. Write the following code replacing in the comment that says # Escribe el primer ejemplo aquí:

 nombre_1 = "Josue" edad = 24 print("Su nombre es {} y tiene {} años".format(nombre_1, edad))

In this case, we are sending two variables to the string in the format method: nombre and edad . When executing the code, these variables will go into each brace pair {} in the order they were placed inside the method. The important thing is that the number of keys is the same as the number of variables, otherwise it will show you an IndexError error. But what if we want to display them in a specific order? Do the following example:

  1. Write the following code replacing in the comment that says # Escribe el segundo ejemplo aquí:

 pais = "Italia" nombre_2 = "Camilo" numero_paises = 30 print("{2} ha conocido {0} países pero su favorito es {1} por su comida".format(numero_paises, pais, nombre_2))

Here we are altering the order of the variables when displaying the message, taking into account the position in which they are found in the format method. Important! In Python, and in programming in general, the positions start counting from zero (we will see it in detail when we see the subject of lists), so the positions would be like this:

numero_paises → posicion 0

país → posicion 1

nombre_2 → posicion 2

With this clear, we only have to add the number of the position of the variable inside the braces where we want it to be displayed. Here the important thing is that there is a variable in the number of the position that we are indicating. That is, for the example, we cannot place the number {3} in the string since it would show us an IndexError error because there is no variable in position 3 within the method.

Very well, however there is another way of handling variables that may be even easier to interpret. I explain with the following example:

  1. Write the following code in the comment that says # Escribe el tercer ejemplo aquí:

 ciudad = 'Madrid' numero_dias = 20 print(f'Hoy tengo el viaje a {ciudad} y estaré {numero_dias} dias por fuera de casa')

In this way, all you have to do is place the letter f at the beginning of the string and between braces {} you place the name of the variable. Much better, right?

Excellent! You now know how to send messages more effectively without losing readability in your code. In the next lesson we will continue to see more interesting concepts. I see you there!

Nested conditionals

In the previous lesson we saw many things related to conditionals, however, there is an outstanding concept that is very useful when programming. Nested conditionals (and nested blocks in general).

What if we wanted to evaluate an if conditional inside another if conditional? Well, that's what it's all about when we talk about nesting in programming, that is, being able to put statements inside other statements (If you've seen the movie Inception, you'll see that it's a similar analogy). Let's see how it works:

  1. Write the following example on the line # Escribe tu código aquí

 tengo_vacaciones = True if tengo_vacaciones: vuelo_comprado = False if vuelo_comprado: print('¡Nos vamos de vacaciones!') else: print('Debo comprar el vuelo hoy mismo') else: dias_faltantes = 8 if dias_faltantes <= 10: print('Debería buscar un vuelo para mis proximas vacaciones')

As you can see, it is possible to use an if inside another if , and even in the else , as long as we handle the code blocks properly, or in other words, we respect the intention of four spaces after the colon. In this case the variable tengo_vacaciones is True , so it will enter the first if . Then, after assigning the vuelo_comprado variable, check its status and, since it is False , it will enter through the else displaying the message 'Debo comprar el vuelo...'

  1. Now, change the state of the variables and try to display the three messages in the console output.

These nested blocks help to have a very strong control over the execution of the code. In addition, you can keep nesting statements inside already nested statements as many times as you need to increase the complexity and decision power of your code. Of course, remember to be careful and handle the code blocks very well.

Tip: Nested statements apply not only to conditionals, but also to loops, functions, classes, and more.

This concept is useful for understanding code blocks and more easily handling indents. If you understand this, you understand the basic syntax of Python. However, in the next class we will see the final and definitive explanation of code blocks so that it is completely clear to you. I wait for you there!

Python code blocks

You might find it helpful to think of blocks as little boxes to store a set of instructions. For example,

  1. Write and execute the following code, replacing on the line that says # Escribe tu bloque aquí and watch the console output:

 if True: # comienzo del bloque print("Estoy dentro de un bloque if"); print("Tambien estoy dentro de un bloque if"); # final del bloque print("Yo no estoy dentro del bloque if")

As you can see, the first two print() shown to be inside the if have something in common: they are indented with four spaces. Also, as we have seen throughout the course, the if ends with 2 dots : indicating that what follows is a block of code. For its part, the third print() is outside the scope of the code block, that is, it is not inside the if since it does not have the same indentation.

Now change the state of the if to False , run the program, and watch the message in the console output change.

Blocks are very important in our code since they allow us to control the execution of the code or the scope of the variables. By changing the if condition to be False, everything inside that block will not be executed.

Remember: In Python, not having proper indentation is a syntax error, so you have to be very careful about it.

In the next lesson we will see one last concept that will save you a couple of lines of code. I wait for you there!

Ternary Operator

There are times when the value of a variable will depend on a condition. We could use the if conditional in the traditional way that we have already seen. However, it can result in many unnecessary lines of code that can also make it difficult to read. It is then that we see the utility of the ternary operator, also known as conditional expressions.

The idea is to make an entire if scheme in the same line of code. How is this possible? Let's look at a very simple example:

  1. Write the following code on the line with the comment # Escribe tu código aquí

 numero_1, numero_2 = 5, 10 menor = numero_1 if numero_1 < numero_2 else numero_2 print(f'El numero menor es {menor}')

Here we did several things. Let's go by parts.

In the first line we declare two variables: numero_1 and numero_2 . These will have the values 5 and 10 respectively, since the assignment is made according to their position. We can place as many variables as necessary (we are already saving lines). The only thing you have to keep in mind is to have the same number of variable names as values. Otherwise, a ValueError error will be returned.

In the next line we are declaring the menor variable through the ternary operator. First we put the value we want to assign when the condition is True . Next we place the condition with the if and finally, through the else we place the value that we want to assign to the menor variable when the condition is False .

For the example case, the condition results in True because numero_1 is less than numero_2 . Therefore, the value that we will assign to menor is the same value that numero_1 has, that is, 5 .

With the ternary operator it is also possible to simplify the elif statement. Let's see it in the following example:

  1. Write the following code on the line with the comment # Escribe tu código aquí

 edad_maria, edad_sofia = 21, 29 mayor = 'Maria y Sofía tienen la misma edad' if edad_maria == edad_sofia else 'María es la mayor' if edad_maria > edad_sofia else 'Sofia es mayor' print(mayor)

This case is a bit more complex but follows the same methodology. First we indicate the value that will be assigned to the mayor variable if the first condition is met. We then place this first condition with the if . If this is not true, we put else followed by the value we want to assign if the second condition is met (this would be the value of the elif ). Then we put the second condition (which would be the condition of the elif ). At the end we place else followed by the value we want to assign if no condition is met.

As with elif , we can assign as many conditions as necessary, although it is always important that you take care of the readability of your code.

I invite you to change the value of the variables and observe the result in the console output. Likewise, I also invite you to investigate this operator further as it will help you achieve cleaner code.

Excellent! You have finished this module. You learned how to use comments, the print function, to use variables in strings in a more professional way, nested conditionals and code blocks, and finally to know what it is and how to use the ternary operator. Again it is a great advance and it is time to introduce ourselves to new topics. That is why we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other levels that we have prepared for you.

Important! Don't forget to save your results by clicking the ☑ "verify" button at the top right of your screen. I look forward to seeing you in the next course!

Introduction to lists

I welcome you to this new module of the python course. On this occasion we will learn one of the main structures to store different data in the same place. We are talking about lists.

lists

Lists are basically containers that, unlike variables, allow us to store more than one piece of data. Imagine it as a box that internally has multiple compartments and in each of them you can store a different value, even if they are not of the same type. They are easy to identify as their values are enclosed in square brackets [] separated by commas " , ". Let's see how to declare a list:

  1. Write the following code on the line with the comment # Escribe tu código aquí

 lista_variada = ['lapiz', 'reloj', 5, True]

As you can see, its declaration is similar to declaring a variable, only in this case we do not have a single variable, but a list enclosed in square brackets.

Access the value of a list

Now, you may be wondering, how can I access the value of a list? How do I do if I want to use only the value 'lapiz' or True in the example above? To do this, we must remember a concept that you briefly saw in the previous module: positioning.

Lists store data in the order it was written, and to access a value, we must refer to its specific position. As I told you, in the world of programming we always count from zero, so, for the example, if we want to obtain the value 'lapiz' from this list, we must refer to the zero position of it. If instead we want to get the value 'reloj' , we refer to position 1. Let's see how it's done:

  1. Write the following code below the list declaration:

 print( lista_variada[0] ) # 'lapiz' print( lista_variada[1] ) # 'reloj' print( lista_variada[2] ) # 5 print( lista_variada[3] ) # True

As you can see, the way to get a value is by placing the name of the list and indicating the position of the value between square brackets.

Now imagine that you don't know the values in the list, how do you know what position each value has? Don't worry, you can always print the full list:

  1. Write the following code:

 print(lista_variada)

As you can see, you already know what the list has inside.

Very well, you already know the lists, however, there is still much to see and many things that can be done with them. In the next lesson you will see a very common error that you will find when working with lists. I wait for you there!

IndexError: list index out of range

At some point we mentioned this error and now we will see why it is generated and what we can do to solve it.

As you already know, lists are managed by position and as such, their size is defined by the number of variables that we have in it. Consider the following list:

 lista_letras = ['b', 's', 'q', 'f']

Clearly the list has four elements, four letters. Therefore its size is 4 and its positions respectively will be 0, 1, 2, 3. Remember that we start counting from zero.

Now, when pointing to these positions, we commonly say index, referring to the position where you must point to obtain a value within the list. Following this logic, if you try to point the index at position 4, it will not find any value and therefore will show you the error IndexError referring to the fact that there is no value at this position.

In the code editor there is a list and we are trying to print a value that is out of range. If you run it it will show you the error. To solve it you must change the index to which we are trying to access by one that is smaller than the size of the list like this:

  1. Change the value on the line with the comment # Corrige el error aquí

 print(lista_letras[3]) # 'f'

In this case if we are looking for the value in a correct position within the list.

Now, imagine that you don't know what a list contains but you want to know its size. For this we will use a function that has the lists to identify how many elements they contain: The len() function

We will take the previous list and see its size:

  1. Write the following code in the comment that says # Revisa el tamaño de la lista aquí

 return len(lista_letras)

This function performs the count of elements within the list and returns a number with the total of this count. It is incredibly useful for a lot of applications that we will see later.

Excellent! In the next lesson we will see some commonly used methods when working with lists. I wait for you there!

Basic methods for working with lists

Methods help us to efficiently modify with those of a list. Let's consider the following:

 lista_numeros = [7,2,5,10,4] print(lista_numeros)

If we want to add a new element to the list, we use the append() method and inside the parentheses we place the element we want to add.

 lista_numeros.append(8) # [7,2,5,10,4,8] print(lista_numeros)

Note that this method always adds the element to the end of the array.

Now, let's consider a second list and we want to add the elements of the second to the first. For this there is the extend() method and in the parentheses we place the list that we want to add.

 lista_externa = [3,14,20,0] lista_numeros.extend(lista_externa) # [7,2,5,10,4,8,3,14,20,0] print(lista_numeros)

Since such lista_externa remains the same, instead lista_numeros already contains the new values.

Now, we want to remove an element from the list. We then use the pop() method.

 lista_numeros.pop() # [7,2,5,10,4,8,3,14,20] print(lista_numeros)

This method removes the element in the last position from the list.

The reverse() method allows us to reverse the order of the entire list, leaving the last element in the first position and the first element at the end.

 lista_numeros.reverse() # [20,14,3,8,4,10,5,2,7] print(lista_numeros)

The last one we will see is the sort() method that is used to order the elements of the list from the smallest to the largest.

 lista_numeros.sort() # [2,3,4,5,7,8,10,14,20] print(lista_numeros) return lista_numeros

There are other methods and I invite you to investigate them as they can be quite useful. However, the ones we mention here are some of the most useful you will find on a day-to-day basis.

Very well! So far we have already defined the lists and their most common methods. In the next lesson you will see them working in a more practical example. I wait for you there!

Working conditionals with lists

Before going directly to if , you need to know two new operators: IN and NOT IN . These help us to validate if a value is inside a list and as a result it gives us a boolean value. Let's see examples:

  1. Write the following operations in the code editor.

 frutas = ['Lulo', 'Pera', 'Manzana', 'Uva'] print('Manzana' in frutas) # True print('Manzana' not in frutas) # False print('Fresa' not in frutas) # True

If we want to interpret these statements in natural language, they would say something like: "Tell me if the item 'Apple' is in my list of fruits" or "Tell me if the item 'Strawberry' is not in my list of fruits"

With this clear you can do if on a list. Let's see an example:

  1. Write the following conditional in the code editor.

 if 'Manzana' in frutas: if 'Banana' not in frutas: print('Debo comprar bananas') if 'Pera' not in frutas: print(' y peras') elif 'Mango' not in frutas: print(' y mangos')

Taking into account the list of fruits, we see that 'Manzana' is in the list, so it enters the first if . Then it evaluates if 'Banana' is not in the list. Since this is true, it enters the if and displays the first message. And so it continues evaluating the following if . I invite you to run and see the full message in the console output.

Similarly, we can also use them in the ternary operator.

 jugo = 'Quiero jugo de Lulo' if 'Lulo' in frutas else 'No quiero jugo' print(jugo)

These conditionals with lists are very often found in the working world and mastering them will help you in a lot of solutions. The positive is that high language level makes this very easy to understand.

Since you have managed to understand lists very well, in the next lesson we will see the last but perhaps the most common way of working with them. I wait for you there!

loop through the elements of a list

In this lesson we will advance to the concept of cycles, which we will see later, since we will need it to understand lists in depth.

A cycle is nothing more than a block of code with instructions that are repeated a certain number of times or until a condition is no longer true.

In particular, the for loop allows us to execute the code block for each of the elements that exist in a list. We can even use that element as a variable but it is only defined within the code block, that is, its use is limited to the duration of the cycle execution.

So let's see how it works:

Write the following code in the editor:

 planes = ['cantar', 'bailar', 'ir al cine', 'cenar', 'pasear'] print('Aqui inicia el ciclo') for plan in planes: # Definimos el indice "plan" mensaje = f'La actividad para hoy es {plan}' # Usamos el indice "plan" el cual contiene el valor del elemento print(mensaje) print('Fin del ciclo')

In the second line you find the for loop. This could be read like this: "For each plan within the plans list, execute the following block of code"

In the plans list we have five items. The first thing the for loop does is take the first element and assign it to the plan index. From here, we can use plan as if it were a variable that will only be in effect until the block of code is finished. In this case, we use it to customize the message variable that we then send to the console. Here ends the first round. The code then returns to the line where we defined the for, grabs the next item in the list, and repeats the process until it's done with all the items in the list. Finally it stops repeating itself and continues with its normal execution, which in this case is to print the end of cycle message and the program ends.

This is the basic operation of the cycle. However, as I mentioned at the beginning, we will see this concept in detail later.

Cool! You are almost done with this module. In the next lesson you will test your knowledge with an exercise that will link the conditional with this cycle and, of course, the whole topic of lists. I wait for you there!

Exercise: Validating a new student

It's time to put what you've learned to the test. On this occasion the exercise can either be simple or very challenging depending on the way you try to solve it, but I trust that you will achieve it. Before starting to solve it, please read the entire sentence up to where it says "Stop here". Let's start:

You have a list of students and you want to know if the new student is already registered there or if you need to register them. The list and the new student will arrive in the following parameters to validate different test cases:

  • alumnos → It is the list with the name of all the enrolled students. By the way, it's messed up.

  • alumno_nuevo → It is a string with the name of the new student

To solve the exercise you must return one of the following two possibilities depending on the case:

  • If the new student is already on the list, you return the following message: '{aquí va el nombre del alumno} ya está inscrito'

  • If the new student is not yet in the list, you must add it to the alumnos list and at the end return this list in alphabetical order.

There are several ways to do it, some more complex than others, and you are free to choose any way to arrive at the solution. You may only need methods or you may use the for loop. Whichever option is, it is valid as long as you achieve the result and pass the test cases.

Stop here! Try to do it on your own right now. You can go executing the code and validating the expected response to know where to go. I also recommend you use the console to validate if what you are doing is correct. However, if you feel complicated, come back and I'll give you some help so you can advance in your learning. Go ahead!

*****

Here is the help:

You can go through the entire list and for each student check if their name matches that of the new student. If so, you immediately return the message. If not, you add the new student to the list (in the module we saw how to add new elements to the end of a list). Finally, you sort the list and return it.

With this you already have a great help to perform the exercise.

*****

You did? Here I show you two possible ways to reach the same solution:

Using the for loop:

 for alumno in alumnos: if alumno == alumno_nuevo: mensaje = f'{alumno_nuevo} ya está inscrito' print(mensaje) return mensaje else: print('Aun no lo encuentro') print('No lo encontré, voy a inscribrilo') alumnos.append(alumno_nuevo) alumnos.sort() print(alumnos) return(alumnos)

Looking for it directly in the list with the if :

 if alumno_nuevo in alumnos: mensaje = f'{alumno_nuevo} ya está inscrito' print(mensaje) return mensaje else: print('No lo encontré, voy a inscribrilo') alumnos.append(alumno_nuevo) alumnos.sort() print(alumnos) return(alumnos)

Excellent! You have finished the Lists module. You learned what a list is, how to correct a very common mistake working with lists, the most elementary methods for working with lists, how to use them in exercises with conditionals and loops, and you did a simple but smart exercise. You already have a lot of very important knowledge that is the daily bread in the world of work. However, as you know, there are more things waiting for you to learn. That is why we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other levels that we have prepared for you.

while loop

We welcome you to this new module of the python course. On this occasion we will see the loops or cycles, their definition, which ones exist and how to work with them. Without further ado, let's begin.

What is a cycle?

The simplest way to define a loop is to think of it as a set of instructions that will be repeated as many times as necessary until a condition is no longer met. Consider the following situation:

Imagine that your program has to update the cell phone number of 10 people. You update the first one, then copy the same code changing only the cell number and update. Then copy the same code and repeat the process until you do it 10 times. You did it but now imagine not 10 but 50, 100 and even many more! This is an ideal scenario to place a cycle and avoid this long and repetitive task. You create the program to run until there are no more phones to update.

That is precisely the virtue of the cycle. Help us simplify those repetitive tasks.

Now, there are two fundamental loops you need to know about, the while and the for loop, and in this lesson you'll start with the former:

The while loop

This loop executes the code that we write inside it as long as the condition that we indicate is true. As soon as the condition becomes false, the loop will break (it's a way of saying that the code inside the loop will no longer be repeated) and the execution of the rest of the program will continue.

Let's look at an example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 numero = 5 print('Inicio del bucle while') while numero > 0: print(numero) numero = numero - 1 print('Fin del bucle while')

The first thing is to think what is the condition to enter the loop. In this case we will do a countdown and for this we will need to declare a numero variable. Then, below the start message, we declare the while loop. It's just putting the word while , followed by the condition and ending with the colon to start the code block. There we write the statements that are going to be repeated until the condition breaks (Python is easy!).

Now, you may wonder how in this example the condition is broken if the numero variable is 5? Well, we will have to find a way to decrease the value of that variable. If you notice, already being inside the code block of the while loop we have an arithmetic operation: numero = numero - 1 , and as you can imagine what it does is take the value that the variable arrives with, perform the operation and return the result to assign to the same variable. Then when the loop is evaluated, it will already have a different value.

Finally, when the variable numero is zero (for this case), the condition ceases to be true and therefore the while code block will not be executed, jumping to the rest of the execution, in this case the end message on the console.

This is how this cycle works. Remember that the important thing is to place a condition to the while and once you are inside the code block, place a strategy to break the loop. The latter is vital if you don't want your program to keep running forever .

Excellent! You already know how to do a while loop in python. In the next lesson you will see the for loop. I wait for you there!

For loop and range() function

At the end of the previous module we made a short introduction to the for loop with lists. However, here we are going to expand the ways of using it.

Let's first define the for loop. Unlike the while loop, this loop iterates within a range that we define, either with the rango() function, or through a list itself. Let's look at this last case.

When we work with lists, many times we will need to perform operations or validations with each of its elements. There are ways to do it and among them is going through it through a for loop. For example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 lista = ['elemento_0', 'elemento_1', 'elemento_2', 'elemento_3'] print('Inicio del ciclo for') for elemento in lista: print(elemento) print('Fin del ciclo for')

In this case, the syntax is a bit different from what we have seen, but it is also easy to interpret. First you put the word for . Then you put a name of an index. This is up to you, but keep in mind that it makes sense with the value of the elements in the list. Imagine this index as if it were a variable that will only work within the loop and as a value you are going to assign a different element from the list for each iteration. Then you put the name of the list and end with the colon to start the code block.

The loop will start executing the code and once it has finished going through all the elements of the list, it will be the end and it will continue with the rest of the program.

function range()

As its name indicates, this function generates a range of numbers over which we can iterate. Look at the following example to explain it much better.

Important! Remember that in programming the counts are made from zero. That is, the first lap will be lap number 0, the next will be lap number 1, and then lap 2, and so on.

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 print('
 Funcion range(4): ') for numero in range(4): print(numero)

Note: The ' ' symbol represents a line break in the console. You can place it anywhere in the string where you need to change lines.

As we see in the example, the range() function is placed in the place where we previously placed the list. This function receives a parameter, which is the number in parentheses, which represents the number of times the cycle is repeated, which in this case is 4. Then we are printing the lap we are in and here you must pay attention to console output, as you will see that the count does indeed start at 0.

However, we can also tell you where to start the account from. In the following example we place two parameters. The first number is where you start the account and the second is where you should end it.

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 print('
 Funcion range(-2, 4): ') for numero in range(-2, 4): print(numero)

In the console output, notice that we actually start at -2 but end at the number 3. Be very clear that the count ends at the number immediately before the one you put in the end.

Very well! You already know more ways to use the for loop. In the next lesson you will see more interesting ways to mix concepts you already know with loops. I wait for you there!

Useful cycle concepts: break, continue and strings

In this lesson you will see some concepts that will be very useful when working with cycles. To do this, consider the following example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor:

 nombre = 'BaHckEnd' for letra in nombre: # Itera sobre el string if letra == 'H': # Condicionales continue # Sentencia continue if letra == 'E': break # Sentencia break print(letra)

Don't be scared by the text in the nombre variable. It's for practical purposes, you'll see. There are several interesting things here. Let's go one by one.

Strings

It may seem strange to you, but you can iterate over a string. How is this possible? If you remember, strings are a chain of characters, that is, they are characters that are joined together, forming a kind of chain. The for loop interprets this as an array or "list" of characters over which it can iterate character by character.

If

That's right, we can place conditionals inside loops. Anyway, loops are blocks of code where we can write whatever we need. In fact, placing conditionals inside loops is widely used, for example, to search for a letter or a value in a list. The different uses are unlimited in both the for loop and the while .

Continue

So far when we executed a loop, its execution went to the end of the block and started its next iteration. However, this does not have to be the case always. During the execution of the loop when it reaches a continue statement, the program automatically interprets that it ends the iteration it is in and starts a new one from the beginning, no matter what comes after. It is a way to skip what follows in the execution.

Normally this statement is placed inside a conditional as in the case of the example. When the condition is true and you enter the if , the continue will be found and it immediately ends the iteration and returns to the beginning to perform a new one. For example, if it finds the letter 'H' , it executes continue and therefore does not print the letter and will go to the next iteration.

break

This statement is similar to continue , but instead of starting a new iteration, what it does is end or break the loop regardless of whether it has finished traversing the range or the elements of the list. Think of it as a way to aggressively break out of the loop you're in and continue with the rest of the program. For this case, if it finds the letter 'E' , the break will be executed and therefore the cycle will be broken regardless of the fact that there are still letters missing from the string that has not been iterated.

Very well! Now check out this last example with continue and break which will help you understand them:

  1. Write the following code in the editor:

 print('\n') acciones = ['aprendiendo', 'jugando', 'durmiendo', 'soñando', 'practicando', 'salir', 'comiendo'] for accion in acciones: if accion in ['durmiendo', 'soñando']: continue elif accion == 'salir': break print(f'Estoy {accion}') print('Fin de la lección')

In the first condition, if the word is 'durmiendo' or 'soñando' , the program skips the current iteration and does not print that word. In the second condition, if it finds the word 'salir' , there it ends the cycle and shows the message 'Fin de la lección'

Cool! You already have an immense knowledge in cycles. In the next lesson you will see one last concept of cycles to master them. I wait for you there!

nested loops

Like conditionals, loops can also be nested. Let's look at an example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 palabras = ['sol', 'luna'] for palabra in palabras: print(f'Palabra completa: {palabra}') for letra in palabra: print(f'Letra: {letra}')

As we already know, both lists and strings are iterable, that is, they can be looped through.

Now, in the example, we are performing the first for on the list, so each index will be one of its elements, which, in this case, are strings. Then, on that palabra index, we perform another for loop to go through each letter of the string. In the result, we then have two levels of loops displaying first the word and then each letter of that word. Great, isn't it?

One way we see its most frequent use is with lists within lists. Lists within lists? Look at the following example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 print('\nNotas Estudiantes') notas_estudiante = [[4.7, 4.6], [4.3, 5], [4.2, 4.8]] numero = 1 for estudiante in notas_estudiante: print(f'Estudiante No. {numero}') for nota in estudiante: print(f' Nota: {nota}') numero += 1

As you can see, each element of notas_estudiante is in turn a list containing float numbers.

The important thing is that the elements to be iterated really are iterable. For example, an integer or a boolean are not iterable and would give you an error.

Excellent! With this you already have a lot of knowledge to face the cycles. In the next lesson you will put your knowledge in cycles to the test. I'll wait for you there!

Exercise: Separate list

Before starting you must know a very important function that allows us to know if a variable is of a certain type or not.

isinstance() function

This function returns True or False if a variable or value is of a certain type. It receives two parameters: the value or variable and the data type on which we will check if that value is of that type.

For example, isinstance('Hola', str) returns True. It's like asking if the string 'Hello' is of type string.

isinstance(12, bool) returns False. It is as if we were asking if the number 12 is of type boolean (obviously it is false).

Remember that the main data types are str , bool , int and float . I invite you to review the isinstance function in detail because you will use it in the exercise.

Now yes, with this in mind, I tell you what you will do to pass this module:

The idea is that you create a program that separates the values of a list into different lists that only contain the same data type. I give you an example:

If I send you the list [1, 'Azul', 45, True, 'Automovil', False] , you must return the following 3 lists:

['Azul', 'Automovil'] [1, 45] [True, False]

In the return you place the lists in the following order: First the list with strings, followed by integers, then floats and at the end booleans.

Here you are practicing the use of the for loop to evaluate each element, if-elif-else , one of the list methods to add elements and initialize lists (you do the latter at the beginning with a list without elements and then add)

As always, try to do it on your own. However, here is our solution.

********

 cadenas, numeros, booleanos = [], [], [] for elemento in lista: if isinstance(elemento, str): cadenas.append(elemento) elif isinstance(elemento, bool): booleanos.append(elemento) elif isinstance(elemento, int): numeros.append(elemento) else: pass return cadenas, numeros, booleanos

Excellent! You have finished this module. You learned what and what loops are, the range() function, what break and continue are for, nested loops and how to separate lists. So far you have what you need to start doing personal projects. I invite you to review the challenges we have for you and try to find a solution to solve it. In the following classes, we will start with more advanced concepts and closer to what you will find in a professional environment. That is why we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other levels that we have prepared for you.

Functions in Python

Welcome to this module of the course. From here we will start with intermediate level concepts and this time you will learn one of the most relevant topics when it comes to programming: we are talking about functions.

We have already had approximations and worked with functions in previous tutorials. However, for this opportunity it will be clear to you what these statements are and how they work in Python.

During all our Python courses you will have noticed that there is always a block of code like the following:

 def nombreDeLaFuncion():    # código Python

You will know once and for all what this means and how you can create your own functions.

A function, in a few words, is a block of code that has a function in charge, hence its name. These functions can be called at any time using their name, this is called referencing.

The above may not make much sense to you, so we are going to simplify it more with the example of a small calculator, this will have the ability to perform 4 basic operations (add, subtract, multiply and divide).

Creating functions

Let's start by creating the suma() function.

  1. Type the following replacing the # sum function comment here

 def suma(): a = 3 b = 4 print(a + b)

  1. Call the suma() function you just created inside the calculadora() function, replace the comment that says: pass # call your functions here

 suma()

As you can see we have invoked the suma() function by referring to its name, simple isn't it?

Note: Inside these parentheses we can pass values as parameters, but we will see these in the next lesson.

The rest works normally; as you already know everything that is indented to the right will be executed as part of the function block.

  1. create a subtraction function below the add() function block like so:

 def resta(): a = 2 b = 6 print(a - b)

In this case we want to subtract a which is equal to 2 minus b which is equal to 6 this will result in -4.

  1. Create the multiplication and division functions on your own based on the two examples above.

  2. Invokes or calls the other functions.

  3. Click the run button.

Congratulations, you did a great job, let's move on to the next lesson.

Parameters of a function in Python

The parameters are values to which the block of a function has access, these are passed inside the parentheses that go after the name, for example def suma(numero1, numero2) .

Note: For good practice, it is customary for a function to only do one type of thing, generally in relation to its name; For example, if the function will be called fabricarCamisetas() ****it makes no sense for us to call it to make a pair of pants.

Creating a calculator

Now we are going to see how we can improve the calculator from the last lesson so that it adds 2 numbers that we passed to them.

  1. Type the following in the editor replacing the comment # sum function with parameters

 def suma(numero1, numero2): print(numero1 + numero2)

Notice that the variables numero2 numero1 now inside the parentheses, this means that when we call the suma() function we will have to pass both values to it.

  1. Create the other functions for subtraction, multiplication, and division by following the function example above.

How to pass parameters or values to a function

The parameters are passed once the function is called, in the same order in which they were created or defined, that is to say that for our example we first pass number1 and then number2 like this:

 def calculadora():    # invocar funciones con parámetros    suma(4,5)

Note that we have passed two numbers, 4 and 5, these numbers will take the place occupied by the variables number1 and number2 , this means that the sum() function will add both values, resulting in 9.

Invoke the other functions you created and pass them the necessary arguments for their correct operation.

You do very well, let's continue with the next lesson.

How to return values in Python

So far we have used very simple functions that, although they print a value to the console, do not actually return anything, so let's see how we can return values using the return statement.

Continuing with the example of the calculator, let's go on to actually return the values instead of simply printing them on the console. For this, as is customary, let's create 4 functions that represent each basic operation, starting with the addition

  1. create the suma() function.

 def suma(n1, n2): resultado = n1 + n2 return resultado

Note that instead of using print() as we did before, now the return **** statement has been implemented, and you can also notice that its syntax is very simple since we simply use return **** plus the value that we want to return in this case resultado .

  1. Create the other functions for subtraction, multiplication and division based on the example from the previous step

Note: the return **** statement can only be used once, since when the program reads this statement the function will end.

How to view the result

If at this moment you invoke any function from inside calculadora() and execute the code, you will see that nothing really happens, this is because the statement return **** only returns a value but does not take care of its display, for this We will call the functions inside a print() as follows:

  1. Prints the result returned by the suma() function to the console. To do this, it replaces the comment found in the calculator function that says pass # Prints the value of sum()

 print(suma(6, 6))

  1. Run your code.

  2. Print the value returned by each function you created earlier (subtraction, multiplication, division), do not forget to pass each one its corresponding parameters.

  3. run your code again.

Congratulations, you already know the most relevant concepts when working with functions, it's time to raise the level a bit by implementing test cases, see you in the next lesson.

Introduction to test cases

Test cases are not something that belongs to Python or any language in particular, they are actually opportunities to test your code that we implement in PeakU think of it as something like having a personal tutor.

How do they work?

In the lower area you can see two dropdowns called precisely " test cases #n" if you open any of them you will find a subtitle in bold that says "Arguments" these, as you can imagine, are the arguments that we have been passing manually to each function.

We are going to continue using the calculator function so that you understand well how the test cases work.

In the code editor you can see that there are already 2 functions, suma() and calculadora() , also they have 2 parameters or arguments which are num1 and num2 .

Finally notice that we have already called and returned the suma() function inside calculator.

 def calculadora(num1, num2):  return suma(num1, num2)  # invocación y retorno

How to proceed?

  1. Run your code and once it loads, go down to the test cases, you will see that both are in red , this means that we have a programming error that we must correct.

  2. Locate the suma() function in the editor **** maybe you can identify that there is an error, let's see.

 def suma(num1, num2): resultado = num1 - num2 return resultado

As you can tell the suma() function is actually subtracting so we need to correct it.

  1. change the `` **** operator to its + counterpart

 def suma(num1, num2): resultado = num1 + num2 return resultado

  1. Run your code again, now the test cases will have a green color, this means that you have tested and now your result is the same as expected.

Perfect now you are ready to complete the calculator and return your code to be reviewed applying test cases, just remember if the cases are red it means you have a bug, when all are green then your code is perfect ;)

Finalizing the calculator

In the editor you will see that there is already an important advance with the example of the calculator and the 4 basic operations, note that the calculadora() function receives 3 arguments inside its parentheses, these are operador , **** num1 ** **and num2 , ****we want to build a program that identifies which operator is arriving and calls the corresponding function for each case, for example if the operator ****is equal to the string “+” then it will execute the suma() function , if it is "-" it will execute the resta() function and so on, now let's move on to the code.

  1. Create the conditionals for each possible operator in the calculadora() function like this:

 if (operador == "+"):   # suma elif (operador == "-"):   # resta elif (operador == "*"):   # multiplicación elif (operador == "/"):   # divición

  1. Calls and returns each function in its respective conditional.

 if (operador == "+"):   return suma() elif (operador == "-"):   return resta() elif (operador == "*"):  return multiplicacion() elif (operador == "/"):   return division()

  1. Pass the arguments num1 and num2 to each function.

 if (operador == "+"):   return suma(num1, num2) elif (operador == "-"):   return resta(num1, num2) elif (operador == "*"):   return multiplicacion(num1, num2) elif (operador == "/"):   return division(num1, num2)

  1. run your code

If you followed all the steps correctly, now the test cases should be green, this means that you have passed and your code is perfect.

The magic of this system is that it allows you to put your code to the test since in programming it doesn't matter how much you got to an answer or how many steps you did, but rather that the answer is always the expected one and not something different since this would mean a programming error. programming commonly known as bugs.

Congratulations, you have finished this Python functions course, we invite you to continue learning with the other courses we have prepared for you. Don't forget to save your changes and claim your prize by clicking the ✔ "check" button in the top right corner of your screen.

Introduction to Dictionaries

Dictionaries are a type of data structure that allows us to augment capabilities that are sometimes limited by using data types and structures that we already know.

Like lists, we can store multiple data in a single dictionary. However, instead of a single value, we store a key: value pair in dictionaries. Take a look at the following example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor:

 usuario = { "nombre": "Juan", "edad": 22, "tecnologias": ["Python", "Django"] } print(usuario)

Of the most relevant things, we can see that to declare them we use braces {} and inside it we declare each key-value separated by commas. The name of each key is enclosed in quotes and its value is defined by a colon:

Now, if we want to obtain the value of a key in a dictionary, we put the name of the dictionary and between square brackets we pass the key from which we want to obtain its value. Very similar to how we did it in the lists. Let's see:

  1. Write the following code in the editor:

 print(usuario["nombre"]) print(usuario["tecnologias"])

In some cases you could put number as braces. However, you should keep in mind that it is totally different from using lists.

Important: In dictionaries we do not have an order as such. Everything is handled with the keys.

Finally, to add or modify a key-value definition, as you can imagine, you just need to put the name of the dictionary and in square brackets the name of the key. Look at the following example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor:

 usuario["edad"] = 24 usuario["direccion"] = "Calle 32 No 83 - 26" return usuario

In Python everything is an object and dictionaries are no exception. Therefore, you will see that they also have methods that help us to better deal with them, and in the next lesson you will see some of them. I wait for you there!

Main methods in dictionaries

As I mentioned in the previous lesson, you will see that there are some important methods when working with dictionaries. There are more and I invite you to investigate about them. Without further ado, let's begin:

get()

There is another way to get the value of a key in a dictionary and it is through the get() method. Between the parentheses we place the key whose value we want to know.

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 print(f'get nombre {usuario.get("nombre")}')

keys()

This method allows us to get all the keys of a dictionary. Its result is of type dict_keys, which is an iterable, which allows us to work with statements such as conditionals and loops. Later you will see it.

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 print(f'keys {usuario.keys()}')

values()

This method instead of keys, brings us all the values that exist in a dictionary. Likewise, its result is of type dict_values, similar to the one seen in the previous method.

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 print(f'values {usuario.values()}')

items()

This method could be said to be a combination of the previous two, that is, it brings us each key-value pair in a tuple (I'll explain this new term to you in a moment). As you can imagine, the result is an iterable of type dict_items

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 print(f'items {usuario.items()}')

Tuple definition: Basically it is like a list with the difference that they are not mutable, that is, their values cannot be modified once they have been declared; and that tuples are more efficient when properly managing memory. Declaring them is done with parentheses () and their values separated by commas.

pop()

As with lists, we can delete values, only in this case it is not done by order, but by the key that we want to delete. This key must go between the parentheses of the pop method.

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 usuario.pop("direccion") print(usuario)

update()

This method is another way to modify or add values in a dictionary. To do this we add between the parentheses of the method, the key without quotes defining the new value. Look at the following example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 usuario.update(edad = 25, es_empleado = True)

It is also possible to do it from a new dictionary. Look at the following example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 usuario.update({"name": "Juan José", "cargo": "Desarrollador"}) return usuario

So far, if you have followed the steps you will see in the console output the result of each method seen in the lesson.

As I mentioned, there are other methods that I invite you to investigate, however, these seen in the lesson are the ones that you will use the most in your day to day.

In the next lesson you will see how to use dictionaries with conditionals and loops. I wait for you there!

Conditionals and cycles with dictionaries

Before starting, it is important to review the operation of dictionaries on the IN statement to understand how to work with loops and conditionals. When we perform a comparison of a value directly on the dictionary, the reality is that we are only comparing on the keys. Let's review the following example:

 pelicula = { "titulo": "Avengers Endgame", "duracion": 180 } print(f'titulo {"titulo" in pelicula}') print(f'categoria {"categoria" in pelicula}')

As you can see, the first comparison returns True since the "title" key does exist in the dictionary, while the second comparison returns False since the "category" key does not exist in the dictionary. That said, if we want to validate on the values or directly on a key-value pair, we would have to use one of the methods that we saw in the previous lesson.

Conditionals:

As you can see, when using the in statement, it returns a boolean value, so using it in conditionals works in a similar way to the use we had in lists. You just have to keep in mind that if you do it directly on the dictionary, you are iterating on the list. But, if for example you want to search for a specific key-value, you must do it through a tuple and use the items() method:

 if ("titulo", "Avengers Endgame") in pelicula.items(): pelicula.update({"director": "Hermanos Russo"}) print(pelicula)

Cycles :

Dictionaries are more used in the for loop and as you will understand, their direct iteration is done over the keys. So far, again very similar to lists. However, we can also iterate over key-value pairs using the items() method. Look at the following example:

 for key, value in pelicula.items(): print(f'llave: {key}, valor: {value}') return pelicula

Working with these statements is simple as long as we keep in mind what we are iterating or comparing.

In the following lessons you will work on two concepts that will help you save a couple of lines of code. I wait for you there!

List Comprehensions

List and Dictionary Comprehensions are ways to generate both lists and dictionaries in one line of code as long as they follow a certain pattern. But let's go step by step, first with the lists:

Consider the following example to generate a list from a list comprehension

 primeros_numeros = [numero for numero in range(6)] print(primeros_numeros) # [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

I'll explain how it works. The first thing to keep in mind is to enclose the entire expression in square brackets to indicate that we are going to generate a list. Then we place the expression (which can also be an operation, you'll see) that will be stored as an element within the list. Next we perform a for operation where the iterable will have the same name of the variable that we use in the expression to store the element.

In other words, what we do is a loop that goes through an iterable, and for each return we save a value inside the array. Similar to an .append() inside a loop.

Let's review another example:

 numeros_cuadrados = [numero*numero for numero in range(6)] print(numeros_cuadrados) # [0, 1, 4, 9, 16, 25]

In this opportunity we see that we are no longer saving only the number as in the previous example. Here we are already saving the result of the operation number * number.

Something interesting is that we can add conditionals to these list comprehensions. Look at the following example:

 vocales = ['a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u'] palabra = 'murcielago' sin_vocales = [letra for letra in palabra if letra not in vocales] return sin_vocales

In this case, we are looping through the word string variable, but we are only storing in the no_vowels list those letters that are not in the vowels list. In other words, we are removing the vowels from the word.

Regarding syntax, we see that the start does not change starting with the expression that we are going to store in the list. Next is the loop it goes through to generate the list and at the end the condition evaluating on the variable it is iterating over.

As you can see, this is another way to generate lists efficiently and reducing syntax without losing readability. Mastering these list comprehensions will help you greatly enhance your code.

We'll look at dict_comprehensions in the next lesson. I wait for you there!

Dictionary Comprehensions

Finally, dictionary comprehensions follow the same ideology as list comprehensions, only their syntax changes a bit. Let's look at an example:

 llaves = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'] valores = [1, 'casa', True, [1, 2, 3], 'PeakU'] diccionario = { llave:valor for (llave,valor) in zip(llaves, valores) } print(diccionario)

Here we will see several things. The first, and most obvious, thing is that our entire expression will go inside curly braces {}. Next, we see that the expression starts with key:value followed by the for loop, and here there can be multiple ways to do it. In this case, we use a tuple as the variable that will change and we generate the iterable with the zip() function.

zip() function: Generates an iterable of tuples from two lists. The number of tuples that are generated depends on the smallest list size. Items left over at the end of the longest list are not taken into account.

However, as I told you, we can generate dictionaries in multiple ways and we don't necessarily have to have lists for it. Consider the following example:

 numeros_cubo = {x:x**3 for x in range(1,5)} return numeros_cubo # {1: 1, 2: 8, 3: 27, 4: 64}

In this example we place the number generated by range as the key and its result when raised to the cube as the value.

You already have enough knowledge to test yourself in the exercise. I'll wait for you there!

Exercise

Here you will practice the comprehensions. By parameter I am going to send you a string "frase" and a list of numbers "numeros" . Your mission is to return two variables at the end taking into account the following:

  1. In the first challenge you will have to remove all the spaces " " from the string "phrase". Use list comprehensions to save each letter in a list. Then, on the next line, put the following:

 "".join(nombre_de_tu_lista)

What this does is that it takes a list and converts it to a string by joining each of its elements.

  1. Following the first challenge you will have to take the "numbers" list and find the square root of each number with a dict comprehension. Here the key is each number in the list and you must save it as a string. The value will be the result of the square root operation. For example: If the number is 25, the value key must be in the form '25': 5 . Again, note that the key remains as a string.

At the end you return first the generated string without spaces, followed by the dictionary with the square roots.

This is a simple challenge but in which you must take care of the detail. As always and in the same way, I leave you our solution below, but not before inviting you to do it first on your own.

 lista = [letra for letra in frase if letra != ' '] nueva_frase = "".join(lista) raiz_numeros = {str(numero): numero**0.5 for numero in numeros} return nueva_frase, raiz_numeros

Excellent! You have finished this module. You learned what dictionaries are, some of their most important modules, how to use them with conditionals and loops, and one of the most important topics in python: comprehensions. You have more and more resources to face a professional environment. That is why we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other levels that we have prepared for you.
