Introduction to Error Handling - Types of Errors

I welcome you to this module where we will deal with one of the topics that every developer must learn to implement to deal with certain situations and complications that may arise in their development: Error handling.

The first thing we will do is differentiate the errors that exist in python.

When python doesn't finish running properly and displays an Error message, one of two things could be happening: a syntax error or a logical error. Let's go with the first.

SyntaxError

This error is relatively easy to solve since it only shows up if you wrote something that is not correct according to the language's own syntax. It may be that you missed closing a parenthesis or placing a colon, that you placed an extra comma or you missed some quotes. For example: Suppose you want to print a message like this:

 print(Bienvenido al manejo de errores)

When executing it, python will show an error like the following:

 File "<stdin>", line 1 print(Bienvenido al manejo de errores) ^ SyntaxError: invalid syntax

Notice that at the end it is literally telling you that you have a syntax error and indicates the position in which it detected that error. Since you know that strings are enclosed in quotes, you simply fix it so that now the message is displayed correctly: print("Bienvenido al manejo de errores")

Logical errors or Exceptions

They are errors that are displayed while the program is running (runtime errors). In this case it starts to get a bit complicated. However, python does a very decent tracking of these errors. Its causes can be several, from poor planning and execution of the development as such, to an incorrect use of our program by someone external.

Exceptions usually start with a Traceback that tells you where the error was traced from and what files and functions it went through to get there. Then it tells you the type of error and a short message indicating in more detail what happened.

These last ones are the ones that we will try to handle to prevent our program from collapsing without having tried something different.

In the next lesson we will see some of the most common errors and how to handle them through try - catch statements. I'll wait for you there!

Exceptions and Try - Except Statement

As I mentioned in this case, we will see some of the most common exceptions and we will see how to handle the try - except statement to prevent the program from crashing.

Some of the known exceptions are:

  • ZeroDivisionError : You are doing a mathematical division with the denominator at zero.

  • NameError : You have not yet declared the variable you are using or you have misspelled its name.

  • TypeError : You are trying to do an operation or function with the wrong type of variable. One option is to change the variable type.

  • ValueError : You may be executing a function with a value that the function does not allow. For example passing a letter to the int() function

  • IndexError : When you are trying to access a value outside of a range. For example, you try to access a value from a list at a position that does not exist.

  • KeyError : When you try to access a key that does not exist in a dictionary.

There are more and I invite you to investigate them. However, these are the ones that you will find very often in your developments.

When they appear, your program immediately stops running and shows you the error. However, in general, you don't want your program to be broken by a bug that you can control. Consider the following example:

 numero = 'Hola' operacion = 2 * int(numero) print(operacion)

If you run this example, you will get the following error:

 Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'Hola'

As you will see, it tells you that in the int() function you must put something in base 10. That means that you must enter a number. Now, imagine that value is not a variable that we declare, but is being entered by a user. How can you control the user if he wants to send a letter instead of a number? It is not possible, but if you can tell him what to do. Let's fix this example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor

 numero = 'Hola' try: operacion = 2 * int(numero) print(operacion) except ValueError: print(f'"{numero}" no es un valor válido. Debes ingresar un número.')

With this, we could already tell the user what he is doing wrong and how he can get the result he expects. Let's see the syntax that is handled in a try - catch , it is very simple.

The first thing is to start with the word try and we open its block of code. All the statements that would normally be executed without errors are placed in this block. If this happens, if we have no errors, the execution will proceed normally and the entire except block will be skipped. But the moment a statement is executed that generates an error (as in this case when executing the int() function), the program will immediately jump to except . Here what we do is evaluate the type of error:

  • If it's the same type of error that we put in the except , the program goes into executing its block of code. Once finished, the program continues executing the rest of the code.

  • If it is not of the same type, it will go on to evaluate the next except we have, if we have. If there are no more, the program ends and the corresponding error is thrown. You should look at the type and assess how you could handle it.

Let's look at another example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor

 camiseta = { 'color': 'verde', 'talla': 'M' } try: tipo_tela = camiseta['tipo_tela'] except KeyError: camiseta.update(tipo_tela="Genérica") return camiseta

In this case we want to know the type of fabric of a shirt. If it does not have it, we put the type "Generic" and continue the execution of the program.

Note that in this case, if we had not caught the error, the program would stop and show us a KeyError when the key was not found.

Very well! You already know the try-catch . In the next lesson we will see more things related to error handling. I'll wait for you there!

raise

Remembering a bit, exceptions occur while the program is running. Bearing this in mind, we can generate our own errors if we want to stop the execution at some point because, for example, the user entered invalid data.

Imagine the following case: You need the user to enter a value greater than zero and for some reason in your execution you must show an error if it does not. You could do it in the following way:

 print("La variable numero debe ser mayor a cero") numero = -3 if numero <= 0: raise Exception(f'El numero {numero} es menor a cero. Ingresa un número mayor a cero') print(numero)

Running this code with the number variable set to -3 will enter the if and the raise Exception line will be executed. At that moment the following error is thrown:

 Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 2, in <module> Exception: El numero -3 es menor a cero. Ingresa un número mayor a cero

As you can see, the type of exception is the same one that we put in the raise and the message is the string that we put between the parentheses. We can put any of the exception types we saw and just change the message or just put the word Exception .

As an important note, if you are handling multiple exceptions and use the Exception key, you should leave it at the end to avoid problems when executing your code.

Now, for practical purposes, let's also catch this error in a try-except .

  1. Write the following code in the editor.

 numero = -3 try: if int(numero) <= 0: raise Exception(f'El numero {numero} es menor a cero. Ingresa un número mayor a cero') print(numero) except ValueError: print(f'"{numero}" no es un número. Debes ingresar un número valido') except Exception as exc: print(exc)

In this case, we are placing two possible errors that can happen:

The first is to check if it really is a number with the int() function. Otherwise, it will raise the ValueError error and display a message.

The second is to validate if the number is greater than zero and for this we do it with the word raise . If it is not correct, the Exception block is executed, displaying a message. Note that we can put the message in parentheses after the raise Exception and, at the end of the except of the Exception, we call the message with the term as exc .

Cool! In the next lesson we will see another way to generate these errors conscientiously See you there!

Assert

We return to comparisons and logical values. Remember how I mentioned how useful it was to master them? Well, in error handling we also see that they can help us.

This keyword allows us to make a comparison. If the result is true, execution continues normally. But if the result is false, an error of type AssertionError like the following is immediately generated. Let's see it in an example:

 invitados = ['Lorena', 'Martin', 'Emily', 'Diego'] nombre = 'Santiago' assert nombre in invitados, f'Ups! Lo siento {nombre}, no estas invitado. Pero intentaré hacer algo para que te quedes.' print(f'¡Ey, {nombre}! Que bueno que llegaste.')

This time we use the word assert to validate if a name is among the guests of a meeting.

As you can see, it is very simple. You only need to place the word assert followed by the condition and at the end you can place a comma and a personalized message explaining the reason why the error is generated (it is still optional).

With this clear, we can also put this exception inside a try-catch structure.

  1. Write the following code in the editor:

 invitados = ['Lorena', 'Martin', 'Emily', 'Diego'] nombre = 'Santiago' try: assert nombre in invitados print(f'¡Ey, {nombre}! Que bueno que llegaste.') except AssertionError: print(f'Ups! Lo siento, no estas invitado. Pero intentaré hacer algo para que te quedes.')

Excellent! You have what it takes to deal with the errors and exceptions that come your way. Let's go with an exercise so you can practice what you saw in the course. I'll wait for you there!

Factor exercise

The factorial is a multiplication of the first n integers. For example: factorial(5) would be: 1*2*3*4*5 = 120 .

Your challenge is to create a program that calculates the factorial of the number that you send as a parameter and returns the result. However, there will be cases where it sends you a negative number or a letter. In that case, since an error will be generated, you must return one of the following messages:

  • 'Debes ingresar un número positivo' if the number is zero or negative.

  • 'Debes ingresar un número entero positivo válido' if what was entered was not a number

As a recommendation, rely on the assert lesson to handle the value when it arrives negative.

Try to solve the exercise on your own. However, as always I leave you our solution:

******

 def factorial(num): try: num_factorial = 1 assert int(num) > 0 for i in range(1, num+1): num_factorial *= i return num_factorial except ValueError: return 'Debes ingresar un número entero positivo válido' except AssertionError: return 'Debes ingresar un número positivo'

Excellent! You have finished this module. You learned what exceptions are, how to use them to prevent your program from crashing, what assert and raise statements are, and how to generate errors in a controlled way, and you did a classic exercise handling a common error. As you can see, there are more and more advanced things to understand. That is why we invite you to continue educating yourself with the other levels that we have prepared for you.

Important! Don't forget to save your results by clicking the ☑ "verify" button at the top right of your screen. I look forward to seeing you in the next course!

Introduction to Classes

I welcome you to this important module in the world of programming. On this occasion, I will explain how object-oriented programming works. It is important that you practice and do a lot of research in this section, since mastering this topic will take you to a higher level where you can practically carry out any program that you are entrusted with or that you imagine. Without further ado, let's begin.

The first thing you will learn is the classes. There are many definitions and from them we could conclude that they are ways of generating a structure to something that we will call an object and the functionalities that this object can do. A little complicated to understand? I know, and that's why I want us to review this example:

Imagine you have a group of people. Each person has different characteristics such as age, sexuality, nationality, etc. As far as we know, the way to save this data would be with variables, lists or dictionaries. And it wouldn't be bad. However, if you think about it, you would be repeating a lot of code and, furthermore, what if we wanted to add more common characteristics like height or weight? The code becomes giant and crazy. Wouldn't it be better to have a structure already defined with all these attributes and just tell it its value? Well, I tell you that this is where classes come in.

A class would be like that template where we already have all the attributes that an object can have (age, sexuality, nationality, height, weight, etc.), and in this case that object would be each person. The only thing we would have to do is fill in that data. It would be something like this:

  1. Write the following code replacing in the comment # Escribe la definición de la clase aquí

 class Persona: def __init__(self, nombre, edad): self.nombre = nombre self.edad = edad

Okay calm down! I know that there are several new things and as always we will see how the syntax is step by step so that it is clear to you. Let's go!

The first thing is to define the class and for this we put the word class and the name we want to give it. In this case it will be Persona and that is what we will call it when we instantiate objects, later you will see what this is about. Note that the first letter is capitalized. By convention, class names are CamelCased , that is, each word in the name starts with a capital letter and no spaces ( PiezaAjedrez can be a correct class name)

In the next line we see def __init__ . It is here where we are going to establish all the attributes of the class and it is here where the value of each attribute is going to be assigned to each object, to each person. Also called constructor. In this same line we see the word self in parentheses in addition to other parameters. This keyword is to know exactly what object you are referring to, that is, what person you are referring to. Remember that the idea is that the Persona class is a template for several objects or people, and with self you are differentiating exactly which person you are going to create the attributes for. If it is still not clear to you, be patient as you will see it much better when we get to instantiate objects.

At the end, within the code block of this def _init_ method is the assignment of the parameters to the attributes of the object. Again we see the word self referring to the object, followed by a period and the name of the attribute. This is how we create new attributes to the object. And to each attribute we are assigning the value that came as a parameter between the parentheses.

So far try to make this structure very clear to you. Review each line of code very well and when you have it, continue with the lesson.

Perfect! Let's instantiate our first objects. It's very simple, look:

  1. Write the instantiation of the objects replacing in the comment that says # Instancia tus objetos aquí

 jose = Persona(nombre='José', edad=31)

You see it! It is very simple. Let's instantiate another:

 david = Persona(nombre='Juan David', edad=24)

We could do as many as we need. I explain now if what is happening:

You will see that the first thing is to do com if we were declaring a variable, but in this case it is known as instantiating an object of the class. We put the name of the class, in this case Persona , and between parentheses we pass the data of the attributes that this object has. In this case the object jose we pass nombre=José and edad=31 . The next object is david and its attributes will be nombre='Juan David' and edad=24 .

When each line is executed, the program will go to the __init__ method of the Persona class and it is as if self takes the name of the object, be it jose or david , and as in any function, adds the parameters that we pass to the corresponding attribute. Instead of self imagine it as jose.nombre = 'José' and jose.edad=31 or david.nombre = 'Juan David' and david.edad = 24 . That is why I was telling you that the self helps to differentiate exactly which one we are referring to.

Finally, to access the attribute of an object we only have to indicate the name, followed by the dot and the name of the attribute. So:

  1. Write the return below the object instances to close the clases_objetos function block

 return jose.nombre, jose.edad, david.nombre, david.edad

Excellent! The introduction was a bit long but the idea is that the structure for using the classes is very clear. However, it is not necessary to see a property perhaps a little more important than just defining attributes. In the next lesson you will see the methods. I'll wait for you there!

Methods

Let's continue with the example of the person. As such a person can walk, swim, eat, drive, talk, etc. In short, a person can perform actions. These being common we can include them within the class as a template of what an object can do. But, how to do it? Well, for are the methods. See how it works:

In the previous lesson we built the structure of a class with a method, the __init__ . As I told you, this is used to assign attributes to our objects. Let's use that class but add one more attribute for the purposes of the lesson.

  1. Write the following code replacing in the comment that says # Escribe la definición de la clase aquí

 class Persona: def __init__(self, nombre, edad, salario): self.nombre = nombre self.edad = edad self.salario = salario # Escribe tus métodos aquí

Now, to create new methods is like adding a new function to the class. Let's say the person can say hello. Let us then define a method for the person to greet:

  1. Write the following methods replacing in the comment that says # Escribe tus metodos aquí

 def saludar(self): print(f'¡Hola! Me llamo {self.nombre}. Gusto en conocerte.')

As you can see, the idea is very simple. You only need to define the function to be performed and place the sequence of steps or statements to be performed. Note that the name as such is an action, a verb. It tells us that this object is going to do something or something is going to be done with that object. For clean and readable code, it is very important that the name is given as a verb.

Cool! Let's assign another method.

 def cumplir_anios(self): self.edad += 1

In this case, note that we can also modify the values of the attributes through the methods. Other method:

 def ver_salario(self): return self.salario

The methods also return values that we can use in our normal execution. Let's look at one last method.

 def actualizar_salario(self, nuevo_salario): self.salario = nuevo_salario return self.salario

In this last example, see that we are assigning the value that arrives in the nuevo_salario parameter. We will send this value when we call the method from the object. Let's do it:

  1. From here, write the following lines of code inside the clases_metodos function, replacing in the comment that says # Escribe aqui tu instanciación y llamados a los métodos

 santi = Persona(nombre='Santiago', edad=25, salario=1000)

So far we know that we only instantiate an object that we call santi . Now, let's see how the methods of the object are used:

 santi.saludar()

As you can see, the syntax is simple. We only place the object followed by a period and the name of the method. Being like a function we put the parentheses at the end. Let's see the others.

 print(f'Edad inicial: {santi.edad}') santi.cumplir_anios() print(f'Edad final: {santi.edad}')

As you can see, calling the cumplir_anios method changes the value of the variable. We see this in the console when printing the new age.

 print(f'Salario: {santi.ver_salario()}')

In this case, the ver_salario method returns a value that we are directly printing on the console.

 nuevo_salario = santi.actualizar_salario(1800) print(f'Nuevo salario: {nuevo_salario}')

In the latter case, in the actualizar_salario method we are passing a value as a parameter which we assign to the salario attribute. Already as such in the method is where the assignment is made. Now, since it has a return, we can assign it to any variable.

Finally I leave you a trick to obtain a dictionary with the attributes of an object. This is the vars() function:

 return vars(santi)

As such, you must pass this function if or if object as a parameter and what it does is convert each attribute of the object and its value into a dictionary.

As you can see, the methods can be used in many ways and it all depends on your needs, your imagination and how you manage to break down a problem into very small steps.

Very well! Until here you could already face a basic code with classes. However, in the next lesson you will see a topic that you will come across a lot in all languages: Inheritance. I'll wait for you there!

Inheritance

To understand this concept, we will not only think of a person, but there may also be people with a special role such as employee or student. If you analyze it, these roles share certain attributes with a person like name, age, etc, as well as actions like greeting, walking, etc. However, there are attributes and methods that are different in an employee such as position, salary, increase_salary and that are different in a student such as university, current semester, take exam, etc. Let's see in code what this would look like and what it has to do with inheritance.

Let's first define the Persona class and the attributes and methods it could have:

  1. Write the following classes replacing in the comment that says # Escribe las clases aquí

 class Persona: def __init__(self, nombre, edad): self.nombre = nombre self.edad = edad def saludar(self): print(f'¡Hola! Soy {self.nombre} y es un gusto saludate.')

For now, these are the main common attributes between an employee and a student. Now let's create a class for an employee with its own attributes but also containing the attributes and methods of the Persona class:

 class Empleado(Persona): def __init__(self, nombre, edad, compania, cargo, salario): super().__init__(nombre, edad) self.compania = compania self.cargo = cargo self.salario = salario

Everything looks very similar except for a few important things: Why in the Empleado class name are we putting the Persona class name in parentheses? What does the line where it says super() mean?

Well, actually both questions are related to each other. By putting the name of the Persona class in parentheses, what we do is share or inherit its attributes and methods from the Empleado class. It is very important that you remember that we are talking about classes, that is, what we inherit is like the template, but not the values. Now, with super() what we do is bring the attributes of the class that is between the parentheses as such and avoid declaring them again.

That said, an object instantiated with class Persona can not have a compania , cargo or salario . Instead, an object instantiated with the Empleado class can have the attributes nombre , edad , compania , cargo , and salario and can also use the saludar method because it inherited them from the Persona class.

And what would Estudiante be like? Let's see:

 class Estudiante(Persona): def __init__(self, nombre, edad, universidad, semestre_actual, promedio): super().__init__(nombre, edad) self.universidad = universidad self.semestre_actual = semestre_actual self.promedio = promedio

As you can imagine, in this case the Estudiante class inherits the attributes and methods of the Persona class and only those objects that are instantiated with the Estudiante class will have the universidad , semestre_actual and promedio parameters. Very different from an Empleado who has his own attributes. Yes, they both have access to the saludar method.

It is important for you to know that the Persona class is known as the main class or parent class. Therefore, Empleado and Estudiante would be child classes that hijas from their parent Persona class.

Let's instantiate some objects to make it clear for you.

  1. Write the following code inside the inheritance function in the comment that says # Instancia tus objetos aquí

 catalina = Persona(nombre='Catalina', edad=20) milena = Estudiante(nombre='Milena', edad=22, universidad='PeakU University', semestre_actual=8, promedio=4.8) susana = Empleado(nombre='Susana', edad=28, compania='PeakU', cargo='FullStack Dev', salario='1950') # Saluda con el metodo heredado

As you can see, we can assign a nombre and edad to milena and susana thanks to inheritance. In this way we can reduce unnecessary lines of code.

Now let's have everyone send a console greeting.

  1. Write the call to the methods replacing in the comment that says # Saluda con el metodo heredado

 catalina.saludar() milena.saludar() susana.saludar() # Escribe aqui el return final

Inheritance is a powerful way to factor out a lot of code, make it reusable, fully readable, and scalable as your application grows. Imagine that we must introduce a new attribute to all classes, for example nationality or a new method such as birthday. We would only have to add the new thing to the parent class and we could already make use of that method or inherit the attribute by adding it in the super().

Finally let's return the three objects but in dictionary form.

  1. Write the return in the comment that says # Escribe aqui el return final

 return vars(catalina), vars(milena), vars(susana)

Understanding inheritance will give you many tools to increase the potential of your developments. I invite you to investigate them further and practice this concept. In the next lesson we will see some concepts that can help you when facing a problem. I'll wait for you there!

general example

This exercise will be different since beyond developing a problem, it consists of you understanding some new key concepts that I am going to show you. Then you can modify and improve it in your IDE or code editor. I recommend that you save the code at the end of the lesson to play with it to your liking. It is also optional. Without further ado, let's begin.

Let's go by parts. The first thing I'll show you are static methods and static variables. When talking about statics, the idea is that we don't need to instantiate objects to access the variables and use the methods of a class. Let's look at an example:

  1. Write the following code in the editor replacing in the comment that says # Escribe aquí las clases

 class Animal: reino = 'animal' def __init__(self, numero_patas=None): self.numero_patas = numero_patas @staticmethod def alimentar(): # Método estático return('Aquí tienes comida') # Escribe aquí las clases

The first thing we see, after placing the name to the class, is to assign a variable in the same way that we have done throughout the course. However, being inside the class, it is of a static type, so we can access it directly from the class in this way: Animal.reino

Then you have the constructor definition although there is something new. In the parameter numero_patas we are assigning the value None . This is done to make them optional when instantiating an object. In itself what happens is that the value None is being placed by default if the value is not sent when the object is instantiated.

Next, we have a @staticmethod and below it the alimentar() function. By placing it like this we make this function static and therefore be able to use it from the class without needing to instantiate an object, like this: Animal.alimentar()

Let's add a couple more classes to get right into the use of static variables and methods.

  1. Write the following code in the editor replacing in the comment that says # Escribe aquí las clases

 class Mascota(Animal): tipo = 'mamífero' def __init__(self, nombre, raza, genero, numero_patas=None): super().__init__(numero_patas) self.nombre = nombre self.raza = raza self.genero = genero def alimentar(self): return f'{Animal.alimentar()}, {self.nombre}' class Gato(Mascota): especie = 'Felis catus' class Perro(Mascota): especie = 'Canis familiaris'

As you can see, we declare a Mascota class that inherits from Animal , that is, we can use its attributes and methods even if they are static. Now notice that here also the alimentar() method but this time it does something different. This is known as polymorphism , that is, the ability to change the behavior of a method that has the same name. You will see that it will act differently depending on what we call it.

At the end we inherit the attributes and methods of Mascota to the Gato and Perro classes. Note that we no longer have the constructor, since all the attributes we need are inherited from Mascota . If we put one more attribute, we would need to define the init and add the super() so that it inherits.

  1. Finally, let's call the functions by writing the following code in the comment that says # Escribe aqui los llamados a las clases

 zeus = Perro(nombre='Zeus', raza='Rottweiler', genero='M') lana = Gato(nombre='Lana', raza='Angora', genero='F', numero_patas=4) print(f'Animal reino: {Animal.reino}') print(f'Mascota reino: {Mascota.reino}') print(f'Zeus reino: {zeus.reino}') print(f'Mascota tipo: {Mascota.tipo}') print(f'Lana reino: {lana.tipo}') print(f'Zeus especie: {zeus.especie}') print(f'Lana especie: {lana.especie}') print(Animal.alimentar()) # Llamamos a la clase estática print(zeus.alimentar()) print(lana.alimentar()) print(f'El perro es un {Mascota.tipo} de la especie {Perro.especie}') print(f'El gato es un {Mascota.tipo} de la especie {Gato.especie}') print(f'{lana.nombre} es un {lana.tipo} de {lana.numero_patas} patas de la especie {lana.especie} de raza {lana.raza}') return f'{zeus.nombre} es un {zeus.tipo} de la especie {zeus.especie} de raza {zeus.raza}'

Run the code and look at each output. You will see that we are using each method and attribute differently.

Cool! That would end the module. We invite you to continue educating yourself with the lessons we have prepared for you.

Important! Don't forget to save your results by clicking the ☑ "verify" button at the top right of your screen. I look forward to seeing you in the next course!

metacharacters

We welcome you to this module of the course. This time we will review some concepts that will be very useful in your day to day life. Let's start.

As a developer, sometimes we will need to find exact information within a text, be it a specific email, a username, or omit some special character from said text. In this case we will use the expresiones regulares that are abbreviated as regex .

Let's start with the Metacharacters:

 \d --Digitos (0-9) \D --No digitos (0-9) \w --caracter (az, AZ, 0-9, _) \W --No caracteres \s --Espacio en blanco (espacio, tab, salto de linea) \S --No Espacio en blanco (espacio, tab, salto de linea) . --Cualquier caracter excepto nueva linea ^ --inicio de una cadena de caracteres $ --fin de una cadena de caracteres

Let's learn a little more about this list of metacharacters:

  1. Replace the comment of # añade tu variable de get_first_number acá with the following code:

     get_first_number = r'\d'

    With this regex you get the first match of the first number of your text.

  2. Replace the comment of # añade tu variable de get_first_character acá with the following code:

     get_first_character = r'\w'

    With this regex you get the first match of the first character of your text.

  3. Replace the # añade tu variable de get_initial_character acá with the following code:

     get_initial_character = r'^\w'

    With this regex you get the initial character of your text.

  4. Replace the # añade tu variable de get_last_character acá with the following code:

     get_last_character = r'\w$'

    With this regex you get the last character of all your text.

Note : To use regex in python you must import it like this: import re and in each regular expression you use you must start the string with the letter r such as r'\w$' .

Congratulations go to the next level!

Search range number.

We have already seen the metacharacters that are the basic searches to find something in a text, now we will use them with a range and for this we will use the following table:

 * --0 o más coincidencias (codicioso - greedy) + --1 o más coincidencias (codicioso - greedy) ? --0 o 1 coincidencias (perezoso - lazy) {3} --numero exacto {3, 4} --rango de números (mínimo, máximo)

Let's learn a little more about this list:

  1. Replace the # añade tu variable expression_1 acá comment with the following code:

     expression_1 = r'\d+'

    By using \d+ you get 1 or more number matches in your text.

  2. Replace the # añade tu variable expression_2 acá comment with the following code:

     expression_2 = r'^\w*'

    By using \w* you get 0 or more matches of any character in your text.

  3. Replace the comment of # añade tu variable expression_3 acá with the following code:

     expression_3 = r'^\w{3}'

    By using ^\w{3} you get a range of 3 initial matches of your text.

  4. Replace the # añade tu variable expression_4 acá comment with the following code:

     expression_4 = r'\w{3}$'

    1. By using \w{3}$ you get a range of 3 final matches of your text.

Congratulations go to the next level!

Grouping with regex.

By grouping metacharacters and ranges you can make more precise searches in your texts, let's see a little more with this table:

 () -- grupos [] -- hace un match con todos los valores que están dentro de los corchetes cuadrados. [^] --omite los valores que están dentro de los corchetes cuadrados.

  1. Replace the # añade tu variable expression_1 acá comment with the following code:

     expression_1 = r'(\d{2})-(\d{2})-(\d{4})'

    By using (\d{2})-(\d{2})-(\d{4}) you get the matches that meet that grouping pattern, you are telling it to find you numbers that are grouped as follows : 12-12-1234 .

  2. Replace the # añade tu variable expression_2 acá comment with the following code:

     expression_2 = r'[^\W\d]+-[^\W\d]{4}'

    By using [^\W\d]+-[^\W\d]{4} you are telling it to find some non-number characters in your text, followed by a - , followed by 4 other non-number characters , example: aaa-bbbb .

  3. Replace the # añade tu variable expression_3 acá comment with the following code:

     expression_3 = r'[AZ]+-\w{3}'

    By using [AZ]+-\w{3} you are telling it to find in your text uppercase letters followed by a -, followed by the next 3 characters of your search, example: RM-2sR .

  4. Replace the # añade tu variable expression_4 acá comment with the following code:

     expression_4 = r'f[\d]\w[\d]+'

    By using f[\d]\w[\d]+ you are telling it to find in your text that starts with the letter f, followed by a number, followed by a character, followed by a number, example: f6h7 .

Congratulations go to the next level!

regex search method

With this method we can search for a pattern in a text string.

This method receives 3 parameters, two that are required and one that is optional.

Syntax:

 re.search(tu_expresión_regular, tu_texto, un_flag)

The required parameters are tu_expresión_regular , tu_texto , and the optional one is the flags .

In this case we are going to use a flag that is re.M which means MultiLine(multi-line) makes it so that if the text has several line breaks it can search the entire text and not just up to its line break.

At the end it returns an object with that match, in case nothing is found it returns None .

  1. Replace the # añade tu metodo acá comment with the following code:

     re.search(r'(\d{2})-(\d{2})-(\d{4})', text, flags=re.M)[0]

    By using (\d{2})-(\d{2})-(\d{4}) you get the matches that meet that grouping pattern, you are telling it to find you numbers that are grouped as follows : 12-12-1234 .

Note : if you are wondering why we are using try, except, it is because we are catching the NoneType error when it does not find the match when doing this search re.search()[0]

Suggestion : you can see more about the flags in this link: https://pynative.com/python-regex-flags/#:~:text=re.MULTILINE-,The%20re.,used%20with%20metacharacter%20% 5E%20and%20%24%20.&text=When%20this%20flag%20is%20specified%2C%20the%20pattern%20character%20%5E%20matches%20at,newline's%20start%20(%20%5Cn%20 ) .

Congratulations go to the next level!

regex findAll method

With this method we can perform the search and find multiple matches within the text.

This method receives 3 parameters, two that are required and one that is optional.

Syntax:

 re.search(tu_expresión_regular, tu_texto, un_flag)

The required parameters are tu_expresión_regular , tu_texto , and the optional one is the flags .

In this case we are going to use a flag that is re.M which means MultiLine(multi-line) makes it so that if the text has several line breaks it can search the entire text and not just up to its line break.

At the end it returns a list with each match it has made.

  1. Replace the # añade tu metodo acá comment with the following code:

     re.findall(r'[^A-Z0-9\s-]+', text, flags=re.M)

    By using [^A-Z0-9\s-]+ you get the matches that meet that grouping pattern, you are telling it to do a search for you but to omit the capital letters, the numbers, the spaces and the - sign.

Congratulations, you have reached the end of the course!

Hello World

Welcome to this Django course where we will learn step by step everything you need to know to venture into backend development.

A bit of theory.

Django is a framework for developing web projects using the python language; Django defines a very characteristic design pattern which is MTV (model - template - view), where the model is everything related to the database, the template is the HTML files that are responsible for displaying data in that format and the The view is responsible for implementing the business logic.

In these first modules we will focus more on the last point, that is, the logic necessary for a Django project to work correctly.

So let's move on to writing our first "Hello world!" in this framework, to do this, note that in the editor at the top there are 3 tabs or files ( urls.py , views.py and index.html ), with which we will be working during the course.

We will explain how each file works later, for now stay in the views.py file .

  1. Replace the comment that says # my first view with the following:

 def index(request): # Respuesta de la vista.

Note: By convention the main view is usually named "index" but this is not required.

As you can see, a view is nothing more than a simple python function that receives an HTTP request ( request ) as its main parameter. This parameter is mandatory when working with views in django since it contains the metadata of the request.

  1. Now replace the # Response comment of the view with the following:

 return JsonResponse({'msg': '¡Hola Mundo!'}, status=200)

Notice that we are returning a response of type Json which contains the message "Hello world!" and its status is 200 , we will go into more of these topics later so don't worry if you don't fully understand it by now.

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see in the test cases, the response it gives us is precisely the message “Hello world!” which we define in the function.

Congratulations, you have created your first hello world, it is time to continue advancing and delving a little more into each of the files we have, see you in the next lesson.

What are urls?

The urls.py file is responsible for defining where a request is directed. Django uses a list ( urlpatterns ) to do this job, in general terms Django looks for the corresponding path and if it finds it in the list it calls the view in charge of its operation, you can think of this file as an air controller which as the planes arrive, this tells them where they should land.

A url looks something like this: ejemplo_dominio.co/ruta

The last part of the url, in this case ' ruta ' will be the one Django looks for in the urls.py file

Let's see it in practice.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Add your route here with the following:

 path("", # Invoca la vista aquí ),

Note that in this case the route does not have a name, this is because it is the main route of the application.

Note: The main view may or may not have a name, so it is not mandatory to leave a path without a name.

  1. A route always calls a view, now replace the comment it says with the following:

 views.index

Notice that in this case we have called the index function found in the views.py file.

Don't forget to close the parentheses of the path method or you may have a runtime error.

  1. Click the run button.

Now we have the same result as in the previous lesson, with the difference that this time we did the process in reverse and now you know better how the routes of a project work.

It's time to move on to the next lesson and review the relationship between views and paths in more detail.

URLs and views

This time we will see a little more in depth how views and urls work as a whole, for this we will create a small application for a restaurant that allows us to send the menu once the view is called.

Let's define the url.

Let's start by adding a " menu " url which will call a view with the same name.

  1. Replace the comment that says # menu url here with the following:

   path('menu', views.menu)

As you already know, when Django receives the request it looks for the required route, in this case ' menu ', once found it calls the associated view so that it handles the request, so let's move on to creating the view.

Let's start by creating the function that will handle the view, for that go to the views.py file.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Create the menu view here

 def menu(request): # Crea el contexto aqui

Let's continue creating a context, the context is nothing more than the content or body of the response in Json format, let's see it in practice to make it clearer.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Create the context here with the following:

 context = [ { "nombre": "Ensalada", "precio": 10 }, { "nombre": "Filete de res", "precio": 20 }, { "nombre": "Jugos tropicales", "precio": 15 } ] # Emite tu respuesta aquí

As a last step we are going to return the response, remember that we are working with Json format so we need to return a response of the same type.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Post your answer here with the following:

 return JsonResponse(context, status=200, safe=False)

  1. Click the run button.

As expected, the response provided by Django is just the specified context, which, as we said, contains a restaurant menu.

Alright, you've finished this lesson, it's time to move on and get to know new features of Django, see you in the next lesson.

HTTP methods

In web development we have several types of HTTP methods which help us to control the requests made to the server and so that the server knows what to do with said request.

We have several types of HTTP methods such as:

  • GET

  • POST

  • PUT

  • PATCH

  • DELETE

  • HEAD

Throughout these lessons we have worked with one of the main ones, which is the GET method, this is used to send data to the template as we did in the previous lesson by passing a context through a response in Json format.

How to know which is the method used in the request?

The method used arrives as an attribute of the HTTPrequest object that we pass to the view, that is, we can access it by using the dot nomenclature as shown in the following example:

 request.method == 'GET'

Note that in this case we want to check if the method used is " GET " but we can use it to check any of them like " POST " or " PUT ", etc.

So let's see if the method we're actually using is GET .

  1. Replace the comment that says # Validate the request here with the following:

 if request.method == "GET": return JsonResponse({'msg': 'La petición fue de tipo GET'}, status=200) else: return JsonResponse({'msg': 'La petición NO es de tipo GET'}, status=200)

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see in the test cases, the first one was made with a GET type request, so the returned message is " The request was of GET type ", but for the second case the request is of POST type what the returned message is “ The request is NOT of type GET ”

For now, don't worry if you don't understand very well what the purpose of these requests is, for now we are only presenting their basic syntax and in future more advanced levels we will review them in more depth.

POST method

The POST method is used to send data to the server and have it do the necessary operations with that data.

Let's see this time how we can use the POST method to make a small program that returns the sum of two numbers or, if the request is not a POST, returns an alert message.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Process the request here in the views.py file with the following:

 suma = 5 + 4 return JsonResponse({'suma': f'La suma de 5 + 4 es: {suma}'}, status=200)

Now returns the message "The request is not a POST" in case the requested method is not POST.

  1. Replace the comment that says # In case it is not a POST with the following:

 else: return JsonResponse({'msg': 'La petición no es un POST'}, status=200)

  1. Click the run button.

If you see you will realize that the first one returns the result of the sum since it is a POST, just as expected!, but in the second case we only have the alert message since as you can imagine it is not a POST method .

Congratulations, you have finished this introductory course to Django which serves as a basis for the others that come later and we will be reviewing each of the topics covered in this one in more depth, remember to continue educating.

See you next time.

Requests and methods

We welcome you to this basic level Django course, where we will delve into HTTP requests and methods so that you can understand and master this topic, which, although basic, is still one of the most important in web development.

Throughout this course we will be working with simulated data as a dictionary in Python, this will be our representation, for now, of the database.

GET-method

The GET method is commonly used to make requests to the server and therefore obtain a response with the requested data.

  1. Create the path 'programming - languages ' in the url.py file, to do so replace the # language path comment here with the following:

 path('lenguajes', views.lenguajes),

Now go to the views.py file there you will see a list like the following:

 lenguajes = [ { 'nombre': 'Python', 'año_de_aparicion': '1991', 'es_tipado_dinamico': True }, { 'nombre': 'C#', 'año_de_aparicion': '2000', 'es_tipado_dinamico': False }, ]

  1. We are going to return just such a list every time the request is of type get, replace the comment that says # GET Request here .

 if request.method == 'GET': return JsonResponse(lenguajes, status=200, safe=False)

Note: When the response we want to send is in list format, we must change the safe parameter (which defaults to True ) of the JsonResponse method, then it would be: safe=False .

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see in the test cases, the response was exactly what was expected, that is, a list with information about programming languages.

Very well, you have finished this first lesson, in the next one we will see the POST method in depth, see you there.

POST method

We use this method to create new records in the database, imagine that we have a form where what we want is to add a new language to the list that we have from the last lesson, let's see how we can do this, remember to locate yourself in the views.py file views.py .

  1. Create a conditional to validate if the method used is POST, to do this replace the comment that says # POST Validation here with the following:

 elif request.method == 'POST': # obtener datos desde la petición POST

It is time to obtain the data that has been sent through the method used.

  1. Now add the following replacing the # get data from POST request comment.

 nuevo_lenguaje = request.POST.get('lenguaje') # guarda los datos aquí

Once the data is obtained, it is time to save it or in this case add it to the list that we already have.

  1. Replace the comment that says # save data here with the following:

 lenguaje.append(nuevo_lenguaje) # Retorna la respuesta aquí

Finally, it returns a message indicating that everything went well and the record has been created successfully.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Return the response here with the following:

 return JsonResponse({'msg': 'Nuevo lenguaje agregado con exito.'}, status=200)

Very well now you know what it is for and how the POST method is used in a Django project, in the next lessons we will be seeing the other methods and their uses, see you there.

PUT Method

The PUT method is normally used to update or create new records in the database, updating being its main use in web programming.

In the last lesson we had added a new programming language in our database list, let's say that for some reason that was not the new language that we wanted to add so we are going to change or update its values.

  1. Create a conditional to validate if the method used is PUT, to do this replace the comment that says # PUT Validation here with the following:

 elif request.method == 'PUT': # Actualiza el registro aquí

Now that we know that the method is PUT, we proceed to update the last record in the list of languages.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Update the record here with the following:

 datos_para_actualizar = request.data.get('lenguaje') lenguajes[-1] = datos_para_actualizar # Retorna la lista aquí

Note: For now we are updating the last record because we already knew it in advance, but in more advanced courses we will see how we can select a specific one, sending parameters through the request.

Once the registry is updated, we are going to return the list of languages to know what their new values are.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Return the list here with the following:

 return JsonResponse(lenguajes, status=200, safe=False)

  1. Click the run button.

Now in the test cases you will be able to see how the values that we previously had in the “ database ” have been updated, just what we need, simple, don't you think?

We have concluded this lesson, do not slow down and keep moving forward.

PATCH method

The PATCH method is used to make partial updates of a resource, for example if we wanted to update the name of a user in some application, we will most likely want to use the PATCH method to carry out this function.

In this lesson we are going to update the first record of our list of languages, let's see how we can do that.

  1. Create a conditional to validate if the method used is PATCH, to do this replace the comment that says # PATCH Validation here with the following:

 elif request.method == 'PATCH': # Actualiza el registro aquí

  1. Replace the comment that says # Update the record here with the following:

 nombre = request.data.get('nombre') lenguajes[0]['nombre'] = nombre # Retorna la lista aquí

Since this time we only needed to update one of the fields, we were much more specific when obtaining it in order to be able to reference exactly what we required.

Once the registry is updated, we are going to return the list of languages to know what their new values are.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Return the list here with the following:

 return JsonResponse(lenguajes, status=200, safe=False)

  1. Click the run button.

If you scroll down to the test cases, you will notice that the value of the "name" field of the first record has now changed to "JavaScript" .

How well you do, let's move on to the next lesson where we will learn about the last method that we are missing which is DELETE , see you there.

DELETE method

The last method that we will see in this course is DELETE which, as its name indicates, is used to delete or delete a record, its use is quite simple in most cases, let's see it in action.

On this occasion we are going to eliminate the last record from our list of languages with which we have been working throughout the course.

  1. Create a conditional to validate if the method used is DELETE, to do this replace the comment that says # Validation DELETE here with the following:

 elif request.method == 'DELETE': # Elimina el registro aquí

  1. Replace the comment that says # Delete the record here with the following:

 # Retorna la lista aquí

As you can see, the operation we do in this method is very simple, since we only have to worry about literally deleting the record we need.

Finally we return the list of languages to see if what we need was really done

  1. Replace the comment that says # Return the list here with the following:

 return JsonResponse(lenguajes, status=200, safe=False)

  1. Click the run button.

If everything goes well you should be able to see how in the test cases only 2 records appear in the list, instead of 3 as it was initially.

Congratulations, you have reached the end of this basic level Django course where you learned about the 5 main methods used on the web and what their specific use is, see you next time.

django templates

We welcome you to this Django course where you will have the opportunity to learn what Django templates are and what they are for, as well as their syntax and basic structure.

What are templates?

Roughly speaking, the templates are the part in charge of displaying the data to the user, through an HTML document.

Interpolation.

When we talk about interpolation in Django we refer to the process by which we can inject data sent by the view, into an HTML file following the double brace syntax {{...}} , which we will see in the following examples, without further ado What to add let's move on to the code.

As usual, we are going to create a small application so that its understanding is easier.

  1. Go to the index.html file and replace the comment that says <!-- First interpolation --> with the following:

 <h2>¡Estoy aprendiendo {{ framework }}!</h2>

  1. Click the run button.

You can see how in the test cases the result is “I'm learning Django!” Alright, let's proceed to see why this happens.

Go to the views.py file and locate the following code:

 return render(request, 'index.html', {'framework': 'Django'})

As you can see, the index function returns a render() function which is precisely responsible for rendering our template or HTML document and passing it a context, in this case the name of the Django framework.

Note: the aforementioned render() function must always receive the instance of the HttpRequest class and the path where the HTML file is located.

You have finished this lesson very well, in the next ones we will delve more into these topics in addition to seeing new things, do not miss it and continue with the next lesson.

Conditionals I

When working with Django templates it is also possible to implement certain logic, just as if we were working directly with Python within the HTML file, although this is not what really happens, so let's see how we can use conditionals within an application with Django templates.

We have already seen that the syntax used to interpolate data that comes from the views is by using the double brace {{...}} , however, to make use of conditionals and other sentences we must implement the syntax {%...%} , let's see it in code.

  1. Go to the HTML editor and replace the comment that says <!-- First conditional --> with the following:

 {% if es_visible %} <h3>Este subtítulo está condicionado por Django</h3> {% endif %}

As you can see, the syntax used for conditionals is very similar to the one used by Python.

  1. Click the run button.

Note that since the condition is not met, the result obtained is different from the expected one, but this is the least of it, the most important thing is that the content can be controlled dynamically from the templates.

  1. Go to the views.py file and change the value of “ es_visible ” to True.

 {'es_visible': True}

  1. Run your code again.

On this occasion, everything should be fine since the condition is met, so it executes or displays the block that is inside the if conditional.

Congratulations, you have completed this lesson, it is time to continue advancing and delve deeper into the subject of conditionals, see you.

Conditionals II

As we said, the syntax to use conditionals in Django templates is very similar to Python, so we can also use strings like if - elif - else , this time we will see how we can do that.

Django handles all logical statements in blocks, this means that every block that is opened must be closed, as the following example shows:

 {% if condición %} {% elif condición %} {% else %} {% endif %}

Note that there is only one closing tag {% endif %} , this is so because all statements of this type correspond to a single chain, it would be different if there were 2 if blocks in that case each one would need its corresponding closure.

Alright, now it's time to create a little program that displays a different result depending on how high a number sent by the view is.

  1. Create an if block with the condition numero<=3 , replacing the comment that says <!-- if block here -->

 {% if numero <= 3 %} <p>El número esta en el rango más bajo.</p> <!-- Siguiente condición aquí --> {% endif %}

  1. Make a following condition that says nuemro>3 and numero<=6 , replace the comment that says <!-- Next condition here --> .

 {% elif nuemro>3 and numero<=6 %} <p>El número está en el rango de la mitad.</p> <!-- condición por defecto aquí -->

Finally, create an else block in case the previous conditions are not met.

  1. Replace the comment that says <!-- default condition here --> .

 {% else %} <p>El número esta en el rango más alto de todos.</p>

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see the result is “ The number is in the middle range ”, if you change the number sent in the view to other ranges, you will surely see a different result.

Remember, a blockchain has a common closure tag and separate blocks have their own closure.

Congratulations, you have completed this lesson where you learned about conditional blocks in Django template, it's time to move on and find out what else we can do.

Interpolation and conditionals

One of the advantages of using a different syntax for interpolation and for blocks is that they allow us to identify at a glance what we are doing in addition to avoiding execution conflicts, which is why this time we will see how we can make use of both concepts in the same template.

Go to the views.py file and create a context.

  1. Replace the comment that says # Create the context here

 # Plataforma de productos contexto = { 'nombre': 'Calcetines', 'disponible': True, 'precio': 5 } return render(request, 'index.html', contexto)

Alright, now that we have the context, it's time to go to the templates, so go to the index.html file.

  1. Replace the comment that says <!-- Availability condition --> with the following:

 {% if disponible %} <!-- Interpolación de productos aquí --> {% endif %}

  1. Now replace the comment <!-- Product interpolation here --> with:

 <h1>Nombre del producto: {{ nombre }}</h1> <p>Precio: <strong>${{ precio }}</strong></p>

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see, as our code grows it becomes more common for us to mix these concepts.

Excellent, you have completed this lesson and you are one step closer to finishing the course, in the next one we will see how we can use cycles within Django templates, don't miss it.

loops

As in any programming language, loops allow us to perform repetitive tasks without the need to repeat the instructions, Django templates has a very similar functionality which we will explain this time, let's start.

In the last lesson we had a product that was displayed or not depending on whether it was available, we are going to create a list which we can go through with a loop and thus fully understand the use of this statement.

Create a list of products which will be passed as a context to the template.

  1. In the views.py file, replace the comment that says #List of products here with the following:

 productos = [ { 'nombre': 'Calcetines', 'disponible': True, 'precio': 5 }, { 'nombre': 'Pantalón', 'disponible': True, 'precio': 20 }, { 'nombre': 'Camiseta', 'disponible': True, 'precio': 12 }, ]

  1. In the index.html file replace the comment that says <!-- for loop here -->

 {% for producto in productos %} <!-- Productos aquí --> {% endfor %}

As you can see, creating a cycle has a syntax identical to that used by conditionals, that is, braces and an opening and closing percentage sign, also note that to end the block we use {% endfor %}

Finally, let's complete the code with the information we want to repeat.

  1. Replace the comment that says <!-- Products here --> with the following:

 {% if producto.disponible %} <h1>Nombre del producto: {{ producto.nombre }}</h1> <p>Precio: <strong>${{ producto.precio }}</strong></p> {% endif %}

Note: note that on this occasion in order to access the values we must use the dot nomenclature, since we are iterating over each dictionary in a list.

  1. Click the run button.

As you can see in the test cases, the code inside the for block is repeated for each of the products in the list, just what we needed, great right?


Congratulations, you have completed this course on templates in Django, surely there is still a lot to see on this subject so if you want to go deeper you can click here . See you next time.

Introduction to basic Node JS tutorial

Welcome to our Node JS tutorial. In this and the following modules we will teach you the most important things you need to know about this tool.

let's see a little

Let's show a hello world :D.

  1. Replace the text that says // Añade tu código acá with the following code:

     message: 'Hello World'

Alright, move on to the next module!

Modules and exports

In Node JS you have your own built-in module system. You will say But what are the built-in modules? In short, in a Node JS project you can have many files as you can see in this image.

and we use module.exports to be able to export them in any other file in our project.

Let's see a little more on the subject

  1. Replace the text that says // Añade tu código acá with the following code:

     const hello_world = (event, context, callback) => { let myMessage = 'Hello World' const response = { statusCode: 200, body: JSON.stringify({ message: myMessage }), }; callback(null, response); };

    With this code you are sending a hello world message to the response of your endpoint.

  2. Replace the text that says // exporta tu función acá with the following code:

     module.exports = { hello_world }

    With this code you are exporting that function so that another file can call the internal functionalities of your code.

Note : In our Node JS in the browser course you won't have to worry about creating multiple files in the project, we already do that internally.

Alright, move on to the next module!

Modules and Exports 2

We can do the functions in this way.

Let's see a little more on the subject

  1. Replace the text that says // Añade tu código acá with the following code:

     module.exports.hello_world = (event, context, callback) => { let myMessage = 'Hello World' const response = { statusCode: 200, body: JSON.stringify({ message: myMessage }), }; callback(null, response); };

    Notice that we create the function and export it right away.

Alright, move on to the next module!

Parameters in the functions.

We can send parameters to our functions as you have already seen in our JS courses.

Let's see a little more on the subject

  1. Replace the text that says // Añade tu código acá with the following code:

     module.exports.add = (param1, param2, callback) => { // añade num1 acá // añade num2 acá let result = num1 + num2; const response = { statusCode: 200, body: { result: result, }, }; callback(null, response); };

    Note that we create the function and export it immediately, that function receives 3 parameters: param1, param2 and callback. We will use param1 in this class.

    In param1 are two variables firstNumber and secondNumber that we will use to create a function that adds those two numbers that come.

  2. Replace the text that says // Añade num1 acá with the following code:

     let num1 = param1.firstNumer;

    We capture the data from param1.firstNumber into our num1 variable.

  3. Replace the text that says // Añade num2 acá with the following code:

     let num2 = param1.secondNumber;

    We capture the data from param1.secondNumber into our num2 variable.

  4. Run the Code and see the result.

Alright, move on to the next module!
